369 <script>

370var w=window;if(w.performance||w.mozPerformance||w.msPerformance||w.webkitPerformance){var d=document;AKSB=w.AKSB||{},AKSB.q=AKSB.q||[],AKSB.mark=AKSB.mark||function(e,_){AKSB.q.push(["mark",e,_||(new Date).getTime()])},AKSB.measure=AKSB.measure||function(e,_,t){AKSB.q.push(["measure",e,_,t||(new Date).getTime()])},AKSB.done=AKSB.done||function(e){AKSB.q.push(["done",e])},AKSB.mark("firstbyte",(new Date).getTime()),AKSB.prof={custid:"855684",ustr:"",originlat:"0",clientrtt:"8",ghostip:"124.106.175.183",ipv6:false,pct:"10",clientip:"122.52.203.188",requestid:"739b798",region:"38280",protocol:"",blver:14,akM:"dscb",akN:"ae",akTT:"O",akTX:"1",akTI:"739b798",ai:"547368",ra:"false",pmgn:"",pmgi:"",pmp:"",qc:""},function(e){var _=d.createElement("script");_.async="async",_.src=e;var t=d.getElementsByTagName("script"),t=t[t.length-1];t.parentNode.insertBefore(_,t)}(("https:"===d.location.protocol?"https:":"http:")+"//ds-aksb-a.akamaihd.net/aksb.min.js")}</script>

371

372 </head>

851

852 <h1>

853Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment (PDQ)Health Professional Version</h1>

854

855 <div id="cgvBody">

856

857 <div class="summary-sections">

858

859 <nav class="on-this-page" role="navigation">

860

861 <h6>

862On This Page</h6>

863

864 <ul>

865

866 <li>

869</li>

870

871 <li>

939</li>

957

958</nav>

959

960

961 <div class="accordion">

962

963

964

965 <section id="_1">

966

967 <h2>

968General Information About Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL)</h2>

969

970 <div id="_section_1" class="pdq-sections">

971<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

972<h6>

973In This Section</h6>

974<ul>

975<li>

976<a href="#_2_toc">

977Incidence and Mortality</a>

978</li>

979<li>

980<a href="#_5_toc">

981 Anatomy </a>

982</li>

983<li>

984<a href="#_7_toc">

985Prognosis and Survival</a>

986</li>

987</ul>

988</nav>

989<div class="pdq-hp-patient-toggle">

990<a href="/types/lymphoma/patient/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq">

991Go to Patient Version</a>

992</div>

993<p id="_9" tabindex="-1">

994The non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHL) are a heterogeneous group of lymphoproliferative malignancies with differing patterns of behavior and responses to treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9951</a>

996]</p>

997<p id="_10" tabindex="-1">

998Like Hodgkin lymphoma, NHL usually originates in lymphoid tissues and can spread to other organs. NHL, however, is much less predictable than Hodgkin lymphoma and has a far greater predilection to disseminate to extranodal sites. The prognosis depends on the histological type, stage, and treatment.</p>

999<section id="_2">

1000<h3 id="_2_toc">

1001Incidence and Mortality</h3>

1002<p id="_3" tabindex="-1">

1003Estimated new cases and deaths from NHL in the United States in 2023:[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

10042</a>

1005]</p>

1006<div class="pdq-content-list">

1007<ul id="_4">

1008<li>

1009New cases: 80,550.</li>

1010<li>

1011Deaths: 20,180.</li>

1012</ul>

1013</div>

1014</section>

1015<section id="_5">

1016<h3 id="_5_toc">

1017 Anatomy </h3>

1018<p id="_6" tabindex="-1">

1019NHL usually originates in lymphoid tissues.</p>

1020<figure id="figure_11" class="image-center-medium">

1021<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/533339.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

1022Enlarge</a>

1023<img id="_11" alt="Lymph system; drawing shows the lymph vessels and lymph organs including the lymph nodes, tonsils, thymus, spleen, and bone marrow. One inset shows the inside structure of a lymph node and the attached lymph vessels with arrows showing how the lymph (clear fluid) moves into and out of the lymph node. Another inset shows a close up of bone marrow with blood cells." title="Lymph system; drawing shows the lymph vessels and lymph organs including the lymph nodes, tonsils, thymus, spleen, and bone marrow. One inset shows the inside structure of a lymph node and the attached lymph vessels with arrows showing how the lymph (clear fluid) moves into and out of the lymph node. Another inset shows a close up of bone marrow with blood cells." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/533339-750.jpg">

1024<figcaption class="caption-container">

1025Anatomy of the lymph system.</figcaption>

1026</figure>

1027</section>

1028<section id="_7">

1029<h3 id="_7_toc">

1030Prognosis and Survival</h3>

1031<p id="_677" tabindex="-1">

1032NHL can be divided into two prognostic groups: the indolent lymphomas and the aggressive lymphomas.</p>

1033<p id="_14" tabindex="-1">

1034 Indolent NHL types have a relatively good prognosis, with a median survival as long as 20 years, but they usually are not curable in advanced clinical stages.[<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

10353</a>

1036] Early-stage (stage I and stage II) indolent NHL can be effectively treated with radiation therapy alone. Most of the indolent types are nodular (or follicular) in morphology.</p>

1037<p id="_15" tabindex="-1">

1038 The aggressive type of NHL has a shorter natural history, but a significant number of these patients can be cured with intensive combination chemotherapy regimens.</p>

1039<p id="_16" tabindex="-1">

1040 In general, with modern treatment of patients with NHL, the overall survival rate at 5 years is over 60%. More than 50% of patients with aggressive NHL can be cured. Most relapses occur in the first 2 years after therapy. The risk of late relapse is higher in patients who manifest both indolent and aggressive histologies.[<a href="#cit/section_1.4">

10414</a>

1042]</p>

1043<p id="_17" tabindex="-1">

1044While indolent NHL is responsive to immunotherapy, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy, a continuous rate of relapse is usually seen in advanced stages. However, patients can often be re-treated with considerable success if the disease histology remains low grade. Patients who present with or convert to aggressive forms of NHL may have sustained complete remissions with combination chemotherapy regimens or aggressive consolidation with marrow or stem cell support.[<a href="#cit/section_1.5">

10455</a>

1046,<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

10476</a>

1048]</p>

1049</section>

1050<h6 do-not-show="toc">

1051References</h6>

1052<ol>

1053<li id="section_1.1">

1054Shankland KR, Armitage JO, Hancock BW: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Lancet 380 (9844): 848-57, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22835603&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22835603&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1055[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1056</li>

1057<li id="section_1.2">

1058American Cancer Society: Cancer Facts and Figures 2023. American Cancer Society, 2023. <a href="https://www.cancer.org/content/dam/cancer-org/research/cancer-facts-and-statistics/annual-cancer-facts-and-figures/2023/2023-cancer-facts-and-figures.pdf" title="https://www.cancer.org/content/dam/cancer-org/research/cancer-facts-and-statistics/annual-cancer-facts-and-figures/2023/2023-cancer-facts-and-figures.pdf">

1059Available online</a>

1060. Last accessed June 8, 2023.</li>

1061<li id="section_1.3">

1062Tan D, Horning SJ, Hoppe RT, et al.: Improvements in observed and relative survival in follicular grade 1-2 lymphoma during 4 decades: the Stanford University experience. Blood 122 (6): 981-7, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23777769&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23777769&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1063[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1064</li>

1065<li id="section_1.4">

1066Cabanillas F, Velasquez WS, Hagemeister FB, et al.: Clinical, biologic, and histologic features of late relapses in diffuse large cell lymphoma. Blood 79 (4): 1024-8, 1992.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=1737086&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=1737086&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1067[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1068</li>

1069<li id="section_1.5">

1070Bastion Y, Sebban C, Berger F, et al.: Incidence, predictive factors, and outcome of lymphoma transformation in follicular lymphoma patients. J Clin Oncol 15 (4): 1587-94, 1997.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9193357&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9193357&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1071[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1072</li>

1073<li id="section_1.6">

1074Yuen AR, Kamel OW, Halpern J, et al.: Long-term survival after histologic transformation of low-grade follicular lymphoma. J Clin Oncol 13 (7): 1726-33, 1995.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7602362&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7602362&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1075[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1076</li>

1077</ol>

1078</div>

1079

1080 </section>

1081

1082

1083

1084 <section id="_18">

1085

1086 <h2>

1087Late Effects of Treatment of NHL</h2>

1088

1089 <div id="_section_18" class="pdq-sections">

1090<p id="_169" tabindex="-1">

1091Late effects of treatment of non-Hodgkin lymphoma

1092

1093

1094(NHL) have been observed. Impaired fertility may occur after exposure to alkylating agents.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

10951</a>

1096] For as many as three decades after diagnosis, patients are at a significantly elevated risk of developing second primary cancers, especially the following:[<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

10972</a>

1098-<a href="#cit/section_2.5">

10995</a>

1100]</p>

1101<div class="pdq-content-list">

1102<ul id="_170">

1103<li>

1104Lung cancer.</li>

1105<li>

1106Brain cancer.</li>

1107<li>

1108Kidney cancer.</li>

1109<li>

1110Bladder cancer.</li>

1111<li>

1112 Melanoma.</li>

1113<li>

1114Hodgkin lymphoma.</li>

1115<li>

1116Acute nonlymphocytic leukemia.</li>

1117</ul>

1118</div>

1119<p id="_171" tabindex="-1">

1120Left ventricular dysfunction was a significant late effect in long-term survivors of high-grade NHL who received more than 200 mg/m&#178; of doxorubicin.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

11211</a>

1122,<a href="#cit/section_2.6">

11236</a>

1124]</p>

1125<p id="_172" tabindex="-1">

1126Myelodysplastic syndrome and acute myelogenous leukemia are late complications of myeloablative therapy with autologous bone marrow or peripheral blood stem cell support, as well as conventional chemotherapy-containing alkylating agents.[<a href="#cit/section_2.3">

11273</a>

1128,<a href="#cit/section_2.7">

11297</a>

1130-<a href="#cit/section_2.14">

113114</a>

1132] Most of these patients show clonal hematopoiesis even before the transplantation, suggesting that the hematologic injury usually occurs during induction or reinduction chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.9">

11339</a>

1134,<a href="#cit/section_2.15">

113515</a>

1136,<a href="#cit/section_2.16">

113716</a>

1138] With a median 10-year follow-up after autologous bone marrow transplantation (BMT) with conditioning using cyclophosphamide and total-body radiation therapy, the incidence of a second malignancy was 21% in a series of 605 patients, and 10% of those were solid tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.17">

113917</a>

1140] </p>

1141<p id="_682" tabindex="-1">

1142Successful pregnancies with children born free of congenital abnormalities have been reported in young women after autologous BMT.[<a href="#cit/section_2.18">

114318</a>

1144] Late-occurring venous thromboembolism can occur after allogeneic or autologous BMT.[<a href="#cit/section_2.19">

114519</a>

1146]</p>

1147<p id="_1221" tabindex="-1">

1148Long-term impaired immune health was evaluated in a retrospective cohort study of 21,690 survivors of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma from the California Cancer Registry. Elevated incidence rate ratios were found up to 10 years later for pneumonia (10.8-fold), meningitis (5.3-fold), immunoglobulin deficiency (17.6-fold), and autoimmune cytopenias (12-fold).[<a href="#cit/section_2.20">

114920</a>

1150] Similarly, there are impaired humoral responses to COVID-19 virus vaccination in patients with lymphoma who receive B-cell&#8211;directed therapies.[<a href="#cit/section_2.21">

115121</a>

1152,<a href="#cit/section_2.22">

115322</a>

1154]</p>

1155<p id="_683" tabindex="-1">

1156Some patients have osteopenia or osteoporosis at the start of therapy; bone density may worsen after therapy for lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.23">

115723</a>

1158]</p>

1159<h6 do-not-show="toc">

1256

1257 </section>

1258

1259

1260

1261 <section id="_20">

1262

1263 <h2>

1264Cellular Classification of NHL</h2>

1265

1266 <div id="_section_20" class="pdq-sections">

1267<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

1268<h6>

1269In This Section</h6>

1270<ul>

1271<li>

1272<a href="#_22_toc">

1273Historical Classification Systems</a>

1274</li>

1275<li>

1276<a href="#_25_toc">

1277Current Classification Systems<ul>

1278<li>

1279<a href="#_27_toc">

1280Updated REAL/WHO classification</a>

1281</li>

1282</ul>

1283</a>

1284</li>

1285</ul>

1286</nav>

1287<p id="_21" tabindex="-1">

1288A pathologist should be considered for consultation before a biopsy because some studies require special preparation of tissue (e.g., frozen tissue). Knowledge of cell surface markers and immunoglobulin and T-cell receptor gene rearrangements may help with diagnostic and therapeutic decisions. The clonal excess of light-chain immunoglobulin may differentiate malignant from reactive cells. Since the prognosis and the approach to treatment are influenced by histopathology, outside biopsy specimens should be carefully reviewed by a hematopathologist who is experienced in diagnosing lymphomas. Although lymph node biopsies are recommended whenever possible, sometimes immunophenotypic data are sufficient to allow diagnosis of lymphoma when fine-needle aspiration cytology is preferred.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

12891</a>

1290,<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

12912</a>

1292]</p>

1293<section id="_22">

1294<h3 id="_22_toc">

1295Historical Classification Systems</h3>

1296<p id="_23" tabindex="-1">

1297Historically, uniform treatment of patients with non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) has been hampered by the lack of a uniform classification system. In 1982, results of a consensus study were published as the Working Formulation.[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

12983</a>

1299] The Working Formulation combined results from six major classification systems into one classification. This allowed comparison of studies from different institutions and countries. The Rappaport classification, which also follows, is no longer in common use.</p>

1300<table id="_24" class="table-default expandable-container">

1301<caption>

1302Table 1. Historical Classification Systems for Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL)</caption>

1303<colgroup>

1304<col width="50.00%">

1305<col width="50.00%">

1306</colgroup>

1307<THead>

1308<tr>

1309<th align="Center" scope="col">

1310Working Formulation [<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

13113</a>

1312] </th>

1313<th align="Center" scope="col">

1314Rappaport Classification </th>

1315</tr>

1316</THead>

1317<tbody>

1318<tr>

1319<td>

1320<strong>

1321Low grade</strong>

1322</td>

1323<td>

1324&#160;</td>

1325</tr>

1326<tr>

1327<td>

1328A. Small lymphocytic, consistent with chronic lymphocytic leukemia</td>

1329<td>

1330Diffuse lymphocytic, well-differentiated</td>

1331</tr>

1332<tr>

1333<td>

1334B. Follicular, predominantly small-cleaved cell</td>

1335<td>

1336Nodular lymphocytic, poorly differentiated</td>

1337</tr>

1338<tr>

1339<td>

1340C. Follicular, mixed small-cleaved, and large cell</td>

1341<td>

1342Nodular mixed, lymphocytic, and histiocytic</td>

1343</tr>

1344<tr>

1345<td>

1346<strong>

1347Intermediate grade</strong>

1348</td>

1349<td>

1350&#160;</td>

1351</tr>

1352<tr>

1353<td>

1354D. Follicular, predominantly large cell</td>

1355<td>

1356Nodular histiocytic</td>

1357</tr>

1358<tr>

1359<td>

1360E. Diffuse, small-cleaved cell</td>

1361<td>

1362Diffuse lymphocytic, poorly differentiated</td>

1363</tr>

1364<tr>

1365<td>

1366F. Diffuse mixed, small and large cell</td>

1367<td>

1368Diffuse mixed, lymphocytic, and histiocytic</td>

1369</tr>

1370<tr>

1371<td>

1372G. Diffuse, large cell, cleaved, or noncleaved cell</td>

1373<td>

1374Diffuse histiocytic</td>

1375</tr>

1376<tr>

1377<td>

1378<strong>

1379High grade</strong>

1380</td>

1381<td>

1382&#160;</td>

1383</tr>

1384<tr>

1385<td>

1386H. Immunoblastic, large cell</td>

1387<td>

1388Diffuse histiocytic</td>

1389</tr>

1390<tr>

1391<td>

1392I. Lymphoblastic, convoluted, or nonconvoluted cell</td>

1393<td>

1394Diffuse lymphoblastic</td>

1395</tr>

1396<tr>

1397<td>

1398J. Small noncleaved-cell, Burkitt, or non-Burkitt</td>

1399<td>

1400Diffuse undifferentiated Burkitt or non-Burkitt</td>

1401</tr>

1402</tbody>

1403</table>

1404</section>

1405<section id="_25">

1406<h3 id="_25_toc">

1407Current Classification Systems</h3>

1408<p id="_26" tabindex="-1">

1409As the understanding of NHL has improved and as the histopathological diagnosis of NHL has become more sophisticated with the use of immunologic and genetic techniques, a number of new pathological entities have been described.[<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

14104</a>

1411] In addition, the understanding and treatment of many of the previously described pathological subtypes have changed. As a result, the Working Formulation has become outdated and less useful to clinicians and pathologists. Thus, European and American pathologists have proposed a new classification, the Revised European American Lymphoma (REAL) classification.[<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

14125</a>

1413-<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

14148</a>

1415] Since 1995, members of the European and American Hematopathology societies have been collaborating on a new World Health Organization (WHO) classification, which represents an updated version of the REAL system.[<a href="#cit/section_3.9">

14169</a>

1417,<a href="#cit/section_3.10">

141810</a>

1419]</p>

1420<p id="_397" tabindex="-1">

1421The WHO modification of the REAL classification recognizes three major categories

1422of lymphoid malignancies based on morphology and cell lineage: B-cell

1423neoplasms, T-cell/natural killer (NK)-cell neoplasms, and Hodgkin lymphoma (HL).

1424Both lymphomas and lymphoid leukemias are included in this classification

1425because both solid and circulating phases are present in many lymphoid

1426neoplasms and distinction between them is artificial. For example, B-cell

1427chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and B-cell small lymphocytic lymphoma are simply

1428different manifestations of the same neoplasm, as are lymphoblastic lymphomas

1429and acute lymphocytic leukemias. Within the B-cell and T-cell categories, two

1430subdivisions are recognized: precursor neoplasms, which correspond to the

1431earliest stages of differentiation, and more mature differentiated

1432neoplasms.[<a href="#cit/section_3.9">

14339</a>

1434,<a href="#cit/section_3.10">

143510</a>

1436]</p>

1437<section id="_27">

1438<h4 id="_27_toc">

1439Updated REAL/WHO classification</h4>

1440<div class="pdq-content-list">

1441<p class="pdq-list-title">

1442B-cell neoplasms</p>

1443<ol id="_28">

1444<li>

1445Precursor B-cell neoplasm: precursor B-acute lymphoblastic

1446leukemia/lymphoblastic lymphoma (LBL).</li>

1447<li>

1448Peripheral B-cell neoplasms.<div class="pdq-content-list">

1449<ol id="_29" class="lower-alpha">

1450<li>

1451B-cell CLL/small lymphocytic lymphoma.</li>

1452<li>

1453B-cell prolymphocytic leukemia.</li>

1454<li>

1455Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma/immunocytoma.</li>

1456<li>

1457Mantle cell lymphoma.</li>

1458<li>

1459Follicular lymphoma.</li>

1460<li>

1461Extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphoma of mucosa-associated lymphatic tissue (MALT) type.</li>

1462<li>

1463Nodal marginal zone B-cell lymphoma (&#177; monocytoid B-cells).</li>

1464<li>

1465Splenic marginal zone lymphoma (&#177; villous lymphocytes).</li>

1466<li>

1467Hairy cell leukemia.</li>

1468<li>

1469Plasmacytoma/plasma cell myeloma.</li>

1470<li>

1471Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.</li>

1472<li>

1473Burkitt lymphoma.</li>

1474</ol>

1475</div>

1476</li>

1477</ol>

1478</div>

1479<div class="pdq-content-list">

1480<p class="pdq-list-title">

1481T-cell and putative NK-cell neoplasms</p>

1482<ol id="_30">

1483<li>

1484Precursor T-cell neoplasm: precursor T-acute lymphoblastic leukemia/LBL.</li>

1485<li>

1486Peripheral T-cell and NK-cell neoplasms.<div class="pdq-content-list">

1487<ol id="_31" class="lower-alpha">

1488<li>

1489T-cell CLL/prolymphocytic leukemia.</li>

1490<li>

1491T-cell granular lymphocytic leukemia.</li>

1492<li>

1493Mycosis fungoides (including S&#233;zary syndrome).</li>

1494<li>

1495Peripheral T-cell lymphoma, not otherwise characterized.</li>

1496<li>

1497Hepatosplenic gamma/delta T-cell lymphoma.</li>

1498<li>

1499Subcutaneous panniculitis-like T-cell lymphoma.</li>

1500<li>

1501Angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.</li>

1502<li>

1503Extranodal T-/NK-cell lymphoma, nasal type.</li>

1504<li>

1505Enteropathy-type intestinal T-cell lymphoma.</li>

1506<li>

1507Adult T-cell lymphoma/leukemia (human T-lymphotrophic virus [HTLV] 1+).</li>

1508<li>

1509Anaplastic large cell lymphoma, primary systemic type.</li>

1510<li>

1511Anaplastic large cell lymphoma, primary cutaneous type.</li>

1512<li>

1513Aggressive NK-cell leukemia.</li>

1514</ol>

1515</div>

1516</li>

1517</ol>

1518</div>

1519<div class="pdq-content-list">

1520<p class="pdq-list-title">

1521HL</p>

1522<ol id="_32">

1523<li>

1524Nodular lymphocyte-predominant HL.

1525</li>

1526<li>

1527Classical HL.<div class="pdq-content-list">

1528<ol id="_33" class="lower-alpha">

1529<li>

1530Nodular sclerosis HL.</li>

1531<li>

1532Lymphocyte-rich classical HL.</li>

1533<li>

1534Mixed-cellularity HL.</li>

1535<li>

1536Lymphocyte-depleted HL.</li>

1537</ol>

1538</div>

1539</li>

1540</ol>

1541</div>

1542</section>

1543<section id="_1471">

1544<p id="_1470" tabindex="-1">

1545The REAL classification encompasses all the lymphoproliferative neoplasms. For more information, see the following PDQ summaries:</p>

1546<div class="pdq-content-list">

1547<ul id="_35">

1548<li>

1549<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/adult-all-treatment-pdq">

1550Adult Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment</a>

1551</li>

1552<li>

1553<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-hodgkin-treatment-pdq">

1554Adult Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment</a>

1555</li>

1556<li>

1557<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/aids-related-treatment-pdq">

1558AIDS-Related Lymphoma Treatment</a>

1559</li>

1560<li>

1561<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/cll-treatment-pdq">

1562Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Treatment</a>

1563</li>

1564<li>

1565<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/hairy-cell-treatment-pdq">

1566Hairy Cell Leukemia Treatment</a>

1567</li>

1568<li>

1569<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/mycosis-fungoides-treatment-pdq">

1570Mycosis Fungoides (Including S&#233;zary Syndrome) Treatment</a>

1571</li>

1572<li>

1573<a href="/types/myeloma/patient/myeloma-treatment-pdq">

1574Plasma Cell Neoplasms (Including Multiple Myeloma) Treatment</a>

1575</li>

1576<li>

1579</li>

1581</div>

1582</section>

1583</section>

1629

1630 <section id="_608">

1631

1632 <h2>

1633Indolent NHL</h2>

1634

1635 <div id="_section_608" class="pdq-sections">

1636<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

1637<h6>

1638In This Section</h6>

1639<ul>

1640<li>

1641<a href="#_552_toc">

1642Follicular Lymphoma<ul>

1643<li>

1644<a href="#_554_toc">

1645Prognosis</a>

1646</li>

1647<li>

1648<a href="#_559_toc">

1649Therapeutic approaches</a>

1650</li>

1651</ul>

1652</a>

1653</li>

1654<li>

1655<a href="#_562_toc">

1656Lymphoplasmacytic Lymphoma (Waldenstr&#246;m Macroglobulinemia)<ul>

1657<li>

1658<a href="#_567_toc">

1659Therapeutic approaches</a>

1660</li>

1661</ul>

1662</a>

1663</li>

1664<li>

1665<a href="#_571_toc">

1666Marginal Zone Lymphoma<ul>

1667<li>

1668<a href="#_573_toc">

1669Gastric MALT</a>

1670</li>

1671<li>

1672<a href="#_575_toc">

1673Extragastric MALT</a>

1674</li>

1675<li>

1676<a href="#_577_toc">

1677Nodal marginal zone lymphoma</a>

1678</li>

1679<li>

1680<a href="#_579_toc">

1681Mediterranean abdominal lymphoma</a>

1682</li>

1683<li>

1684<a href="#_581_toc">

1685Splenic marginal zone lymphoma</a>

1686</li>

1687</ul>

1688</a>

1689</li>

1690<li>

1691<a href="#_584_toc">

1692Primary Cutaneous Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma</a>

1693</li>

1694</ul>

1695</nav>

1696<p id="_609" tabindex="-1">

1697Indolent non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) includes the following subtypes:</p>

1698<div class="pdq-content-list">

1699<ul id="_610">

1700<li>

1701<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_552">

1702Follicular lymphoma</a>

1703.</li>

1704<li>

1705<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_562">

1706Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (Waldenstr&#246;m macroglobulinemia)</a>

1707.</li>

1708<li>

1709<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_571">

1710Marginal zone lymphoma</a>

1711.</li>

1712<li>

1713<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_581">

1714Splenic marginal zone lymphoma</a>

1715.</li>

1716<li>

1717<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_584">

1718Primary cutaneous anaplastic large cell lymphoma</a>

1719.</li>

1720</ul>

1721</div>

1722<section id="_552">

1723<h3 id="_552_toc">

1724Follicular Lymphoma</h3>

1725<p id="_553" tabindex="-1">

1726Follicular lymphoma comprises 20% of all NHL and as many as 70% of the indolent lymphomas reported in American and European clinical trials.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

17271</a>

1728-<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

17293</a>

1730] Most patients with follicular lymphoma are age 50 years and older and present with widespread disease at diagnosis. Nodal involvement is most common and is often accompanied by splenic and bone marrow disease. Rearrangement of the <em class="gene-name">

1731BCL2</em>

1732 gene is present in more than 90% of patients with follicular lymphoma; overexpression of the BCL2 protein is associated with the inability to eradicate the lymphoma by inhibiting apoptosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

17334</a>

1734]</p>

1735<section id="_554">

1736<h4 id="_554_toc">

1737Prognosis</h4>

1738<p id="_555" tabindex="-1">

1739Despite the advanced stage, the median survival ranges from 8 to 15 years, leading to the designation of being indolent.[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

17405</a>

1741-<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

17427</a>

1743] Patients with advanced-stage follicular lymphoma are not cured with current therapeutic options. The rate of relapse is fairly consistent over time, even in patients who have achieved complete responses to treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

17448</a>

1745] Watchful waiting, i.e., the deferring of treatment until the patient becomes symptomatic, is an option for patients with advanced-stage follicular lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_4.9">

17469</a>

1747,<a href="#cit/section_4.10">

174810</a>

1749] An international index for follicular lymphoma (i.e., the Follicular Lymphoma International Prognostic Index [FLIPI]) [<a href="#cit/section_4.11">

175011</a>

1751-<a href="#cit/section_4.13">

175213</a>

1753] identified five significant risk factors prognostic of overall survival (OS):</p>

1754<div class="pdq-content-list">

1755<ol id="_556">

1756<li>

1757Age (&#8804;60 years vs. &gt;60 years).</li>

1758<li>

1759Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) (normal vs. elevated).</li>

1760<li>

1761Stage (stage I or stage II vs. stage III or stage IV).</li>

1762<li>

1763Hemoglobin level (&#8805;120 g/L vs. &lt;120 g/L).</li>

1764<li>

1765Number of nodal areas (&#8804;4 vs. &gt;4).</li>

1766</ol>

1767</div>

1768<p id="_557" tabindex="-1">

1769Patients with one risk factor or none have an 85% 10-year survival rate, and three or more risk factors confer a 40% 10-year survival rate.[<a href="#cit/section_4.11">

177011</a>

1771] In a revised FLIPI-2, an elevated beta-2-microglobulin and lymph node size of more than 6 cm are proposed prognostic factors instead of serum LDH and the number of nodal areas.[<a href="#cit/section_4.14">

177214</a>

1773] Although the FLIPI and FLIPI-2 indices can predict progression-free survival (PFS) and OS, the scores cannot be used to establish the need for therapy, nor can they be used to predict response to therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.11">

177411</a>

1775,<a href="#cit/section_4.14">

177614</a>

1777] The primary use of FLIPI or FLIPI-2 is to assure a balance of prognostic factors or to define entry requirements in randomized clinical trials. Individuals with an adverse FLIPI score may well benefit from watchful waiting or may respond well to initial therapy. An alternative prognostic index using only beta-2-microglobulin and initial bone marrow involvement (PRIMA-PI) has the disadvantage of requiring an invasive test not usually required outside the context of a clinical trial.[<a href="#cit/section_4.15">

177815</a>

1779] An alternative prognostic index using only noninvasive clinical variables outperformed FLIPI, FLIPI-2, and PRIMA-PI, using data from immunochemotherapy trials.[<a href="#cit/section_4.16">

178016</a>

1781]</p>

1782<p id="_919" tabindex="-1">

1783Three retrospective analyses, including one pooled analysis of 5,225 patients in 13 randomized clinical trials, identified a high-risk group that had a 50% OS rate at 5 years when relapses occurred within 24 months of induction chemoimmunotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.17">

178417</a>

1785-<a href="#cit/section_4.19">

178619</a>

1787] A fourth retrospective analysis of 296 patients who received bendamustine-rituximab found a 2-year OS rate of 38% (95% confidence interval [CI], 20%&#8722;55%) among those with progression of disease before 24 months (POD24). Most of these patients (76%) had transformed disease (histological progression to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma [DLBCL]).[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

178820</a>

1789] These higher-risk POD24 patients represent a target population for clinical trials.</p>

1790<p id="_558" tabindex="-1">

1791Follicular, small-cleaved cell lymphoma and follicular mixed small-cleaved and large cell lymphoma do not have reproducibly different disease-free survival or OS.</p>

1792</section>

1793<section id="_559">

1794<h4 id="_559_toc">

1795Therapeutic approaches</h4>

1796<p id="_1044" tabindex="-1">

1797Because of the often-indolent clinical course and the lack of symptoms in some patients with follicular lymphoma, watchful waiting remains a standard of care during the initial encounter and for patients with slow asymptomatic relapsing disease. When therapy is required, numerous therapeutic options may be employed in varying sequences with an OS equivalence at 5 to 10 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.9">

17989</a>

1799,<a href="#cit/section_4.21">

180021</a>

1801-<a href="#cit/section_4.23">

180223</a>

1803] Rituximab can be given alone or in combination with various chemotherapy options.[<a href="#cit/section_4.23">

180423</a>

1805,<a href="#cit/section_4.24">

180624</a>

1807] Rituximab can also be combined with the immunomodulating-agent lenalidomide to avoid the short- and long-term toxicities of cytotoxic agents.[<a href="#cit/section_4.25">

180825</a>

1809-<a href="#cit/section_4.27">

181027</a>

1811] Another anti&#8211;CD20 monoclonal antibody, obinutuzumab, can be administered with combination chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.28">

181228</a>

1813] Inhibitors of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) are also effective in patients with relapsed or refractory disease.[<a href="#cit/section_4.29">

181429</a>

1815] CD19-directed chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells may be used In patients who have disease progression after two or more prior lines of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.30">

181630</a>

1817] Mosunetuzumab, a bispecific CD20-directed CD3 T-cell engager, may also be used in this setting.[<a href="#cit/section_4.31">

181831</a>

1819] Consolidation therapy for relapsed disease after reinduction therapy using autologous stem cell transplant (SCT) or allogeneic SCT can be considered.[<a href="#cit/section_4.32">

182032</a>

1821]</p>

1822<p id="_560" tabindex="-1">

1823Follicular lymphoma <em>

1824in situ</em>

1825 and primary follicular lymphoma of the duodenum are particularly indolent variants that rarely progress and rarely require therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.33">

182633</a>

1827,<a href="#cit/section_4.34">

182834</a>

1829] A so-called pediatric-type nodal follicular lymphoma has indolent behavior and rarely recurs; adult patients with this histological variant are characterized by a lack of <em class="gene-name">

1830BCL2</em>

1831 rearrangement in conjunction with a Ki-67 proliferation index greater than 30% and a localized stage I presentation.[<a href="#cit/section_4.35">

183235</a>

1833]</p>

1834<p id="_561" tabindex="-1">

1835Patients with indolent lymphoma may experience a relapse with a more aggressive histology. If the clinical pattern of relapse suggests that the disease is behaving in a more aggressive manner, a biopsy can be performed, if feasible.[<a href="#cit/section_4.36">

183636</a>

1837] Documentation of conversion to a more aggressive histology requires an appropriate change to a therapy applicable to that histological type.[<a href="#cit/section_4.37">

183837</a>

1839] Rapid growth or discordant growth between various disease sites may indicate a histological conversion.[<a href="#cit/section_4.36">

184036</a>

1841] The risk of histological transformation was 30% by 10 years in a retrospective review of 325 patients from diagnosis between 1972 and 1999.[<a href="#cit/section_4.38">

184238</a>

1843] In this series, high-risk factors for subsequent histological transformation were advanced stage, high-risk FLIPI, and expectant management (as opposed to treatment being initiated at diagnosis). The 5-year OS rate was more than 50% for patients who had biopsy-proven, aggressive-histology transformation in several multicenter cohort studies employing rituximab plus anthracycline or platinum-based chemotherapy, or similar therapy followed by autologous or allogeneic SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_4.36">

184436</a>

1845,<a href="#cit/section_4.39">

184639</a>

1847,<a href="#cit/section_4.40">

184840</a>

1849] </p>

1850<p id="_842" tabindex="-1">

1851In a prospective nonrandomized study, at a median follow-up of 6.8 years, 379 (14%) of 2,652 patients subsequently transformed to a more aggressive histology after an initial diagnosis of follicular lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_4.41">

185241</a>

1853][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1854Level of evidence C3</a>

1855] The median OS after subsequent transformation was 5 years; however, among 47 patients with evidence of transformation in conjunction with follicular lymphoma at the time of initial diagnosis, the OS was no worse than that of the other nontransformed patients (5-year OS rate, 88%; 95% CI, 74%&#8211;95%).</p>

1856</section>

1857</section>

1858<section id="_562">

1859<h3 id="_562_toc">

1860Lymphoplasmacytic Lymphoma (Waldenstr&#246;m Macroglobulinemia)</h3>

1861<p id="_563" tabindex="-1">

1862Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma is usually associated with a monoclonal serum paraprotein of immunoglobulin M (IgM) type (Waldenstr&#246;m macroglobulinemia).[<a href="#cit/section_4.42">

186342</a>

1864] Most patients have bone marrow, lymph node, and splenic involvement, and some patients may develop hyperviscosity syndrome. Most patients with Waldenstr&#246;m macroglobulinemia carry the <em class="gene-name">

1865MYD88</em>

1866 mutation, which some pathologists consider pathognomonic for the disease.[<a href="#cit/section_4.43">

186743</a>

1868] Other lymphomas may also be associated with serum paraproteins. Patients with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma should be checked for associated hepatitis C virus infection.</p>

1869<p id="_564" tabindex="-1">

1870Asymptomatic patients can be monitored for evidence of disease progression without immediate need for chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.9">

18719</a>

1872,<a href="#cit/section_4.44">

187344</a>

1874,<a href="#cit/section_4.45">

187545</a>

1876]</p>

1877<p id="_565" tabindex="-1">

1878 Prognostic factors associated with symptoms requiring therapy include the following: </p>

1879<div class="pdq-content-list">

1880<ul id="_566">

1881<li>

1882Age 70 years or older.</li>

1883<li>

1884Beta-2-microglobulin of 3 mg/dL or more. </li>

1885<li>

1886Increased serum LDH.[<a href="#cit/section_4.44">

188744</a>

1888]</li>

1889</ul>

1890</div>

1891<section id="_567">

1892<h4 id="_567_toc">

1893Therapeutic approaches</h4>

1894<p id="_568" tabindex="-1">

1895The management of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma is similar to that of other low-grade lymphomas, especially diffuse, small lymphocytic lymphoma/chronic lymphocytic leukemia.[<a href="#cit/section_4.46">

189646</a>

1897-<a href="#cit/section_4.48">

189848</a>

1899] If the viscosity relative to water is greater than four, the patient may have manifestations of hyperviscosity. Plasmapheresis is useful for temporary, acute symptoms such as retinopathy, congestive heart failure, and central nervous system (CNS) dysfunction but can be combined with chemotherapy for prolonged disease control. Symptomatic patients with a serum viscosity of four or lower are usually started directly on chemoimmunotherapy or biologically directed therapies. Therapy may be required to correct hemolytic anemia in patients with chronic cold agglutinin disease; rituximab, bendamustine, and steroids are often used.[<a href="#cit/section_4.45">

190045</a>

1901] Occasionally, a heated room is required for patients whose cold agglutinins become activated by even minor chilling. Sutimlimab, an immunoglobulin G4 monoclonal antibody that selectively inhibits the complement pathway at C15, can reduce hemolysis when therapies directed at the lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma prove ineffective.[<a href="#cit/section_4.49">

190249</a>

1903]</p>

1904<p id="_1288" tabindex="-1">

1905First-line regimens include rituximab and ibrutinib (a Bruton tyrosine kinase [BTK] inhibitor), rituximab alone, the nucleoside analogues, and alkylating agents, either as single agents or as part of combination chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.50">

190650</a>

1907-<a href="#cit/section_4.54">

190854</a>

1909] In a randomized prospective trial, 150 symptomatic patients (including previously untreated and relapsing patients) received either ibrutinib and rituximab or rituximab and a placebo. With a median follow-up of 50 months, the 4.5 year PFS rate favored the ibrutinib-and-rituximab arm (68%; 95% CI, 55%&#8211;78%) versus the rituximab-and-placebo arm (25%; 95% CI, 15%&#8211;37%) (hazard ratio, 0.25; 95% CI, 0.15&#8211;0.42; <em>

1910P </em>

1911&lt; .0001), and the OS rate at 30 months was no different in the two arms (92%&#8211;94%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.54">

191254</a>

1913][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1914Level of evidence B1</a>

1915] Zanubrutinib, another BTK inhibitor, was compared with ibrutinib in a randomized prospective clinical trial of 164 patients with relapsed disease and 38 previously untreated patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.55">

191655</a>

1917] With a median follow-up of 18 months, the PFS rate was the same in both groups at 84%. The zanubrutinib group had fewer cases of atrial fibrillation (11 vs. 1) and 50% fewer cases of hypertension (statistics not provided).[<a href="#cit/section_4.55">

191855</a>

1919][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1920Level of evidence C3</a>

1921] BTK inhibition with ibrutinib allowed all 13 patients with cold-antibody&#8211;mediated autoimmune hemolytic anemia and acrocyanosis to attain clinical remission regardless of underlying pathology or <em class="gene-name">

1922MYD88</em>

1923 status.[<a href="#cit/section_4.56">

192456</a>

1925][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1926Level of evidence C3</a>

1927]</p>

1928<p id="_569" tabindex="-1">

1929Previously untreated patients who received rituximab had response rates of 60% to 80%, but close monitoring of the serum IgM is required because of a sudden rise in this paraprotein at the start of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.50">

193050</a>

1931,<a href="#cit/section_4.57">

193257</a>

1933,<a href="#cit/section_4.58">

193458</a>

1935][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1936Level of evidence C3</a>

1937] The rise of IgM after rituximab can be avoided with the concomitant use of an alkylating agent, such as cyclophosphamide or the proteosome inhibitors bortezomib or ixazomib.[<a href="#cit/section_4.45">

193845</a>

1939,<a href="#cit/section_4.59">

194059</a>

1941-<a href="#cit/section_4.61">

194261</a>

1943] A combination of bortezomib, dexamethasone, and rituximab has been used with avoidance of an IgM rebound.[<a href="#cit/section_4.62">

194462</a>

1945-<a href="#cit/section_4.64">

194664</a>

1947] Previously untreated patients with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma who received the nucleoside analogues cladribine and fludarabine have shown similar response rates.[<a href="#cit/section_4.53">

194853</a>

1949,<a href="#cit/section_4.65">

195065</a>

1951,<a href="#cit/section_4.66">

195266</a>

1953][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1954Level of evidence C3</a>

1955] Patients who received single-agent alkylators, bendamustine, bortezomib, venetoclax, and combination chemotherapy with or without rituximab also show similar response rates.[<a href="#cit/section_4.53">

195653</a>

1957,<a href="#cit/section_4.59">

195859</a>

1959,<a href="#cit/section_4.61">

196061</a>

1961,<a href="#cit/section_4.67">

196267</a>

1963-<a href="#cit/section_4.71">

196471</a>

1965][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1966Level of evidence C3</a>

1967] In the rare case of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma involving the CNS (Bing-Neel syndrome), ibrutinib resulted in an 85% response rate in an anecdotal series of 28 patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.72">

196872</a>

1969][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1970Level of evidence C3</a>

1971]</p>

1972<p id="_570" tabindex="-1">

1973Myeloablative therapy with autologous or allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell support is under clinical evaluation.[<a href="#cit/section_4.73">

197473</a>

1975-<a href="#cit/section_4.76">

197676</a>

1977] Candidates for this approach should avoid long-term use of alkylating agents or purine nucleoside analogues, which can deplete hematopoietic stem cells or predispose patients to myelodysplasia or acute leukemia.[<a href="#cit/section_4.50">

197850</a>

1979,<a href="#cit/section_4.77">

198077</a>

1981] After relapse from alkylating-agent therapy, 92 patients with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma were randomly assigned to either fludarabine or cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, and prednisone. Although relapse-free survival favored fludarabine (median duration of 19 months vs. 3 months, <em>

1982P</em>

1983 &lt; .01), no difference was observed in OS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.78">

198478</a>

1985][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1986Level of evidence B1</a>

1987] </p>

1988</section>

1989</section>

1990<section id="_571">

1991<h3 id="_571_toc">

1992Marginal Zone Lymphoma</h3>

1993<p id="_572" tabindex="-1">

1994When marginal zone lymphomas involve the nodes, they are called monocytoid B-cell lymphomas or nodal marginal zone B-cell lymphomas, and when they involve extranodal sites (e.g., gastrointestinal tract, thyroid, lung, breast, orbit, and skin), they are called mucosa-associated lymphatic tissue (MALT) lymphomas.[<a href="#cit/section_4.79">

199579</a>

1996,<a href="#cit/section_4.80">

199780</a>

1998] Splenic marginal zone lymphoma is a distinct clinical entity that usually presents with massive splenomegaly. A variant form of MALT lymphoma is known as immunoproliferative small intestinal disease (IPSID).[<a href="#cit/section_4.80">

199980</a>

2000] A prognostic index for all of the marginal zone lymphomas has three adverse prognostic factors: age 70 years or older, stage III or stage IV disease, and high LDH level.[<a href="#cit/section_4.81">

200181</a>

2002] Fewer than 10% of patients transform to a higher-grade lymphoma; risk factors in one retrospective review included elevated LDH, more than four nodal sites at the time of initial diagnosis of marginal zone lymphoma, and failure to achieve complete response after initial treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_4.82">

200382</a>

2004]</p>

2005<section id="_573">

2006<h4 id="_573_toc">

2007Gastric MALT</h4>

2008<p id="_574" tabindex="-1">

2009Many patients have a history of autoimmune disease, such as Hashimoto thyroiditis or Sj&#246;gren syndrome, or of <em>

2010Helicobacter</em>

2011 gastritis. Most patients present with stage I or stage II extranodal disease, which is most often in the stomach. Treatment of <em>

2012Helicobacter pylori</em>

2013 infection may resolve most cases of localized gastric involvement.[<a href="#cit/section_4.83">

201483</a>

2015,<a href="#cit/section_4.84">

201684</a>

2017] After standard antibiotic regimens, 50% of patients show resolution of gastric MALT by endoscopy after 3 months. Other patients may show resolution after 12 to 18 months of observation. Of the patients who attain complete remission, 30% demonstrate monoclonality by immunoglobulin heavy chain rearrangement on stomach biopsies with a 5-year median follow-up.[<a href="#cit/section_4.85">

201885</a>

2019] The clinical implication of this finding is unknown. Translocation t(11;18) in patients with gastric MALT predicts for poor response to antibiotic therapy, for <em>

2020H. pylori</em>

2021&#8211;negative testing, and for poor response to oral alkylator chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.86">

202286</a>

2023-<a href="#cit/section_4.88">

202488</a>

2025] Stable asymptomatic patients with persistently positive biopsies have been successfully followed on a watchful waiting approach until disease progression.[<a href="#cit/section_4.84">

202684</a>

2027] Patients who progress are treated with radiation therapy,[<a href="#cit/section_4.89">

202889</a>

2029-<a href="#cit/section_4.93">

203093</a>

2031] rituximab,[<a href="#cit/section_4.94">

203294</a>

2033] surgery (total gastrectomy or partial gastrectomy plus radiation therapy),[<a href="#cit/section_4.95">

203495</a>

2035] chemotherapy,[<a href="#cit/section_4.96">

203696</a>

2037] or combined-modality therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.97">

203897</a>

2039] The use of endoscopic ultrasonography may help clinicians to follow responses in these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.98">

204098</a>

2041] Four case series encompassing more than 100 patients with stage IE or IIE DLBCL with or without associated MALT (but <em>

2042H. pylori</em>

2043-positive) reported durable complete remissions in more than 50% of the patients after treatment of <em>

2044H. pylori</em>

2045.[<a href="#cit/section_4.99">

204699</a>

2047-<a href="#cit/section_4.102">

2048102</a>

2049]</p>

2050</section>

2051<section id="_575">

2052<h4 id="_575_toc">

2053Extragastric MALT</h4>

2054<p id="_576" tabindex="-1">

2055 Localized involvement of other sites can be treated with radiation or surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_4.90">

205690</a>

2057-<a href="#cit/section_4.92">

205892</a>

2059,<a href="#cit/section_4.103">

2060103</a>

2061-<a href="#cit/section_4.106">

2062106</a>

2063] Patients with extragastric MALT lymphoma have a higher relapse rate than patients with gastric MALT lymphoma in some series, with relapses many years and even decades later.[<a href="#cit/section_4.107">

2064107</a>

2065] Many of these recurrences involve different MALT sites than the original location.[<a href="#cit/section_4.108">

2066108</a>

2067] When disseminated to lymph nodes, bone marrow, or blood, this entity behaves like other low-grade lymphomas.[<a href="#cit/section_4.109">

2068109</a>

2069,<a href="#cit/section_4.110">

2070110</a>

2071] A prospective, randomized trial of 401 patients with nongastric, extranodal MALT compared chlorambucil alone versus rituximab plus chlorambucil versus rituximab alone.[<a href="#cit/section_4.111">

2072111</a>

2073] With a median follow-up of 7.4 years, the event-free survival was better for the rituximab-plus-chlorambucil arm (68%) than for the rituximab-alone arm (51%) and for the chlorambucil-alone arm (50%) (<em>

2074P</em>

2075 = .0009). However, the 5-year OS rate was 90% in all arms.[<a href="#cit/section_4.111">

2076111</a>

2077] For patients with ocular adnexal MALT, antibiotic therapy using doxycycline that targeted <em>

2078Chlamydia psittaci</em>

2079 resulted in durable remissions for almost half of the patients in a review of the literature that included 131 patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.112">

2080112</a>

2081][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2082Level of evidence C3</a>

2083] These responses to doxycycline are mainly seen in Italian trials and less often in trials conducted in other geographic sites.[<a href="#cit/section_4.113">

2084113</a>

2085] Large B-cell lymphomas of MALT sites are classified and treated as diffuse large cell lymphomas.[<a href="#cit/section_4.114">

2086114</a>

2087] A large, retrospective review of primary ocular adnexal MALT found that after 10 years of follow-up, 4% of stage I patients treated with radiation therapy transformed to DLBCL, and 3% of them developed CNS involvement.[<a href="#cit/section_4.115">

2088115</a>

2089]</p>

2090</section>

2091<section id="_577">

2092<h4 id="_577_toc">

2093Nodal marginal zone lymphoma</h4>

2094<p id="_578" tabindex="-1">

2095Patients with nodal marginal zone lymphoma (monocytoid B-cell lymphoma) are treated with the same paradigm of watchful waiting or therapies as described for follicular lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_4.116">

2096116</a>

2097] Similar to follicular lymphoma, patients with POD24 who required initiation of therapy had a worse prognosis (53% 3-year OS rate) than did the patients without POD24 (95% 3-year OS rate).[<a href="#cit/section_4.117">

2098117</a>

2099] Among patients with concomitant hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection, 40% to 60% attained a complete or partial remission after loss of detectable HCV RNA with antiviral treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_4.118">

2100118</a>

2101,<a href="#cit/section_4.119">

2102119</a>

2103][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2104Level of evidence C3</a>

2105]</p>

2106</section>

2107<section id="_579">

2108<h4 id="_579_toc">

2109Mediterranean abdominal lymphoma</h4>

2110<p id="_580" tabindex="-1">

2111The disease variously known as Mediterranean abdominal lymphoma, heavy&#8211;chain disease, or IPSID, which occurs in young adults in eastern Mediterranean countries, is another version of MALT lymphoma, which responds to antibiotics in its early stages.[<a href="#cit/section_4.120">

2112120</a>

2113] <em>

2114Campylobacter jejuni</em>

2115 has been identified as one of the bacterial species associated with IPSID, and antibiotic therapy may result in remission of the disease.[<a href="#cit/section_4.121">

2116121</a>

2117]</p>

2118</section>

2119<section id="_581">

2120<h4 id="_581_toc">

2121Splenic marginal zone lymphoma</h4>

2122<p id="_582" tabindex="-1">

2123Splenic marginal zone lymphoma is an indolent lymphoma that is marked by massive splenomegaly and peripheral blood and bone marrow involvement, usually without adenopathy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

2124122</a>

2125,<a href="#cit/section_4.123">

2126123</a>

2127] This type of lymphoma is otherwise known as splenic lymphoma with villous lymphocytes. Splenectomy may result in prolonged remission.[<a href="#cit/section_4.124">

2128124</a>

2129,<a href="#cit/section_4.125">

2130125</a>

2131]</p>

2132<p id="_583" tabindex="-1">

2133 Management is similar to that of other low-grade lymphomas and usually involves rituximab alone or rituximab in combination with purine analogues or alkylating agent chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.126">

2134126</a>

2135] Splenic marginal zone lymphoma responds less well to chemotherapy, which would ordinarily be effective for chronic lymphocytic leukemia.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

2136122</a>

2137,<a href="#cit/section_4.126">

2138126</a>

2139,<a href="#cit/section_4.127">

2140127</a>

2141] Among small numbers of patients with splenic marginal zone lymphoma (splenic lymphoma with villous lymphocytes) and infection with HCV, most attained a complete or partial remission after loss of detectable HCV RNA with treatment using interferon-alpha with or without ribavirin.[<a href="#cit/section_4.118">

2142118</a>

2143,<a href="#cit/section_4.128">

2144128</a>

2145]; [<a href="#cit/section_4.129">

2146129</a>

2147][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2148Level of evidence C3</a>

2149] In contrast, no responses to interferon were seen in six HCV-negative patients.</p>

2150</section>

2151</section>

2152<section id="_584">

2153<h3 id="_584_toc">

2154Primary Cutaneous Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma</h3>

2155<p id="_585" tabindex="-1">

2156Primary cutaneous anaplastic large cell lymphoma presents in the skin only with no preexisting lymphoproliferative disease and no extracutaneous sites of involvement.[<a href="#cit/section_4.130">

2157130</a>

2158-<a href="#cit/section_4.132">

2159132</a>

2160] Patients with this type of lymphoma encompass a spectrum ranging from clinically benign lymphomatoid papulosis, marked by localized nodules that may regress spontaneously, to a progressive and systemic disease requiring aggressive doxorubicin-based combination chemotherapy. This spectrum has been called the primary cutaneous CD30-positive T-cell lymphoproliferative disorder.</p>

2161<p id="_586" tabindex="-1">

2162Patients with localized disease usually undergo radiation therapy. With more disseminated involvement, watchful waiting or doxorubicin-based combination chemotherapy is applied.[<a href="#cit/section_4.130">

2163130</a>

2164-<a href="#cit/section_4.132">

2165132</a>

2166]</p>

2167<p id="_587" tabindex="-1">

2168For more information, see <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/cll-treatment-pdq">

2169Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Treatment</a>

2170, <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/mycosis-fungoides-treatment-pdq">

2171Mycosis Fungoides (Including S&#233;zary Syndrome) Treatment</a>

2172, <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/hairy-cell-treatment-pdq">

2173Hairy Cell Leukemia Treatment</a>

2174, and <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-hodgkin-treatment-pdq">

2175Adult Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment</a>

2176.</p>

2177</section>

2178<h6 do-not-show="toc">

Br J Haematol 120 (5): 759-64, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12614206&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12614206&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2673[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2674</li>

2675<li id="section_4.126">

2676Arcaini L, Lazzarino M, Colombo N, et al.: Splenic marginal zone lymphoma: a prognostic model for clinical use. Blood 107 (12): 4643-9, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16493005&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16493005&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2677[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2678</li>

2679<li id="section_4.127">

2680Iannitto E, Ambrosetti A, Ammatuna E, et al.: Splenic marginal zone lymphoma with or without villous lymphocytes. Hematologic findings and outcomes in a series of 57 patients. Cancer 101 (9): 2050-7, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15389479&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15389479&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2681[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2682</li>

2683<li id="section_4.128">

2684Hermine O, Lefr&#232;re F, Bronowicki JP, et al.: Regression of splenic lymphoma with villous lymphocytes after treatment of hepatitis C virus infection. N Engl J Med 347 (2): 89-94, 2002.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12110736&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12110736&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2685[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2686</li>

2687<li id="section_4.129">

2688Kelaidi C, Rollot F, Park S, et al.: Response to antiviral treatment in hepatitis C virus-associated marginal zone lymphomas. Leukemia 18 (10): 1711-6, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15284859&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15284859&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2689[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2690</li>

2691<li id="section_4.130">

2692de Bruin PC, Beljaards RC, van Heerde P, et al.: Differences in clinical behaviour and immunophenotype between primary cutaneous and primary nodal anaplastic large cell lymphoma of T-cell or null cell phenotype. Histopathology 23 (2): 127-35, 1993.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8406384&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8406384&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2693[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2694</li>

2695<li id="section_4.131">

2696Willemze R, Beljaards RC: Spectrum of primary cutaneous CD30 (Ki-1)-positive lymphoproliferative disorders. A proposal for classification and guidelines for management and treatment. J Am Acad Dermatol 28 (6): 973-80, 1993.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8388410&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8388410&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2697[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2698</li>

2699<li id="section_4.132">

2700Kempf W, Pfaltz K, Vermeer MH, et al.: EORTC, ISCL, and USCLC consensus recommendations for the treatment of primary cutaneous CD30-positive lymphoproliferative disorders: lymphomatoid papulosis and primary cutaneous anaplastic large-cell lymphoma. Blood 118 (15): 4024-35, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21841159&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21841159&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2701[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2702</li>

2703</ol>

2704</div>

2705

2706 </section>

2707

2708

2709

2861</nav>

2862<p id="_83" tabindex="-1">

2863Aggressive non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) includes the following subtypes:</p>

2864<div class="pdq-content-list">

2865<ul id="_84">

2866<li>

2867<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_85">

2868Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma</a>

2869.</li>

2870<li>

2871<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_92">

2872Mediastinal large B-cell lymphoma (primary mediastinal large B-cell lymphoma)</a>

2873.</li>

2874<li>

2875<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_96">

2876Follicular large cell lymphoma</a>

2877.</li>

2878<li>

2879<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_100">

2880Anaplastic large cell lymphoma</a>

2881.</li>

2882<li>

2883<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_104">

2884Extranodal NK&#8211;/T-cell lymphoma</a>

2885.</li>

2886<li>

2887<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_107">

2888Lymphomatoid granulomatosis</a>

2889.</li>

2890<li>

2891<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_110">

2892Angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma</a>

2893.</li>

2894<li>

2895<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_113">

2896Peripheral T-cell lymphoma</a>

2897.</li>

2898<li>

2899<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_118">

2900Enteropathy-type intestinal T-cell lymphoma</a>

2901.</li>

2902<li>

2903<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_121">

2904Intravascular large B-cell lymphoma (intravascular lymphomatosis)</a>

2905.</li>

2906<li>

2907<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_124">

2908Burkitt lymphoma/diffuse small noncleaved-cell lymphoma</a>

2909.</li>

2910<li>

2911<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_128">

2912Lymphoblastic lymphoma</a>

2913.</li>

2914<li>

2915<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_131">

2916Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma</a>

2917.</li>

2918<li>

2919<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_135">

2920Mantle cell lymphoma</a>

2921.</li>

2922<li>

2923<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_139">

2924Polymorphic posttransplantation lymphoproliferative disorder</a>

2925.</li>

2926<li>

2927<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_143">

2928True histiocytic lymphoma</a>

2929.</li>

2930<li>

2931<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_146">

2932Primary effusion lymphoma</a>

2933.</li>

2934<li>

2935<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_810">

2936 Plasmablastic lymphoma</a>

2937.</li>

2938</ul>

2939</div>

2940<section id="_85">

2941<h3 id="_85_toc">

2942Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma</h3>

2943<p id="_86" tabindex="-1">

2944Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common type of NHL and comprises 30% of newly diagnosed cases.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

29451</a>

2946] Most patients present with rapidly enlarging masses, often with both local and systemic symptoms (designated B symptoms with fever, recurrent night sweats, or weight loss). For more information about weight loss, see <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/appetite-loss/nutrition-hp-pdq">

2947Nutrition in Cancer Care</a>

2948.</p>

2949<p id="_412" tabindex="-1">

2950Some cases of large B-cell lymphoma have a prominent background of reactive T cells and often of histiocytes, so-called T-cell/histiocyte-rich large B-cell lymphoma. This subtype of large cell lymphoma has frequent liver, spleen, and bone marrow involvement; however, the outcome is equivalent to that of similarly staged patients with DLBCL.[<a href="#cit/section_5.2">

29512</a>

2952-<a href="#cit/section_5.4">

29534</a>

2954] Some patients with DLBCL at diagnosis have a concomitant indolent small B-cell component; while overall survival (OS) appears similar after multidrug chemotherapy, there is a higher risk of indolent relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_5.5">

29555</a>

2956]</p>

2957<section id="_525">

2958<h4 id="_525_toc">

2959Prognosis</h4>

2960<p id="_87" tabindex="-1">

2961 Most patients with localized disease are curable with combined-modality therapy or combination chemotherapy alone.[<a href="#cit/section_5.6">

29626</a>

2963] Among patients with advanced-stage disease, 50% are cured with doxorubicin-based combination chemotherapy and rituximab, typically R-CHOP (rituximab, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone).[<a href="#cit/section_5.7">

29647</a>

2965-<a href="#cit/section_5.9">

29669</a>

2967]</p>

2968<p id="_88" tabindex="-1">

2969The National Comprehensive Cancer Network International Prognostic Index (IPI) for aggressive NHL (diffuse large cell lymphoma) identifies the following five significant risk factors prognostic of OS and their associated risk scores:[<a href="#cit/section_5.10">

297010</a>

2971]</p>

2972<div class="pdq-content-list">

2973<ul id="_1046">

2974<li>

2975Age.<div class="pdq-content-list">

2976<ul id="_1377" class="list-dash">

2977<li>

2978&lt;40 years: 0.</li>

2979<li>

298041&#8211;60 years: 1.</li>

2981<li>

298261&#8211;75 years: 2.</li>

2983<li>

2984&gt;75 years: 3.</li>

2985</ul>

2986</div>

2987</li>

2988<li>

2989Stage III/IV: 1.</li>

2990<li>

2991Performance status 2/3/4: 1.</li>

2992<li>

2993Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH).<div class="pdq-content-list">

2994<ul id="_1378" class="list-dash">

2995<li>

2996Normalized: 0.</li>

2997<li>

2998&gt;1x&#8211;3x: 1.</li>

2999<li>

3000&gt;3x: 2.</li>

3001</ul>

3002</div>

3003</li>

3004<li>

3005Number of extranodal sites &#8805;2: 1.</li>

3006</ul>

3007</div>

3008<p id="_1056" tabindex="-1">

3009Risk scores:</p>

3010<div class="pdq-content-list">

3011<ul id="_1057">

3012<li>

3013Low (0 or 1): 5-year OS rate, 96%; progression-free survival (PFS) rate, 91%.</li>

3014<li>

3015Low intermediate (2 or 3): 5-year OS rate, 82%; PFS rate, 74%.</li>

3016<li>

3017High intermediate (4 or 5): 5-year OS rate, 64%; PFS rate, 51%.</li>

3018<li>

3019High (&gt;6): 5-year OS rate, 33%; PFS rate, 30%.</li>

3020</ul>

3021</div>

3022<p id="_90" tabindex="-1">

3023Age-adjusted and stage-adjusted modifications of this IPI are used for younger patients with localized disease.[<a href="#cit/section_5.11">

302411</a>

3025] Shorter intervals of time between diagnosis and treatment appear to be a surrogate for poor prognostic biological factors.[<a href="#cit/section_5.12">

302612</a>

3027] </p>

3028<p id="_926" tabindex="-1">

3029The <em class="gene-name">

3030BCL2</em>

3031 gene and rearrangement of the <em class="gene-name">

3032MYC</em>

3033 gene or dual overexpression of the <em class="gene-name">

3034MYC</em>

3035 gene, or both, confer a particularly poor prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_5.13">

303613</a>

3037-<a href="#cit/section_5.15">

303815</a>

3039] Dose-intensive therapies, infusional therapies, and stem cell transplantation (SCT) consolidation are being explored in this high-risk group.[<a href="#cit/section_5.16">

304016</a>

3041,<a href="#cit/section_5.17">

304217</a>

3043] A retrospective review evaluated 159 patients with previously untreated DLBCL who underwent <em>

3044double-hit</em>

3045 genetic testing by fluorescence <em>

3046in situ</em>

3047 hybridization (FISH) and achieved complete response (CR).[<a href="#cit/section_5.18">

304818</a>

3049] The induction therapy did not alter 3-year relapse-free survival or OS when autologous SCT was employed.</p>

3050<p id="_897" tabindex="-1">

3051In a retrospective review of 117 patients with relapsed or refractory DLBCL who underwent autologous SCT, the 4-year OS rate was 25% for double-hit lymphomas (rearrangement of <em class="gene-name">

3052BCL2</em>

3053 and <em class="gene-name">

3054MYC</em>

3055), 61% for double-expressor lymphomas (no rearrangement, but increased expression of <em class="gene-name">

3056BCL2</em>

3057 and <em class="gene-name">

3058MYC</em>

3059), and 70% for patients without these features.[<a href="#cit/section_5.19">

306019</a>

3061] Patients at high risk of relapse may be considered for clinical trials.[<a href="#cit/section_5.20">

306220</a>

3063]</p>

3064<p id="_898" tabindex="-1">

3065 Molecular profiles of gene expression using DNA microarrays may help to stratify patients in the future for therapies directed at specific targets and to better predict survival after standard chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.21">

306621</a>

3067] For example, true anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK)-positive large B-cell lymphomas are extremely rare, and they do not respond well to conventional R-CHOP therapy. Anecdotal responses to ALK inhibitors like lorlatinib or alectinib have been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_5.22">

306822</a>

3069][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3070Level of evidence C3</a>

3071] Patients who have DLBCL with coexpression of CD20 and CD30 may define a subgroup with a unique molecular signature, a more favorable prognosis, and possible therapeutic implication for the use of anti-CD30&#8211;specific therapy, such as brentuximab vedotin.[<a href="#cit/section_5.23">

307223</a>

3073] Patients with DLBCL who are event-free after 2 years have a subsequent OS equivalent to that of the age- and sex-matched general population.[<a href="#cit/section_5.24">

307424</a>

3075]</p>

3076</section>

3077<section id="_526">

3078<h4 id="_526_toc">

3079Central nervous system (CNS) prophylaxis</h4>

3080<p id="_1346" tabindex="-1">

3081The CNS-IPI tool predicts which patients have a CNS relapse risk exceeding 10%. It was developed by the German Lymphoma Study Group and validated by the British Columbia Cancer Agency database. The presence of four to six of the CNS-IPI risk factors (age &gt;60 years, performance status &#8805;2, elevated LDH, stage III or IV disease, &gt;1 extranodal site, or involvement of the kidneys or adrenal glands) was used to define a high-risk group for CNS recurrence (a 12% risk of CNS involvement by 2 years).[<a href="#cit/section_5.25">

308225</a>

3083]</p>

3084<p id="_91" tabindex="-1">

3085CNS prophylaxis (usually with four to six doses of intrathecal methotrexate) is often recommended for patients with testicular involvement.[<a href="#cit/section_5.26">

308626</a>

3087-<a href="#cit/section_5.28">

308828</a>

3089][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3090Level of evidence C3</a>

3091] A retrospective analysis of the German RICOVER studies compared intrathecal methotrexate with no prophylaxis in patients with DLBCL. This study was completed during the R-CHOP treatment era. With the possible exception of patients with testicular involvement, the analysis showed that intrathecal methotrexate did not reduce the risk of CNS disease.[<a href="#cit/section_5.29">

309229</a>

3093][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3094Level of evidence C3</a>

3095] Some clinicians employ high-dose intravenous (IV) methotrexate (usually four doses) as an alternative to intrathecal therapy because drug delivery is improved and patient morbidity is decreased.[<a href="#cit/section_5.30">

309630</a>

3097] A retrospective study evaluated 1,162 patients from 21 U.S. academic centers where 77% received intrathecal methotrexate, 20% received high-dose IV methotrexate, and 3% received both sequentially (because of toxicity).[<a href="#cit/section_5.31">

309831</a>

3099] There was no difference in CNS relapse rates between patients who received intrathecal methotrexate or high-dose IV methotrexate (5.4% vs. 6.8%, <em>

3100P</em>

3101 = .40). Testicular involvement, nongerminal center subtype, and high extranodal involvement predicted increased CNS relapse regardless of the route of prophylaxis.[<a href="#cit/section_5.31">

310231</a>

3103] Two retrospective studies evaluating high-dose methotrexate in patients with high-risk DLBCL also showed no improvement in CNS relapse rate.[<a href="#cit/section_5.32">

310432</a>

3105,<a href="#cit/section_5.33">

310633</a>

3107][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3108Level of evidence C3</a>

3109] Patients deemed at high risk for CNS relapse (e.g., patients with four to six CNS-IPI risk factors) often receive intrathecal methotrexate or high-dose IV methotrexate, but the lack of confirmatory randomized studies calls this standard into question and shows an urgent need for better therapeutics verified in clinical trials. Patients with testicular involvement are an exception, as they show benefit from intrathecal or high-dose IV methotrexate.[<a href="#cit/section_5.26">

311026</a>

3111-<a href="#cit/section_5.28">

311228</a>

3113][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3114Level of evidence C3</a>

3115] </p>

3116<p id="_929" tabindex="-1">

3117The addition of rituximab to cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, prednisone (CHOP)-based regimens has significantly reduced the risk of CNS relapse in retrospective analyses.[<a href="#cit/section_5.29">

311829</a>

3119,<a href="#cit/section_5.34">

312034</a>

3121][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3122Level of evidence C3</a>

3123] Patients with CNS dissemination at diagnosis or at relapse usually receive rituximab and high doses of methotrexate and/or cytarabine followed by autologous SCT, but this approach has not been assessed in randomized trials.[<a href="#cit/section_5.35">

312435</a>

3125,<a href="#cit/section_5.36">

312636</a>

3127][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3128Level of evidence C3</a>

3129] </p>

3130</section>

3131</section>

3132<section id="_92">

3133<h3 id="_92_toc">

3134Primary Mediastinal Large B-cell Lymphoma</h3>

3135<p id="_93" tabindex="-1">

3136Primary mediastinal (thymic) large B-cell lymphoma (PMBCL) is a subset of DLBCL with molecular characteristics that are most similar to nodular-sclerosing Hodgkin lymphoma (HL).[<a href="#cit/section_5.37">

313737</a>

3138] Mediastinal lymphomas with features intermediate between primary mediastinal B-cell lymphoma and nodular-sclerosing HL are called mediastinal gray-zone lymphomas.[<a href="#cit/section_5.38">

313938</a>

3140,<a href="#cit/section_5.39">

314139</a>

3142] Patients are usually female and young (median age, 30&#8211;40 years). Patients present with a locally invasive anterior mediastinal mass that may cause respiratory symptoms or superior vena cava syndrome. </p>

3143<p id="_94" tabindex="-1">

3144 Prognosis and therapy are the same as for other comparably staged patients with DLBCL. Uncontrolled, phase II studies employing dose-adjusted R-EPOCH (etoposide, prednisone, vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and doxorubicin plus rituximab) or R-CHOP show high cure rates while avoiding any mediastinal radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.39">

314539</a>

3146-<a href="#cit/section_5.45">

314745</a>

3148][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3149Level of evidence C1</a>

3150] These results suggest that patients who receive R-CHOP&#8211;based regimens may avoid the serious long-term complications of radiation therapy when given with chemotherapy. Posttreatment fluorine F 18-fludeoxyglucose (18F-FDG) positron emission tomography&#8211;computed tomography (PET-CT) scans are controversial; it remains unclear if PET scans can reliably identify patients who can take or omit radiation therapy consolidation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.40">

315140</a>

3152,<a href="#cit/section_5.46">

315346</a>

3154-<a href="#cit/section_5.48">

315548</a>

3156] </p>

3157<p id="_1386" tabindex="-1">

3158A retrospective review of 109 patients with PMBCL showed that 63% had a negative end-of-treatment PET-CT (EOT-PET-CT) (Deauville score 1&#8211;3).[<a href="#cit/section_5.49">

315949</a>

3160] No radiation therapy was offered and the 5-year time-to-progression rate (similar to disease-free survival, but restricted to lymphoma relapse) was 90%, and the 5-year OS rate was 97%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.49">

316149</a>

3162][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3163Level of evidence C3</a>

3164] Patients with a positive EOT-PET-CT received radiation therapy consolidation. It is unclear from this study whether those patients might have done just as well without radiation therapy.
