Clinicians may follow improvement over time for Deauville 4 scores on EOT-PET-CT scans as an alternative to radiation therapy, but this has not been studied in a clinical trial.</p>

3165<p id="_1387" tabindex="-1">

3166In situations where mediastinal radiation therapy would encompass the left side of the heart or would increase breast cancer risk in young female patients, proton therapy may be considered to reduce radiation dose to organs at risk.[<a href="#cit/section_5.50">

316750</a>

3168] For more information, see the <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/cardiopulmonary-hp-pdq#_97">

3169Superior Vena Cava Syndrome</a>

3170 section in Cardiopulmonary Syndromes.</p>

3171<p id="_1182" tabindex="-1">

3172Because PMBCL is characterized by high expression of programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) and variable expression of CD30, a phase II study evaluated nivolumab plus brentuximab vedotin in 30 patients with relapsed disease. With a median follow-up of 11.1 months, the objective response rate was 73% (95% CI, 54%&#8722;88%).[<a href="#cit/section_5.51">

317351</a>

3174][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3175Level of evidence C3</a>

3176] Similarly, phase I and II trials of pembrolizumab in 74 patients with relapsed or refractory disease showed an objective response rate of 45% to 48%. The median duration of response was not reached for the 21 patients with a median follow-up of 29 months or for the 53 patients with a median follow-up of 12.5 months.[<a href="#cit/section_5.52">

317752</a>

3178][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3179Level of evidence C3</a>

3180]</p>

3181<p id="_1474" tabindex="-1">

3182Among those who had received two prior lines of therapy, more than one-half of patients who received CAR T-cell therapy with lisocabtagene maraleucel had disease response.[<a href="#cit/section_5.53">

318353</a>

3184][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3185Level of evidence C3</a>

3186]</p>

3187</section>

3188<section id="_96">

3189<h3 id="_96_toc">

3190Follicular Large Cell Lymphoma</h3>

3191<section id="_527">

3192<h4 id="_527_toc">

3193Prognosis</h4>

3194<p id="_98" tabindex="-1">

3195The natural history of follicular large cell lymphoma remains controversial.[<a href="#cit/section_5.54">

319654</a>

3197] While there is agreement about the significant number of long-term disease-free survivors with early-stage disease, the curability of patients with advanced disease (stage III or stage IV) remains uncertain. Some groups report a continuous relapse rate similar to the other follicular lymphomas (a pattern of indolent lymphoma).[<a href="#cit/section_5.55">

319855</a>

3199] Other investigators report a plateau in freedom from progression at levels expected for an aggressive lymphoma (40% at 10 years).[<a href="#cit/section_5.56">

320056</a>

3201,<a href="#cit/section_5.57">

320257</a>

3203] This discrepancy may be caused by variations in histological classification between institutions and the rarity of patients with follicular large cell lymphoma. A retrospective review of 252 patients, all treated with anthracycline-containing combination chemotherapy, showed that patients with more than 50% diffuse components on biopsy had a worse OS than other patients with follicular large cell lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.58">

320458</a>

3205]</p>

3206</section>

3207<section id="_528">

3208<h4 id="_528_toc">

3209Therapeutic approaches</h4>

3210<p id="_99" tabindex="-1">

3211 Treatment of follicular large cell lymphoma is more similar to treatment of aggressive NHL than it is to the treatment of indolent NHL. In support of this approach, treatment with high-dose chemotherapy and autologous hematopoietic peripheral SCT shows the same curative potential in patients with follicular large cell lymphoma who relapse as it does in patients with diffuse large cell lymphoma who relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_5.59">

321259</a>

3213][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3214Level of evidence C1</a>

3215]</p>

3216<p id="_1475" tabindex="-1">

3217Among those who had received two prior lines of therapy, more than one-half of patients who received CAR T-cell therapy with lisocabtagene maraleucel had disease response.[<a href="#cit/section_5.53">

321853</a>

3219][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3220Level of evidence C3</a>

3221]</p>

3222</section>

3223</section>

3224<section id="_100">

3225<h3 id="_100_toc">

3226Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma</h3>

3227<p id="_101" tabindex="-1">

3228Anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL) is a T-cell lymphoma associated with the CD30 antigen. The translocation of chromosomes 2 and 5 creates a unique fusion protein with a nucleophosmin-ALK.[<a href="#cit/section_5.60">

322960</a>

3230,<a href="#cit/section_5.61">

323161</a>

3232] Patients whose lymphomas express ALK by immunohistochemistry are usually younger and may have systemic symptoms, extranodal disease, and advanced-stage disease. However, they have a more favorable survival rate than ALK-negative patients.[<a href="#cit/section_5.62">

323362</a>

3234,<a href="#cit/section_5.63">

323563</a>

3236]</p>

3237<p id="_103" tabindex="-1">

3238 A prospective randomized trial included 452 patients with CD30-positive T-cell lymphoma, 70% of whom had ALCL (22% ALK-positive and 48% ALK-negative patients). The trial compared the previously used standard regimen, CHOP, with brentuximab vedotin (an anti-CD30 monoclonal antibody conjugated to a cytotoxic agent) combined with cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, and prednisone.[<a href="#cit/section_5.64">

323964</a>

3240] With a median follow-up of 35 months, the 3-year OS rate was 77% in the brentuximab vedotin arm and 68% in the CHOP arm (hazard ratio [HR], 0.66; 95% CI, 0.46&#8211;0.95; <em>

3241P</em>

3242 = .02).[<a href="#cit/section_5.64">

324364</a>

3244][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3245Level of evidence A1</a>

3246] This established brentuximab vedotin plus cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, and prednisone as a new option for patients with ALCL and other CD30-positive T-cell lymphomas, such as angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma and peripheral T-cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified. For patients with relapsed disease, anecdotal responses have been reported for brentuximab vedotin,[<a href="#cit/section_5.65">

324765</a>

3248-<a href="#cit/section_5.68">

324968</a>

3250] romidepsin,[<a href="#cit/section_5.69">

325169</a>

3252] and pralatrexate.[<a href="#cit/section_5.70">

325370</a>

3254][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3255Level of evidence C3</a>

3256] </p>

3257<p id="_1476" tabindex="-1">

3258In a phase II study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00866047">

3259NCT00866047</a>

3260), 66% of 58 patients attained a complete response with brentuximab vedotin. At a median follow-up of 58 months, the 5-year PFS rate was 57% (95% CI, 41%&#8211;74%), and the 5-year OS rate was 79% (95% CI, 65%&#8211;92%). Of the patients achieving a complete response, 42% underwent hematopoietic SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_5.68">

326168</a>

3262][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3263Level of evidence C3</a>

3264] In a retrospective review, 39 patients with relapsed disease had a 3-year PFS rate of 50% after autologous or allogeneic SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_5.71">

326571</a>

3266][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3267Level of evidence C2</a>

3268] A retrospective review of 84 patients with ALK-negative ALCL suggested a survival benefit with autologous SCT. This hypothesis requires confirmation in a randomized prospective trial.[<a href="#cit/section_5.72">

326972</a>

3270]</p>

3271<p id="_418" tabindex="-1">

3272ALCL in children is usually characterized by systemic and cutaneous disease and has high response rates and good OS with doxorubicin-based combination chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.73">

327373</a>

3274] Patients with breast implant&#8211;associated ALCL may do well without chemotherapy after capsulectomy and implant removal if the disease is confined to the fibrous capsule, and no associated mass or lymphadenopathy is present.[<a href="#cit/section_5.74">

327574</a>

3276-<a href="#cit/section_5.77">

327777</a>

3278] Most patients with breast implant&#8211;associated ALCL have a characteristic deletion at 20Q13.13 that may help diagnostically to distinguish it from cutaneous or systemic ALCL.[<a href="#cit/section_5.78">

327978</a>

3280]</p>

3281<p id="_1477" tabindex="-1">

3282Primary cutaneous ALCL is a distinct entity that is typically ALK-negative and has a very indolent/low-grade clinical course.</p>

3283</section>

3284<section id="_104">

3285<h3 id="_104_toc">

3286Extranodal Natural Killer (NK)-/T-cell Lymphoma</h3>

3287<p id="_105" tabindex="-1">

3288Extranodal natural killer (NK)-/T-cell lymphoma (nasal type) is an aggressive lymphoma marked by extensive necrosis and angioinvasion, most often presenting in extranodal sites, in particular the nasal or paranasal sinus region.[<a href="#cit/section_5.79">

328979</a>

3290] Other extranodal sites include the palate, trachea, skin, and gastrointestinal tract. Hemophagocytic syndrome may occur; historically, these tumors were considered part of lethal midline granuloma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.80">

329180</a>

3292] In most cases, Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) genomes are detectable in the tumor cells and immunophenotyping shows CD56 positivity. Cases with blood and marrow involvement are considered NK-cell leukemia. </p>

3293<p id="_106" tabindex="-1">

3294 The increased risk of CNS involvement and of local recurrence has led to recommendations for radiation therapy locally, concurrently, before the start of chemotherapy or between cycle two and three of chemotherapy, and for intrathecal prophylaxis and/or prophylactic cranial radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.81">

329581</a>

3296-<a href="#cit/section_5.88">

329788</a>

3298] </p>

3299<p id="_1223" tabindex="-1">

3300A retrospective review of 1,273 early-stage patients stratified them into a low-risk group and high-risk group using stage, age, LDH, performance status, and primary tumor invasion. Low-risk patients fared best with radiation therapy alone,[<a href="#cit/section_5.89">

330189</a>

3302] while high-risk patients fared best with a strategy of radiation therapy combined with chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.87">

330387</a>

3304,<a href="#cit/section_5.90">

330590</a>

3306,<a href="#cit/section_5.91">

330791</a>

3308] </p>

3309<p id="_1224" tabindex="-1">

3310In a retrospective review of 303 previously untreated patients from an international consortium who received nonanthracycline chemotherapy, the OS rates were identical for early-stage patients (72%&#8722;74% at 5 years) who received either concurrent chemotherapy and radiation therapy or chemotherapy followed by radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.92">

331192</a>

3312][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3313Level of evidence C3</a>

3314]</p>

3315<p id="_1225" tabindex="-1">

3316Higher doses of radiation therapy administered at more than 50 Gy are associated with improved outcomes according to anecdotal reports.[<a href="#cit/section_5.87">

331787</a>

3318] The highly aggressive course, with poor response and short survival with standard therapies, especially for patients with advanced-stage disease or extranasal presentation, has led some investigators to recommend autologous or allogeneic peripheral SCT consolidation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.88">

331988</a>

3320,<a href="#cit/section_5.93">

332193</a>

3322-<a href="#cit/section_5.97">

332397</a>

3324] Asparaginase-containing regimens have shown anecdotal response rates greater than 50% for relapsing, refractory, or newly diagnosed patients.[<a href="#cit/section_5.88">

332588</a>

3326,<a href="#cit/section_5.98">

332798</a>

3328-<a href="#cit/section_5.101">

3329101</a>

3330][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3331Level of evidence C3</a>

3332] Because of the lack of randomized clinical trials with more than 100 patients for this rare type of T-cell lymphoma, regimens containing pegaspargase have become the standard for systemic therapy. Pegaspargase is a less toxic formulation of asparaginase with less hypersensitivity reactions and a longer half-life.[<a href="#cit/section_5.102">

3333102</a>

3334,<a href="#cit/section_5.103">

3335103</a>

3336] NK-/T-cell lymphoma that presents only in the skin has a more favorable prognosis, especially in patients with coexpression of CD30 with CD56.[<a href="#cit/section_5.104">

3337104</a>

3338] A benign NK-cell enteropathy (EBV negative) on endoscopic biopsy can be distinguished from NK-/T-cell lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.105">

3339105</a>

3340] In a phase II trial, the anti-PD-L1 antibody avelumab was given to 21 patients with relapsed or refractory disease. The CR rate was 24%, the overall response rate was 38%, and responses correlated with tumor PD-L1 expression.[<a href="#cit/section_5.106">

3341106</a>

3342][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3343Level of evidence C3</a>

3344] Treatment with pembrolizumab, an anti-programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) antibody, resulted in similar responses in patients with relapsed or refractory disease.[<a href="#cit/section_5.107">

3345107</a>

3346][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3347Level of evidence C3</a>

3348]</p>

3349</section>

3350<section id="_107">

3351<h3 id="_107_toc">

3352Lymphomatoid Granulomatosis</h3>

3353<p id="_108" tabindex="-1">

3354Lymphomatoid granulomatosis is an EBV-positive large B-cell lymphoma with a predominant T-cell background.[<a href="#cit/section_5.108">

3355108</a>

3356,<a href="#cit/section_5.109">

3357109</a>

3358] The histology shows association with angioinvasion and vasculitis, usually manifesting as pulmonary lesions or paranasal sinus involvement.</p>

3359<p id="_109" tabindex="-1">

3360 Patients are managed like others with diffuse large cell lymphoma and require doxorubicin-based combination chemotherapy.</p>

3361</section>

3362<section id="_110">

3363<h3 id="_110_toc">

3364Angioimmunoblastic T-cell Lymphoma</h3>

3365<p id="_111" tabindex="-1">

3366Angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma (AITL or ATCL) was formerly called angioimmunoblastic lymphadenopathy with dysproteinemia. Characterized by clonal T-cell receptor gene rearrangement, this entity is managed like diffuse large cell lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.110">

3367110</a>

3368-<a href="#cit/section_5.113">

3369113</a>

3370] Patients present with profound lymphadenopathy, fever, night sweats, weight loss, skin rash, a positive Coombs test, and polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia.[<a href="#cit/section_5.80">

337180</a>

3372] Opportunistic infections are frequent because of an underlying immune deficiency. B-cell EBV genomes are detected in most affected patients.[<a href="#cit/section_5.114">

3373114</a>

3374] For more information about weight loss, see <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/appetite-loss/nutrition-hp-pdq">

3375Nutrition in Cancer Care</a>

3376 and for more information about skin rash, see <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/skin-nail-changes/pruritus-hp-pdq">

3377Pruritus</a>

3378.</p>

3379<p id="_112" tabindex="-1">

3380 Doxorubicin-based combination chemotherapy, such as the CHOP regimen, is recommended as it is for other aggressive lymphomas.[<a href="#cit/section_5.110">

3381110</a>

3382,<a href="#cit/section_5.113">

3383113</a>

3384] For CD30-positive cases, brentuximab combined with cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, and prednisone is the standard of care.[<a href="#cit/section_5.64">

338564</a>

3386][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3387Level of evidence B1</a>

3388] For more information, see the <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_100">

3389Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma</a>

3390 section. The International Peripheral T-Cell Lymphoma Project involving 22 international centers identified 243 patients with AITL or ATCL; the 5-year OS and failure-free survival rates were 33% and 18%, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_5.115">

3391115</a>

3392] Myeloablative chemotherapy and radiation therapy with autologous or allogeneic peripheral stem cell support has been described in anecdotal reports.[<a href="#cit/section_5.72">

339372</a>

3394,<a href="#cit/section_5.96">

339596</a>

3396,<a href="#cit/section_5.116">

3397116</a>

3398-<a href="#cit/section_5.118">

3399118</a>

3400] Anecdotal responses have been reported for cyclosporine,[<a href="#cit/section_5.119">

3401119</a>

3402] pralatrexate,[<a href="#cit/section_5.120">

3403120</a>

3404] bendamustine,[<a href="#cit/section_5.121">

3405121</a>

3406] the histone deacetylase inhibitor romidepsin, and brentuximab vedotin (even if there is little or no CD30 expression on the lymphoma).[<a href="#cit/section_5.69">

340769</a>

3408,<a href="#cit/section_5.122">

3409122</a>

3410][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3411Level of evidence C3</a>

3412] Occasional spontaneous remissions and protracted responses to steroids only have been reported.</p>

3413</section>

3414<section id="_113">

3415<h3 id="_113_toc">

3416Peripheral T-cell Lymphoma</h3>

3417<p id="_114" tabindex="-1">

3418Patients with peripheral T-cell lymphoma have diffuse large cell or diffuse mixed lymphoma that expresses a cell surface phenotype of a postthymic (or peripheral) T-cell expressing CD4 or CD8 but not both together.[<a href="#cit/section_5.123">

3419123</a>

3420] Peripheral T-cell lymphoma encompasses a group of heterogeneous nodal T-cell lymphomas that will require future delineation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.80">

342180</a>

3422,<a href="#cit/section_5.124">

3423124</a>

3424] This includes the so-called Lennert lymphoma, a T-cell lymphoma admixed with a preponderance of lymphoepithelioid cells. </p>

3425<section id="_529">

3426<h4 id="_529_toc">

3427Prognosis</h4>

3428<p id="_115" tabindex="-1">

3429 Most investigators report worse response and survival rates for patients with peripheral T-cell lymphomas than for patients with comparably staged B-cell aggressive lymphomas.[<a href="#cit/section_5.124">

3430124</a>

3431,<a href="#cit/section_5.125">

3432125</a>

3433] Most patients present with multiple adverse prognostic factors (i.e., older age, stage IV, multiple extranodal sites, and elevated LDH), and these patients have a low (&lt;20%) failure-free survival and OS at 5 years.[<a href="#cit/section_5.124">

3434124</a>

3435,<a href="#cit/section_5.125">

3436125</a>

3437] As with other lymphomas (e.g., DLBCL or follicular lymphoma), event-free survival at 24 months predicts a 5-year OS of 78%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.126">

3438126</a>

3439]</p>

3440</section>

3441<section id="_530">

3442<h4 id="_530_toc">

3443Therapeutic approaches</h4>

3444<p id="_421" tabindex="-1">

3445 Therapy involves doxorubicin-based combination chemotherapy (such as CHOP or CHOPE [CHOP plus etoposide]), which is also used for DLBCL.[<a href="#cit/section_5.127">

3446127</a>

3447] For CD30-positive cases, brentuximab combined with cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, and prednisone is the standard of care.[<a href="#cit/section_5.64">

344864</a>

3449][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3450Level of evidence B1</a>

3451] For more information, see the <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_100">

3452Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma</a>

3453 section. For patients with early-stage disease, anecdotal retrospective series disagree on the value of consolidative radiation therapy after combination chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.128">

3454128</a>

3455][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3456Level of evidence C3</a>

3457] Consolidation therapy using high-dose chemotherapy with autologous or allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell support has been given to patients with advanced-stage peripheral T-cell lymphoma after induction therapy in multiple phase II or retrospective trials. Evidence for this approach is anecdotal.[<a href="#cit/section_5.72">

345872</a>

3459,<a href="#cit/section_5.96">

346096</a>

3461,<a href="#cit/section_5.116">

3462116</a>

3463,<a href="#cit/section_5.118">

3464118</a>

3465,<a href="#cit/section_5.129">

3466129</a>

3467-<a href="#cit/section_5.131">

3468131</a>

3469][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3470Level of evidence C3</a>

3471] </p>

3472<p id="_1388" tabindex="-1">

3473A randomized prospective trial included 104 patients younger than 61 years with stage II, III, or IV peripheral T-cell lymphoma (excluding ALK-positive ALCL). Patients received either autologous SCT or allogeneic SCT as consolidation therapy after induction with CHOEP (cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, etoposide, and prednisone) followed by DHAP (dexamethasone, cytarabine, and cisplatin).[<a href="#cit/section_5.132">

3474132</a>

3475][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3476Level of evidence C3</a>

3477] With a median follow-up of 42 months, the 3-year EFS rate was 43% for patients who received allogeneic SCT and 38% for patients who received autologous SCT. The 3-year OS rate was 57% for patients who received allogeneic SCT and 70% for patients who received autologous SCT (<em>

3478P</em>

3479 = nonsignificant). None of the 21 responding patients who proceeded to allogeneic SCT relapsed, and 36% of patients who proceeded to autologous SCT relapsed. Eight of 26 patients (31%) who received allogeneic SCT died of graft-versus-host disease, and none of the 41 patients who received autologous SCT died of toxicity. The benefit of graft-versus-lymphoma effect was negated by increased transplant-related mortality.</p>

3480<p id="_1389" tabindex="-1">

3481In a prospective trial of 109 evaluable patients with relapsing disease, treatment with pralatrexate resulted in a 30% response rate and a median 10-month duration of response.[<a href="#cit/section_5.69">

348269</a>

3483,<a href="#cit/section_5.133">

3484133</a>

3485][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3486Level of evidence C3</a>

3487] Similar response rates were seen in 130 evaluable patients with relapsing disease who received romidepsin in a prospective trial.[<a href="#cit/section_5.69">

348869</a>

3489][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3490Level of evidence C3</a>

3491] Anecdotal responses have been seen with a combination of pralatrexate and romidepsin,[<a href="#cit/section_5.120">

3492120</a>

3493] single-agent bendamustine,[<a href="#cit/section_5.121">

3494121</a>

3495] belinostat,[<a href="#cit/section_5.134">

3496134</a>

3497] and brentuximab vedotin (even if there is little or no CD30 expression on the lymphoma).[<a href="#cit/section_5.122">

3498122</a>

3499][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3500Level of evidence C3</a>

3501] Incorporation of these new agents with CHOP chemotherapy is under clinical evaluation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.64">

350264</a>

3503,<a href="#cit/section_5.124">

3504124</a>

3505] </p>

3506<p id="_117" tabindex="-1">

3507An unusual type of peripheral T-cell lymphoma occurring mostly in young men, hepatosplenic T-cell lymphoma, appears to be localized to the hepatic and splenic sinusoids, with cell surface expression of the T-cell receptor gamma/delta.[<a href="#cit/section_5.135">

3508135</a>

3509-<a href="#cit/section_5.137">

3510137</a>

3511] Another variant, subcutaneous panniculitis-like T-cell lymphoma, is localized to subcutaneous tissue associated with hemophagocytic syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_5.138">

3512138</a>

3513-<a href="#cit/section_5.141">

3514141</a>

3515] These patients have cells that express alpha-beta phenotype. Those with gamma-delta phenotype have a more aggressive clinical course and are classified as cutaneous gamma-delta T-cell lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.142">

3516142</a>

3517-<a href="#cit/section_5.144">

3518144</a>

3519] These patients may manifest involvement of the epidermis, dermis, subcutaneous region, or mucosa. These entities have extremely poor prognoses with an extremely aggressive clinical course and are treated within the same paradigm as the highest-risk groups with DLBCL.[<a href="#cit/section_5.96">

352096</a>

3521,<a href="#cit/section_5.137">

3522137</a>

3523] An indolent T-cell lymphoproliferative disease of the gastrointestinal tract must be distinguished from peripheral T-cell lymphoma because no therapy may be indicated.[<a href="#cit/section_5.145">

3524145</a>

3525]</p>

3526</section>

3527</section>

3528<section id="_118">

3529<h3 id="_118_toc">

3530Enteropathy-type Intestinal T-cell Lymphoma</h3>

3531<p id="_119" tabindex="-1">

3532Enteropathy-type intestinal T-cell lymphoma involves the small bowel of patients with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac sprue).[<a href="#cit/section_5.80">

353380</a>

3534,<a href="#cit/section_5.146">

3535146</a>

3536-<a href="#cit/section_5.148">

3537148</a>

3538] Because a gluten-free diet prevents the development of lymphoma, patients diagnosed with celiac sprue in childhood rarely develop lymphoma. The diagnosis of celiac disease is usually made by finding villous atrophy in the resected intestine. Surgery is often required for diagnosis and to avoid perforation during therapy.</p>

3539<p id="_120" tabindex="-1">

3540 Therapy is with doxorubicin-based combination chemotherapy, but relapse rates appear higher than for comparably staged diffuse large cell lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.147">

3541147</a>

3542-<a href="#cit/section_5.149">

3543149</a>

3544] Complications of treatment include gastrointestinal bleeding, small bowel perforation, and enterocolic fistulae; patients often require parenteral nutrition. For more information on parenteral nutrition, see <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/appetite-loss/nutrition-hp-pdq">

3545Nutrition in Cancer Care</a>

3546. Multifocal intestinal perforations and visceral abdominal involvement are seen at the time of relapse. High-dose therapy with hematopoietic stem cell rescue has been applied in first remission or at relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_5.96">

354796</a>

3548,<a href="#cit/section_5.147">

3549147</a>

3550,<a href="#cit/section_5.150">

3551150</a>

3552][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3553Level of evidence C2</a>

3554] Evidence for this approach is anecdotal.</p>

3555</section>

3556<section id="_121">

3557<h3 id="_121_toc">

3558Intravascular Large B-cell Lymphoma (Intravascular Lymphomatosis)</h3>

3559<p id="_122" tabindex="-1">

3560Intravascular lymphomatosis is characterized by large cell lymphoma confined to the intravascular lumen. The brain, kidneys, lungs, and skin are the organs most likely affected by intravascular lymphomatosis.</p>

3561<p id="_123" tabindex="-1">

3562 With the use of aggressive R-CHOP&#8211;based combination chemotherapy, as is used in DLBCL, the prognosis is similar to that of conventional stage IV DLBCL.[<a href="#cit/section_5.151">

3563151</a>

3564-<a href="#cit/section_5.153">

3565153</a>

3566]</p>

3567</section>

3568<section id="_124">

3569<h3 id="_124_toc">

3570Burkitt Lymphoma/Diffuse Small Noncleaved-cell Lymphoma</h3>

3571<p id="_125" tabindex="-1">

3572Burkitt lymphoma/diffuse small noncleaved-cell lymphoma typically involves younger patients and represents the most common type of pediatric NHL.[<a href="#cit/section_5.154">

3573154</a>

3574] These types of aggressive extranodal B-cell lymphomas are characterized by translocation and deregulation of the <em class="gene-name">

3575MYC</em>

3576 gene on chromosome 8.[<a href="#cit/section_5.155">

3577155</a>

3578] A subgroup of patients with dual translocation of <em class="gene-name">

3579MYC</em>

3580 and <em class="gene-name">

3581BCL2</em>

3582 appear to have an extremely poor outcome despite aggressive therapy (median OS, 5 months).[<a href="#cit/section_5.156">

3583156</a>

3584][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3585Level of evidence C1</a>

3586]</p>

3587<p id="_126" tabindex="-1">

3588 In some patients with larger B cells, there is morphological overlap with DLBCL. These Burkitt-like large cell lymphomas show <em class="gene-name">

3589MYC</em>

3590 deregulation, extremely high proliferation rates, and a gene-expression profile as expected for classic Burkitt lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.157">

3591157</a>

3592-<a href="#cit/section_5.159">

3593159</a>

3594] Endemic cases, usually from Africa, involve the facial bones or jaws of children, mostly containing EBV genomes. Sporadic cases usually involve the gastrointestinal system, ovaries, or kidneys. Patients present with rapidly growing masses and a very high LDH but are potentially curable with intensive doxorubicin-based combination chemotherapy.</p>

3595<section id="_531">

3596<h4 id="_531_toc">

3597Therapeutic approaches</h4>

3598<p id="_127" tabindex="-1">

3599 Treatment of Burkitt lymphoma/diffuse small noncleaved-cell lymphoma involves aggressive multidrug regimens in combination with rituximab, similar to those used for the advanced-stage aggressive lymphomas (diffuse large cell).[<a href="#cit/section_5.160">

3600160</a>

3601-<a href="#cit/section_5.163">

3602163</a>

3603] Aggressive combination chemotherapy, which is patterned after that used in childhood Burkitt lymphoma, has been very successful for adult patients with more than 60% of advanced-stage patients free of disease at 5 years.[<a href="#cit/section_5.164">

3604164</a>

3605-<a href="#cit/section_5.167">

3606167</a>

3607] Adverse prognostic factors include bulky abdominal disease and high serum LDH. Patients with Burkitt lymphoma have a 20% to 30% lifetime risk of CNS involvement. Prophylaxis with intrathecal chemotherapy is required as part of induction therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.168">

3608168</a>

3609] Patients with HIV-associated Burkitt lymphoma also benefit from less-toxic modification of the aggressive multidrug regimens in combination with rituximab.[<a href="#cit/section_5.169">

3610169</a>

3611][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3612Level of evidence C3</a>

3613] For more information, see <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/primary-cns-lymphoma-treatment-pdq">

3614Primary CNS Lymphoma Treatment</a>

3615 and <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/aids-related-treatment-pdq">

3616AIDS-Related Lymphoma Treatment</a>

3617.</p>

3618</section>

3619</section>

3620<section id="_128">

3621<h3 id="_128_toc">

3622Lymphoblastic Lymphoma</h3>

3623<p id="_129" tabindex="-1">

3624Lymphoblastic lymphoma (precursor T-cell) is a very aggressive form of NHL. It often, but not exclusively, occurs in young patients.[<a href="#cit/section_5.170">

3625170</a>

3626] It is commonly associated with large mediastinal masses and has a high predilection for disseminating to bone marrow and the CNS.</p>

3627<p id="_130" tabindex="-1">

3628 Treatment is usually patterned after that for acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Intensive combination chemotherapy with or without bone marrow transplantation is the standard treatment for this aggressive histological type of NHL.[<a href="#cit/section_5.171">

3629171</a>

3630-<a href="#cit/section_5.173">

3631173</a>

3632] Radiation therapy is sometimes given to areas of bulky tumor masses. Because these forms of NHL tend to progress quickly, combination chemotherapy is instituted rapidly once the diagnosis has been confirmed. Careful review of the pathological specimens, bone marrow aspirate, biopsy specimen, cerebrospinal fluid cytology, and lymphocyte marker constitute the most important aspects of the pretreatment staging workup. For more information, see <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/adult-all-treatment-pdq">

3633Adult Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment</a>

3634.</p>

3635</section>

3636<section id="_131">

3637<h3 id="_131_toc">

3638Adult T-cell Leukemia/Lymphoma</h3>

3639<p id="_132" tabindex="-1">

3640Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATL) is caused by infection with the retrovirus human T-lymphotrophic virus 1 and is frequently associated with lymphadenopathy, hypercalcemia, circulating leukemic cells, bone and skin involvement, hepatosplenomegaly, a rapidly progressive course, and poor response to combination chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.174">

3641174</a>

3642,<a href="#cit/section_5.175">

3643175</a>

3644] ATL has been divided into four clinical subtypes:[<a href="#cit/section_5.176">

3645176</a>

3646,<a href="#cit/section_5.177">

3647177</a>

3648]</p>

3649<div class="pdq-content-list">

3650<ul id="_843">

3651<li>

3652Acute (aggressive course with leukemia, with or without extranodal or nodal involvement). </li>

3653<li>

3654Lymphoma (aggressive course with lymphadenopathy and no leukemia). </li>

3655<li>

3656Chronic (indolent course with leukemia and lymphadenopathy). </li>

3657<li>

3658Smoldering (indolent course with only leukemia). </li>

3659</ul>

3660</div>

3661<p id="_133" tabindex="-1">

3662 The acute and lymphoma types of ATL have done poorly with strategies of combination chemotherapy and allogeneic SCT with a median OS under 1 year.[<a href="#cit/section_5.178">

3663178</a>

3664-<a href="#cit/section_5.180">

3665180</a>

3666] Using combination chemotherapy, less than 10% of 807 patients were alive after 4 years.[<a href="#cit/section_5.180">

3667180</a>

3668] Anecdotal durable remissions have been reported after allogeneic SCT and even after subsequent donor lymphocyte infusion for relapses after transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_5.181">

3669181</a>

3670][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3671Level of evidence C3</a>

3672] Among 815 patients who underwent allogeneic SCT in two retrospective reviews, the 3-year OS rates were 36% and 26%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.182">

3673182</a>

3674,<a href="#cit/section_5.183">

3675183</a>

3676][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3677Level of evidence C1</a>

3678]</p>

3679<p id="_134" tabindex="-1">

3680 The combination of zidovudine and interferon-alpha has activity against ATL, even for patients who failed previous cytotoxic therapy. Durable remissions are seen in most patients who present with this combination, but are not seen in patients with the lymphoma subtype of ATL.[<a href="#cit/section_5.184">

3681184</a>

3682-<a href="#cit/section_5.188">

3683188</a>

3684] In a multicenter phase II study of 26 relapsed patients, 42% responded to lenalidomide (including four CR).[<a href="#cit/section_5.189">

3685189</a>

3686][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3687Level of evidence C3</a>

3688] Symptomatic local progression of all subtypes responds well to palliative radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.190">

3689190</a>

3690] In the relapsed setting, an overall response rate above 50% was seen using mogamulizumab, a humanized monoclonal antibody against the C-C chemokine receptor 4 (CCR4).[<a href="#cit/section_5.191">

3691191</a>

3692][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3693Level of evidence C3</a>

3694] For CD30-positive cases, brentuximab combined with cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, and prednisone is the standard of care.[<a href="#cit/section_5.64">

369564</a>

3696][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3697Level of evidence B1</a>

3698] For more information, see the <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_100">

3699Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma</a>

3700 section.</p>

3701</section>

3702<section id="_135">

3703<h3 id="_135_toc">

3704Mantle Cell Lymphoma</h3>

3705<p id="_136" tabindex="-1">

3706Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) is found in lymph nodes, the spleen, bone marrow, blood, and sometimes the gastrointestinal system (lymphomatous polyposis).[<a href="#cit/section_5.192">

3707192</a>

3708] MCL is characterized by CD5-positive follicular mantle B cells, a translocation of chromosomes 11 and 14, and an overexpression of the cyclin D1 protein.[<a href="#cit/section_5.192">

3709192</a>

3710] MCL may be divided into two clinical subtypes: a classical version with lymphadenopathy with high SOX-11 expression that manifests with an aggressive clinical course and a worse prognosis versus a leukemic, non-nodal version with low SOX-11 expression and a more indolent course and a better prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_5.193">

3711193</a>

3712] A complex karyotype predicts poor response to induction therapy and inferior survival.[<a href="#cit/section_5.194">

3713194</a>

3714] There is frequent overlap on presentation with these subtypes, and the therapeutic implication remains unclear. However, both of these versions can converge later in their course into a blastoid phenotype or treatment-resistant phenotype due to genomic instability and selection.[<a href="#cit/section_5.195">

3715195</a>

3716,<a href="#cit/section_5.196">

3717196</a>

3718]</p>

3719<p id="_137" tabindex="-1">

3720 Like the low-grade lymphomas, MCL appears incurable with anthracycline-based chemotherapy and occurs in older patients with generally asymptomatic advanced-stage disease. The median survival, however, is significantly shorter (5&#8211;7 years) than that of other lymphomas, and this histology is now considered to be an aggressive lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.197">

3721197</a>

3722] A diffuse pattern and the blastoid variant have an aggressive course with shorter survival, while the mantle zone type may have a more indolent course.[<a href="#cit/section_5.196">

3723196</a>

3724,<a href="#cit/section_5.198">

3725198</a>

3726] A high cell-proliferation rate (increased Ki-67, mitotic index, beta-2-microglobulin) may be associated with a poorer prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_5.199">

3727199</a>

3728,<a href="#cit/section_5.200">

3729200</a>

3730]</p>

3731<section id="_532">

3732<h4 id="_532_toc">

3733Therapeutic approaches</h4>

3734<p id="_793" tabindex="-1">

3735Asymptomatic patients with low-risk scores on the IPI may do well when initial therapy is deferred.[<a href="#cit/section_5.201">

3736201</a>

3737,<a href="#cit/section_5.202">

3738202</a>

3739][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3740Level of evidence C3</a>

3741] There is no standard approach to MCL. Several induction chemotherapy regimens may be employed for symptomatic progressing disease. These regimens range in intensity from rituximab alone to rituximab plus ibrutinib, rituximab plus bendamustine, R-CHOP, or high-dose intensive regimens such as R-hyper C-VAD (hyperfractionated cyclophosphamide, vincristine, doxorubicin, and dexamethasone alternating with methotrexate and cytarabine). Some physicians use autologous SCT or allogeneic SCT consolidation next, while others prefer rituximab maintenance, reserving high-dose consolidation for a later time.[<a href="#cit/section_5.203">

3742203</a>

3743] Ibrutinib, lenalidomide, and bortezomib have shown activity in relapsing patients, and these drugs are being incorporated up front.[<a href="#cit/section_5.204">

3744204</a>

3745-<a href="#cit/section_5.209">

3746209</a>

3747]</p>

3748<p id="_1390" tabindex="-1">

3749<strong>

3750 It is unclear which therapeutic approach offers the best long-term survival in this clinicopathological entity. </strong>

3751</p>

3752<p id="_1391" tabindex="-1">

3753In a phase II trial of previously untreated patients with MCL older than 64 years, 50 patients received the B-cell receptor-inhibitor ibrutinib plus rituximab. With a median follow-up of 45 months, the overall response rate was 96%, the CR rate was 76%, the 3-year PFS rate was 87%, and the 3-year OS rate was 94%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.209">

3754209</a>

3755][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3756Level of evidence C3</a>

3757] In a phase II trial of 131 previously untreated patients with MCL aged 65 years or younger, 1 year of ibrutinib plus 4 weeks of rituximab resulted in a CR rate of 89% prior to any chemotherapy consolidation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.210">

3758210</a>

3759][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3760Level of evidence C3</a>

3761] Another phase II trial using ibrutinib plus rituximab included asymptomatic patients with previously untreated MCL; the CR rate was 87%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.211">

3762211</a>

3763][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3764Level of evidence C3</a>

3765] Previously treated patients who received ibrutinib had a response rate of 86% (21% CR rate) and a median PFS of 14 months.[<a href="#cit/section_5.206">

3766206</a>

3767][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3768Level of evidence C3</a>

3769] In a prospective randomized trial, 280 patients with relapsed or refractory MCL received either ibrutinib or temsirolimus.[<a href="#cit/section_5.212">

3770212</a>

3771] With a median follow-up of 15 months, the median PFS favored ibrutinib (14.6 months vs. 6.2 months; HR, 0.43; 95% CI, 0.32&#8211;0.58, <em>

3772P</em>

3773 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_5.212">

3774212</a>

3775][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3776Level of evidence B1</a>

3777] Ibrutinib was combined with another active agent, venetoclax, in a phase II study of 23 patients with relapsed or refractory MCL.[<a href="#cit/section_5.213">

3778213</a>

3779] An unprecedented 71% of patients had a CR and 78% of responding patients maintained response at 15 months.[<a href="#cit/section_5.213">

3780213</a>

3781][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3782Level of evidence C3</a>

3783] </p>

3784<p id="_1467" tabindex="-1">

3785A prospective randomized trial included 523 patients aged 65 years and older with MCL. Patients were randomly assigned to receive either ibrutinib, bendamustine, and rituximab or bendamustine and rituximab alone.[<a href="#cit/section_5.214">

3786214</a>

3787] With a median follow-up of 84.7 months, the median PFS was 80.6 months for patients who received ibrutinib, and 52.9 months for patients who received bendamustine and rituximab alone (HR, 0.75; 95% CI, 0.59&#8211;0.96; <em>

3788P</em>

3789 = .01). There was no difference in the 7-year OS rate (55.0% vs. 56.8%; HR, 1.07; 95% CI, 0.81&#8211;1.40).[<a href="#cit/section_5.214">

3790214</a>

3791][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3792Level of evidence B1</a>

3793] It is unclear if patients who received ibrutinib alone could have achieved these same results without receiving conventional chemotherapy. The magnitude of benefit demonstrated by the PFS results contrasted with the insufficient OS benefit after 7 years may cast doubt on the long-term safety of this combination.</p>

3794<p id="_138" tabindex="-1">

3795In a prospective randomized trial, 560 patients older than 60 years and not eligible for SCT were given either R-CHOP or R-FC (rituximab, fludarabine, cyclophosphamide) for six to eight cycles, followed by maintenance therapy in responders randomly assigned to rituximab or interferon-alpha maintenance therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.215">

3796215</a>

3797] With a median follow-up of 7.6 years, the median OS was significantly shorter after R-FC than after R-CHOP (3.9 years versus 6.4 years; <em>

3798P</em>

3799 = .0054).[<a href="#cit/section_5.215">

3800215</a>

3801][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3802Level of evidence A1</a>

3803] In the same trial, with a median follow-up of 8 years for the 316 responding patients, rituximab maintenance resulted in improved OS over interferon maintenance (median OS, 9.8 years vs. 7.1 years; <em>

3804P</em>

3805 = .009).[<a href="#cit/section_5.215">

3806215</a>

3807][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3808Level of evidence A1</a>

3809] Patients responsive to R-CHOP benefitted most from rituximab in OS (median 9.8 years vs. 6.4 years; <em>

3810P</em>

3811 = .0026).[<a href="#cit/section_5.215">

3812215</a>

3813][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3814Level of evidence C1</a>

3815] A randomized trial compared bendamustine plus rituximab (BR) with R-CHOP and showed improved PFS (35 vs. 22 months; HR, 0.49; 95% CI, 0.28&#8211;0.79; <em>

3816P</em>

3817 = .004) but no difference in OS.[<a href="#cit/section_5.216">

3818216</a>

3819][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3820Level of evidence B1</a>

3821] However, this trial failed to show any benefit for rituximab maintenance after BR. A prospective randomized trial of 487 patients compared VR-CAP (bortezomib, rituximab, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, prednisone) with R-CHOP.[<a href="#cit/section_5.217">

3822217</a>

3823] With a median follow-up of 82 months, the median OS was longer for VR-CAP (90.7 months) compared with R-CHOP (55.7 months) (HR, 0.66; 95% CI, 0.51&#8722;0.85; <em>

3824P</em>

3825 = .001).[<a href="#cit/section_5.217">

3826217</a>

3827][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3828Level of evidence A1</a>

3829]</p>

3830<p id="_891" tabindex="-1">

3831A prospective randomized trial of 497 patients younger than 65 years compared six cycles of R-CHOP with six cycles of alternating R-CHOP and R-DHAP (rituximab, dexamethasone, cytarabine, and cisplatin), with both groups then receiving autologous SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_5.218">

3832218</a>

3833,<a href="#cit/section_5.219">

3834219</a>

3835][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3836Level of evidence B1</a>

3837] With a median follow-up of 10.6 years, the 10-year PFS rate was 73% for patients who received R-DHAP and 57% for patients who received R-CHOP (HR, 0.56; <em>

3838P</em>

3839 = .038), but there was no difference in the 10-year OS rates (60% [R-DHAP] vs. 55% [R-CHOP]; HR, 0.80; 0.61&#8211;1.06; <em>

3840P</em>

3841 = .12).[<a href="#cit/section_5.220">

3842220</a>

3843][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3844Level of evidence B1</a>

3845] This is the randomized trial referenced by all subsequent articles establishing a role for cytarabine in induction therapy; the ultimate lack of survival advantage casts doubt on this assertion.</p>

3846<p id="_1392" tabindex="-1">

3847Randomized trials have not confirmed an OS benefit in patients who receive consolidation therapy with autologous or allogeneic SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_5.221">

3848221</a>

3849-<a href="#cit/section_5.226">

3850226</a>

3851]</p>

3852<p id="_967" tabindex="-1">

3853In a prospective trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00921414">

3854NCT00921414</a>

3855) of 299 patients who were previously untreated for MCL, 257 responders received four courses of R-DHAP and autologous SCT. The patients were randomly assigned to receive rituximab maintenance therapy for 3 years versus no maintenance therapy. After randomization, a median follow-up at 50.2 months showed the rate of PFS at 4-years favored the rituximab-maintenance arm at 83% (95% CI, 73%&#8211;88%) versus the no-maintenance arm at 64% (95% CI, 55%&#8211;73%; <em>

3856P</em>

3857 &lt; .001). The 4-year OS rate also favored the rituximab-maintenance arm at 89% (95% CI, 81%&#8211;94%) versus the no-maintenance arm at 80% (95% CI, 72%&#8211;88%; <em>

3858P</em>

3859 = .04).[<a href="#cit/section_5.227">

3860227</a>

3861][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3862Level of evidence A1</a>

3863]</p>

3864<p id="_968" tabindex="-1">

3865Lenalidomide with or without rituximab also shows response rates of around 50% in relapsed patients, with even higher response rates for previously untreated patients.[<a href="#cit/section_5.205">

3866205</a>

3867,<a href="#cit/section_5.208">

3868208</a>

3869,<a href="#cit/section_5.228">

3870228</a>

3871,<a href="#cit/section_5.229">

3872229</a>

3873][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3874Level of evidence C3</a>

3875] </p>

3876<p id="_1080" tabindex="-1">

3877Acalabrutinib (another B-cell receptor inhibitor via the Bruton tyrosine kinase [BTK] pathway) was studied in 124 patients with relapsed or refractory MCL.[<a href="#cit/section_5.230">

3878230</a>

3879] In a phase II study, there was an 81% overall response rate, 40% CR rate, and 67% 1-year PFS rate.[<a href="#cit/section_5.230">

3880230</a>

3881][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3882Level of evidence C3</a>

3883] Similarly, the BTK inhibitor zanubrutinib was evaluated in a phase II study of 86 patients with relapsed or refractory MCL.[<a href="#cit/section_5.231">

3884231</a>

3885] After a median follow-up of 35.3 months, the overall response rate was 84%, the CR rate was 78%, and the median PFS was 33.0 months.[<a href="#cit/section_5.231">

3886231</a>

3887][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3888Level of evidence C3</a>

3889]</p>

3890<p id="_1210" tabindex="-1">

3891Patients with relapsed or refractory MCL whose disease did not respond to ibrutinib or acalabrutinib were enrolled in a phase II trial using brexucabtagene autoleucel, an anti-CD19 CAR T-cell therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.232">

3892232</a>

3893] With a median follow-up of 36 months, 74 patients had an objective response rate of 91% (95% CI, 82%&#8722;97%) and a CR rate of 68% (95% CI, 55%&#8722;78%).[<a href="#cit/section_5.232">

3894232</a>

3895][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3896Level of evidence C3</a>

3897] Grade 3 or higher cytokine release syndrome occurred in 15% of patients, and neurological events occurred in 31% of patients.</p>

3898<p id="_1472" tabindex="-1">

3899In summary, the optimal sequencing of these various therapies is unclear and is the subject of an ongoing Intergroup clinical trial. Rituximab, lenalidomide, ibrutinib, acalabrutinib, venetoclax, and zanubrutinib represent directed biological agents that may lead to chemotherapy-free treatment strategies for patients with MCL.[<a href="#cit/section_5.233">

3900233</a>

3901]</p>

3902<p id="_1393" tabindex="-1">

3903Routine administration of CNS prophylaxis in high-risk MCL has never been studied in a prospective randomized trial. The use of intrathecal or high-dose methotrexate or the use of systemic therapies with CNS penetration like ibrutinib, high-dose cytarabine, or venetoclax, have not been studied and proven efficacious in this situation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.196">

3904196</a>

3905]</p>

3906</section>

3907</section>

3908<section id="_139">

3909<h3 id="_139_toc">

3910Posttransplantation Lymphoproliferative Disorder</h3>

3911<p id="_140" tabindex="-1">

3912Patients who undergo transplantation of the heart, lung, liver, kidney, or pancreas usually require lifelong immunosuppression. This may result in posttransplantation lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD) in 1% to 3% of recipients, which appears as an aggressive lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.234">

3913234</a>

3914] Pathologists can distinguish a polyclonal B-cell hyperplasia from a monoclonal B-cell lymphoma; both are almost always associated with EBV.[<a href="#cit/section_5.235">

3915235</a>

3916]</p>

3917<section id="_533">

3918<h4 id="_533_toc">

3919Prognosis</h4>

3920<p id="_141" tabindex="-1">

3921 Poor performance status, grafted organ involvement, high IPI, elevated LDH, and multiple sites of disease are poor prognostic factors for PTLD.[<a href="#cit/section_5.236">

3922236</a>

3923,<a href="#cit/section_5.237">

3924237</a>

3925]</p>

3926</section>

3927<section id="_534">

3928<h4 id="_534_toc">

3929Therapeutic options</h4>

3930<p id="_142" tabindex="-1">

3931 In some cases, withdrawal of immunosuppression results in eradication of the lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.238">

3932238</a>

3933,<a href="#cit/section_5.239">

3934239</a>

3935] When this is unsuccessful or not feasible, a course of rituximab may be considered, because it has shown durable remissions in approximately 60% of patients and a favorable toxicity profile.[<a href="#cit/section_5.238">

3936238</a>

3937,<a href="#cit/section_5.240">

3938240</a>

3939,<a href="#cit/section_5.241">

3940241</a>

3941] If these measures fail, doxorubicin-based combination chemotherapy (R-CHOP) is recommended, although some patients can avoid cytotoxic therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.241">

3942241</a>

3943,<a href="#cit/section_5.242">

3944242</a>

3945] Localized presentations can be controlled with surgery or radiation therapy alone. These localized mass lesions, which may grow over a period of months, are often phenotypically polyclonal and tend to occur within weeks or a few months after transplantation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.235">

3946235</a>

3947] Multifocal, rapidly progressive disease occurs late after transplantation (&gt;1 year) and is usually phenotypically monoclonal and associated with EBV.[<a href="#cit/section_5.243">

3948243</a>

3949] These patients may have durable remissions using standard chemotherapy regimens for aggressive lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.243">

3950243</a>

3951-<a href="#cit/section_5.245">

3952245</a>

3953] Instances of EBV-negative PTLD occur even later (median, 5 years posttransplant) and have a worse prognosis; R-CHOP chemotherapy can be applied directly in this circumstance.[<a href="#cit/section_5.246">

3954246</a>

3955] A sustained clinical response after failure from chemotherapy was attained using an immunotoxin (anti-CD22 B-cell surface antigen antibody linked with ricin, a plant toxin).[<a href="#cit/section_5.247">

3956247</a>

3957] An anti-interleukin-6 monoclonal antibody is also under clinical evaluation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.248">

3958248</a>

3959]</p>

3960</section>

3961</section>

3962<section id="_143">

3963<h3 id="_143_toc">

3964True Histiocytic Lymphoma</h3>

3965<p id="_144" tabindex="-1">

3966True histiocytic lymphomas are very rare tumors that show histiocytic differentiation and express histiocytic markers in the absence of B-cell or T-cell lineage-specific immunologic markers.[<a href="#cit/section_5.249">

3967249</a>

3968,<a href="#cit/section_5.250">

3969250</a>

3970] Care must be taken with immunophenotypic tests to exclude ALCL or hemophagocytic syndromes caused by viral infections, especially EBV.</p>

3971<section id="_535">

3972<h4 id="_535_toc">

3973Therapeutic options</h4>

3974<p id="_145" tabindex="-1">

3975 Therapy is modeled after the treatment of comparably staged diffuse large cell lymphomas, but the optimal approach remains to be defined.</p>

3976</section>

3977</section>

3978<section id="_146">

3979<h3 id="_146_toc">

3980Primary Effusion Lymphoma</h3>

3981<p id="_147" tabindex="-1">

3982Primary effusion lymphoma presents exclusively or mainly in the pleural, pericardial, or abdominal cavities in the absence of an identifiable tumor mass.[<a href="#cit/section_5.251">

3983251</a>

3984] Patients are usually HIV seropositive, and the tumor usually contains Kaposi sarcoma&#8211;associated herpes virus/human herpes virus 8.[<a href="#cit/section_5.252">

3985252</a>

3986]</p>

3987<section id="_536">

3988<h4 id="_536_toc">

3989Prognosis</h4>

3990<p id="_148" tabindex="-1">

3991 The prognosis of primary effusion lymphoma is extremely poor.</p>

3992</section>

3993<section id="_537">

3994<h4 id="_537_toc">

3995Therapeutic approaches</h4>

3996<p id="_149" tabindex="-1">

3997 Therapy is usually modeled after the treatment of comparably staged diffuse large cell lymphomas.</p>

3998</section>

3999</section>

4000<section id="_810">

4001<h3 id="_810_toc">

4002Plasmablastic Lymphoma</h3>

4003<p id="_811" tabindex="-1">

4004Plasmablastic lymphoma is most often seen in patients with HIV infection and is characterized by CD20-negative large B cells with plasmacytic features. This type of lymphoma has a very aggressive clinical course, including poor responses and short remissions with standard chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.253">

4005253</a>

4006] Anecdotal reports suggest using aggressive chemotherapy for Burkitt or lymphoblastic lymphoma, followed by SCT consolidation in responding patients, when feasible.[<a href="#cit/section_5.253">

4007253</a>

4008-<a href="#cit/section_5.255">

4009255</a>

4010]</p>

4011</section>

4012<h6 do-not-show="toc">

4013References</h6>

4037[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4038</li>

4045[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4046</li>

4047<li id="section_5.9">

J Clin Oncol 24 (19): 3121-7, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16754935&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16754935&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4049[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4050</li>

4051<li id="section_5.10">

Blood 123 (6): 837-42, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24264230&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24264230&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4053[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4054</li>

Cancer 98 (3): 516-21, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12879468&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12879468&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4057[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4058</li>

4059<li id="section_5.12">

4060Maurer MJ, Ghesqui&#232;res H, Link BK, et al.: Diagnosis-to-Treatment Interval Is an Important Clinical Factor in Newly Diagnosed Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma and Has Implication for Bias in Clinical Trials. J Clin Oncol 36 (16): 1603-1610, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29672223&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29672223&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4061[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4062</li>

4063<li id="section_5.13">

4064Scott DW, King RL, Staiger AM, et al.: High-grade B-cell lymphoma with MYC and BCL2 and/or BCL6 rearrangements with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma morphology.
