5001<li id="section_5.249">

5002Soslow RA, Davis RE, Warnke RA, et al.: True histiocytic lymphoma following therapy for lymphoblastic neoplasms. Blood 87 (12): 5207-12, 1996.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8652834&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8652834&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5003[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5004</li>

5005<li id="section_5.250">

5006Kamel OW, Gocke CD, Kell DL, et al.: True histiocytic lymphoma: a study of 12 cases based on current definition. Leuk Lymphoma 18 (1-2): 81-6, 1995.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8580833&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8580833&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5007[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5008</li>

5009<li id="section_5.251">

5010Nador RG, Cesarman E, Chadburn A, et al.: Primary effusion lymphoma: a distinct clinicopathologic entity associated with the Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpes virus. Blood 88 (2): 645-56, 1996.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8695812&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8695812&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5011[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5012</li>

5013<li id="section_5.252">

5014Shimada K, Hayakawa F, Kiyoi H: Biology and management of primary effusion lymphoma. Blood 132 (18): 1879-1888, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=30154110&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=30154110&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5015[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5016</li>

5017<li id="section_5.253">

5018Castillo JJ, Bibas M, Miranda RN: The biology and treatment of plasmablastic lymphoma. Blood 125 (15): 2323-30, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25636338&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25636338&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5019[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5020</li>

5021<li id="section_5.254">

5022Al-Malki MM, Castillo JJ, Sloan JM, et al.: Hematopoietic cell transplantation for plasmablastic lymphoma: a review. Biol Blood Marrow Transplant 20 (12): 1877-84, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24946718&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24946718&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5023[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5024</li>

5025<li id="section_5.255">

5026Cattaneo C, Re A, Ungari M, et al.: Plasmablastic lymphoma among human immunodeficiency virus-positive patients: results of a single center's experience. Leuk Lymphoma 56 (1): 267-9, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24712980&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24712980&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5027[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5028</li>

5029</ol>

5030</div>

5031

5032 </section>

5033

5034

5035

5036 <section id="_152">

5037

5038 <h2>

5039Stage Information for NHL</h2>

5040

5041 <div id="_section_152" class="pdq-sections">

5042<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

5043<h6>

5044In This Section</h6>

5045<ul>

5046<li>

5047<a href="#_158_toc">

5048Staging Subclassification System<ul>

5049<li>

5050<a href="#_1073_toc">

5051Lugano Classification</a>

5052</li>

5053</ul>

5054</a>

5055</li>

5056</ul>

5057</nav>

5058<p id="_153" tabindex="-1">

5059Stage is important in selecting a treatment for patients with non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). Chest and abdominal computed tomography (CT) scans are usually part of the staging evaluation for all lymphoma patients. The staging system is similar to the staging system used for Hodgkin lymphoma (HL).</p>

5060<p id="_154" tabindex="-1">

5061Common among patients with NHL is involvement of the following:</p>

5062<div class="pdq-content-list">

5063<ul id="_155">

5064<li>

5065Noncontiguous lymph nodes.</li>

5066<li>

5067Waldeyer ring.</li>

5068<li>

5069Epitrochlear nodes.</li>

5070<li>

5071Gastrointestinal tract.</li>

5072<li>

5073Extranodal presentations. (A single extranodal site is occasionally the only site of involvement in patients with diffuse lymphoma.)</li>

5074<li>

5075Bone marrow.</li>

5076<li>

5077Liver (especially common in patients with low-grade lymphomas).</li>

5078</ul>

5079</div>

5080<p id="_156" tabindex="-1">

5081Cytological examination of cerebrospinal fluid may be positive in patients with aggressive NHL. Involvement of hilar and mediastinal lymph nodes is less common than in HL. Mediastinal adenopathy, however, is a prominent feature of lymphoblastic lymphoma and primary mediastinal B-cell lymphoma, entities primarily found in young adults.</p>

5082<p id="_157" tabindex="-1">

5083Most patients with NHL present with advanced (stage III or stage IV) disease that can often be identified with limited staging procedures such as CT scanning and biopsies of the bone marrow and other accessible sites of involvement. In a retrospective review of over 32,000 cases of lymphoma in France, up to 40% of diagnoses were made by core needle biopsy, and 60% were made by excisional biopsy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

50841</a>

5085] After expert review, core needle biopsy provided a definite diagnosis in 92.3% of cases, but it was less conclusive than excisional biopsy, which provided a definite diagnosis in 98.1% of cases (<em>

5086P</em>

5087 &lt; .0001). Laparoscopic biopsy or laparotomy is not required for staging but rarely may be necessary to establish a diagnosis or histological type.[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

50882</a>

5089] Positron emission tomography (PET) with fluorine F 18-fludeoxyglucose can be used for initial staging and for follow-up after therapy as a supplement to CT scanning.[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

50903</a>

5091] Interim PET scans after two to four cycles of therapy did not provide reliable prognostic information because of problems of interobserver reproducibility in a large cooperative group trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00274924">

5092ECOG-E344</a>

5093 [NCT00274924]) and lack of difference in outcome between PET-negative and PET-positive/biopsy-negative patients in two prospective trials [<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

50944</a>

5095-<a href="#cit/section_6.6">

50966</a>

5097] and in a meta-analysis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.7">

50987</a>

5099] For patients with follicular lymphoma, a positive PET result after therapy has a worse prognosis; however, it is unclear whether a positive PET result is predictive when further or different therapy is implemented.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

51008</a>

5101]</p>

5102<p id="_812" tabindex="-1">

5103In a retrospective study of 130 patients with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, PET scanning identified all clinically important marrow involvement from lymphoma, and bone marrow biopsy did not upstage any patient's lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.9">

51049</a>

5105] A retrospective study of 580 patients with follicular lymphoma from seven National Cancer Institute-sponsored trials showed no improvement in assessing response to therapy when bone marrow biopsy was added to radiological imaging.[<a href="#cit/section_6.10">

510610</a>

5107] The workup of NHL should include bone marrow biopsy when management would change (e.g., determining limited stage vs. advanced stage) or when evaluating cytopenias.</p>

5108<section id="_158">

5109<h3 id="_158_toc">

5110Staging Subclassification System</h3>

5111<section id="_1073">

5112<h4 id="_1073_toc">

5113Lugano Classification</h4>

5114<p id="_1074" tabindex="-1">

5115The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) has adopted the Lugano classification to evaluate and stage lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.11">

511611</a>

5117] The Lugano classification system replaces the Ann Arbor classification system, which was adopted in 1971 at the Ann Arbor Conference,[<a href="#cit/section_6.12">

511812</a>

5119] with some modifications 18 years later from the Cotswolds meeting.[<a href="#cit/section_6.13">

512013</a>

5121,<a href="#cit/section_6.14">

512214</a>

5123] </p>

5124<table id="_1075" class="table-default expandable-container">

5125<caption>

5126Table 2. Lugano Classification for Hodgkin and Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma<span class="sup">

5127a</span>

5128</caption>

5129<colgroup>

5130<col width="10.72%">

5131<col width="52.36%">

5132<col width="36.90%">

5133</colgroup>

5134<THead>

5135<tr>

5136<th align="Center" scope="col">

5137Stage</th>

5138<th align="Center" scope="col">

5139 Stage Description</th>

5140<th align="Center" scope="col">

5141Illustration</th>

5142</tr>

5143</THead>

5144<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

5145<tr>

5146<td colspan="3">

5147CSF = cerebrospinal fluid; CT = computed tomography; DLBCL = diffuse large B-cell lymphoma; NHL = non-Hodgkin lymphoma.</td>

5148</tr>

5149<tr>

5150<td colspan="3">

5151<span class="sup">

5152a</span>

5153Hodgkin and Non-Hodgkin Lymphomas. In: Amin MB, Edge SB, Greene FL, et al., eds.: <em>

5154AJCC Cancer Staging Manual</em>

5155. 8th ed. New York, NY: Springer, 2017, pp. 937&#8211;58.</td>

5156</tr>

5157<tr>

5158<td colspan="3">

5159<span class="sup">

5160b</span>

5161Stage II bulky may be considered either early or advanced stage based on lymphoma histology and prognostic factors.</td>

5162</tr>

5163<tr>

5164<td colspan="3">

5165<span class="sup">

5166c</span>

5167The definition of disease bulk varies according to lymphoma histology. In the Lugano classification, bulk ln Hodgkin lymphoma is defined as a mass greater than one-third of the thoracic diameter on CT of the chest or a mass &gt;10 cm. For NHL, the recommended definitions of bulk vary by lymphoma histology. In follicular lymphoma, 6 cm has been suggested based on the Follicular Lymphoma International Prognostic Index-2 and its validation. In DLBCL, cutoffs ranging from 5 cm to 10 cm have been used, although 10 cm is recommended.</td>

5168</tr>

5169</TFoot>

5170<tbody>

5171<tr>

5172<td colspan="3">

5173<em>

5174Limited stage</em>

5175</td>

5176</tr>

5177<tr>

5178<td>

5179I</td>

5180<td>

5181Involvement of a single lymphatic site (i.e., nodal region, Waldeyer&#8217;s ring, thymus, or spleen).</td>

5182<td>

5183<figure id="figure_1088" class="image-center">

5184<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/614643.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

5185Enlarge</a>

5186<img id="_1088" alt="Stage I adult lymphoma; drawing shows cancer in one lymph node group and in the spleen. Also shown are the Waldeyer&#8217;s ring and the thymus. An inset shows a lymph node with a lymph vessel, an artery, and a vein. Cancer cells are shown in the lymph node." title="Stage I adult lymphoma; drawing shows cancer in one lymph node group and in the spleen. Also shown are the Waldeyer&#8217;s ring and the thymus. An inset shows a lymph node with a lymph vessel, an artery, and a vein. Cancer cells are shown in the lymph node." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/614643-750.jpg">

5187</figure>

5188</td>

5189</tr>

5190<tr>

5191<td>

5192IE</td>

5193<td>

5194Single extralymphatic site in the absence of nodal involvement (rare in Hodgkin lymphoma).</td>

5195<td>

5196&#160;</td>

5197</tr>

5198<tr>

5199<td>

5200II</td>

5201<td>

5202Involvement of two or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm.</td>

5203<td>

5204<figure id="figure_1089" class="image-center">

5205<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/614648.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

5206Enlarge</a>

5207<img id="_1089" alt="Stage II adult lymphoma; drawing shows cancer in two lymph node groups above the diaphragm and below the diaphragm. An inset shows a lymph node with a lymph vessel, an artery, and a vein. Cancer cells are shown in the lymph node." title="Stage II adult lymphoma; drawing shows cancer in two lymph node groups above the diaphragm and below the diaphragm. An inset shows a lymph node with a lymph vessel, an artery, and a vein. Cancer cells are shown in the lymph node." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/614648-750.jpg">

5208</figure>

5209</td>

5210</tr>

5211<tr>

5212<td>

5213IIE</td>

5214<td>

5215Contiguous extralymphatic extension from a nodal site with or without involvement of other lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm.</td>

5216<td>

5217<figure id="figure_1090" class="image-center">

5218<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/614650.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

5219Enlarge</a>

5220<img id="_1090" alt="Stage IIE adult lymphoma; drawing shows cancer that has spread from a group of lymph nodes to a nearby area. Also shown is a lung and the diaphragm. An inset shows a lymph node with a lymph vessel, an artery, and a vein. Cancer cells are shown in the lymph node." title="Stage IIE adult lymphoma; drawing shows cancer that has spread from a group of lymph nodes to a nearby area. Also shown is a lung and the diaphragm. An inset shows a lymph node with a lymph vessel, an artery, and a vein. Cancer cells are shown in the lymph node." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/614650-750.jpg">

5221</figure>

5222</td>

5223</tr>

5224<tr>

5225<td>

5226II bulky<span class="sup">

5227b</span>

5228</td>

5229<td>

5230Stage II with disease bulk.<span class="sup">

5231c</span>

5232</td>

5233<td>

5234&#160;</td>

5235</tr>

5236<tr>

5237<td colspan="3">

5238<em>

5239Advanced stage</em>

5240</td>

5241</tr>

5242<tr>

5243<td>

5244III</td>

5245<td>

5246Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm; nodes above the diaphragm with spleen involvement.</td>

5247<td>

5248<figure id="figure_1091" class="image-center">

5249<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/614684.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

5250Enlarge</a>

5251<img id="_1091" alt="Stage III adult lymphoma; drawing shows the right and left sides of the body. The right side of the body shows cancer in a group of lymph nodes above the diaphragm and below the diaphragm. The left side of the body shows cancer in a group of lymph nodes above the diaphragm and cancer in the spleen." title="Stage III adult lymphoma; drawing shows the right and left sides of the body. The right side of the body shows cancer in a group of lymph nodes above the diaphragm and below the diaphragm. The left side of the body shows cancer in a group of lymph nodes above the diaphragm and cancer in the spleen." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/614684-750.jpg">

5252</figure>

5253</td>

5254</tr>

5255<tr>

5256<td>

5257IV</td>

5258<td>

5259Diffuse or disseminated involvement of one or more extralymphatic organs, with or without associated lymph node involvement; or noncontiguous extralymphatic organ involvement in conjunction with nodal stage II disease; or any extralymphatic organ involvement in nodal stage III disease. Stage IV includes any involvement of the CSF, bone marrow, liver, or multiple lung lesions (other than by direct extension in stage IIE disease).</td>

5260<td>

5261<figure id="figure_1092" class="image-center">

5262<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/629626.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

5263Enlarge</a>

5264<img id="_1092" alt="Stage IV adult lymphoma; drawing shows four panels: (a) the top left panel shows cancer in the liver; (b) the top right panel shows cancer in the left lung and in two groups of lymph nodes below the diaphragm; (c) the bottom left panel shows cancer in the left lung and in a group of lymph nodes above the diaphragm and below the diaphragm; and (d) the bottom right panel shows cancer in both lungs, the liver, and the bone marrow (pullout). Also shown is primary cancer in the lymph nodes and a pullout of the brain with cerebrospinal fluid (in blue)." title="Stage IV adult lymphoma; drawing shows four panels: (a) the top left panel shows cancer in the liver; (b) the top right panel shows cancer in the left lung and in two groups of lymph nodes below the diaphragm; (c) the bottom left panel shows cancer in the left lung and in a group of lymph nodes above the diaphragm and below the diaphragm; and (d) the bottom right panel shows cancer in both lungs, the liver, and the bone marrow (pullout). Also shown is primary cancer in the lymph nodes and a pullout of the brain with cerebrospinal fluid (in blue)." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/629626-750.jpg">

5265</figure>

5266</td>

5267</tr>

5268<tr>

5269<td colspan="3">

5270Note: Hodgkin lymphoma uses A or B designation with stage group. A/B is no longer used in NHL.</td>

5271</tr>

5272</tbody>

5273</table>

5274</section>

5275<p id="_162" tabindex="-1">

5276Occasionally, specialized staging systems are used. The physician should be aware of the system used in a specific report.</p>

5277<p id="_163" tabindex="-1">

5278The E designation is used when extranodal lymphoid malignancies arise in tissues separate from, but near, the major lymphatic aggregates. Stage IV refers to disease that is diffusely spread throughout an extranodal site, such as the liver. If pathological proof of involvement of one or more extralymphatic sites has been documented, the symbol for the site of involvement, followed by a plus sign (+), is listed.</p>

5279<table id="_164" class="table-default expandable-container">

5280<caption>

5281Table 3. Notation to Identify Specific Sites</caption>

5282<colgroup>

5283<col width="25.00%">

5284<col width="25.00%">

5285<col width="25.00%">

5286<col width="25.00%">

5287</colgroup>

5288<tbody>

5289<tr>

5290<td>

5291N = nodes</td>

5292<td>

5293H = liver</td>

5294<td>

5295L = lung</td>

5296<td>

5297M = bone marrow</td>

5298</tr>

5299<tr>

5300<td>

5301S = spleen</td>

5302<td>

5303P = pleura</td>

5304<td>

5305O = bone</td>

5306<td>

5307D = skin</td>

5308</tr>

5309</tbody>

5310</table>

5311<p id="_165" tabindex="-1">

5312Current practice assigns a clinical stage based on the findings of the clinical evaluation and a pathological stage based on the findings made as a result of invasive procedures beyond the initial biopsy.</p>

5313<p id="_166" tabindex="-1">

5314For example, on percutaneous biopsy, a patient with inguinal adenopathy and a positive lymphangiogram without systemic symptoms might have involvement of the liver and bone marrow. The precise stage of such a patient would be clinical stage IIA, pathological stage IVA(H+)(M+).

5315

5316</p>

5317<p id="_167" tabindex="-1">

5318Several other factors that are not included in the above staging system are important for the staging and prognosis of patients with NHL. These factors include the following:</p>

5319<div class="pdq-content-list">

5320<ul id="_168">

5321<li>

5322Age.</li>

5323<li>

5324Performance status (PS).</li>

5325<li>

5326Tumor size.</li>

5327<li>

5328Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) values.</li>

5329<li>

5330The number of extranodal sites.</li>

5331</ul>

5332</div>

5333<p id="_1047" tabindex="-1">

5334The National Comprehensive Cancer Network International Prognostic Index (IPI) for aggressive NHL (diffuse large cell lymphoma) identifies the following five significant risk factors prognostic of overall survival (OS) and their associated risk scores:[<a href="#cit/section_6.15">

533515</a>

5336]</p>

5337<div class="pdq-content-list">

5338<ul id="_1048">

5339<li>

5340Age.<div class="pdq-content-list">

5341<ul id="_1379" class="list-dash">

5342<li>

5343&lt;40 years: 0.</li>

5344<li>

534541&#8211;60 years: 1.</li>

5346<li>

534761&#8211;75 years: 2.</li>

5348<li>

5349&gt;75 years: 3.</li>

5350</ul>

5351</div>

5352</li>

5353<li>

5354Stage III/IV: 1.</li>

5355<li>

5356PS 2/3/4: 1.</li>

5357<li>

5358Serum LDH.<div class="pdq-content-list">

5359<ul id="_1380" class="list-dash">

5360<li>

5361Normalized: 0.</li>

5362<li>

5363&gt;1x&#8211;3x: 1.</li>

5364<li>

5365&gt;3x: 2.</li>

5366</ul>

5367</div>

5368</li>

5369<li>

5370Number of extranodal sites &#8805;2: 1.</li>

5371</ul>

5372</div>

5373<p id="_1058" tabindex="-1">

5374Risk scores:</p>

5375<div class="pdq-content-list">

5376<ul id="_1059">

5377<li>

5378Low (0 or 1): 5-year OS rate, 96%; progression-free survival (PFS) rate, 91%.</li>

5379<li>

5380Low intermediate (2 or 3): 5-year OS rate, 82%; PFS rate, 74%.</li>

5381<li>

5382High intermediate (4 or 5): 5-year OS rate, 64%; PFS rate, 51%.</li>

5383<li>

5384High (&gt;6): 5-year OS rate, 33%; PFS rate, 30%.</li>

5385</ul>

5386</div>

5387<p id="_1049" tabindex="-1">

5388Age-adjusted and stage-adjusted modifications of this IPI are used for younger patients with localized disease.[<a href="#cit/section_6.16">

538916</a>

5390] Shorter intervals of time between diagnosis and treatment appear to be a surrogate for poor prognostic biological factors.[<a href="#cit/section_6.17">

539117</a>

5392]</p>

5393<p id="_175" tabindex="-1">

5394The <em class="gene-name">

5395BCL2</em>

5396 gene and rearrangement of the <em class="gene-name">

5397MYC</em>

5398 gene or dual overexpression of the <em class="gene-name">

5399MYC</em>

5400 gene, or both, confer a particularly poor prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.18">

540118</a>

5402,<a href="#cit/section_6.19">

540319</a>

5404] Patients at high risk of relapse may benefit from consolidation therapy or other approaches under clinical evaluation.[<a href="#cit/section_6.20">

540520</a>

5406] Molecular profiles of gene expression using DNA microarrays may help to stratify patients in the future for therapies directed at specific targets and to better predict survival after standard chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.21">

540721</a>

5408]</p>

5409</section>

5410<h6 do-not-show="toc">

5411References</h6>

5412<ol>

5413<li id="section_6.1">

Blood 140 (24): 2573-2583, 2022.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35797472&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35797472&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5415[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5416</li>

5417<li id="section_6.2">

5418Mann GB, Conlon KC, LaQuaglia M, et al.: Emerging role of laparoscopy in the diagnosis of lymphoma. J Clin Oncol 16 (5): 1909-15, 1998.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9586909&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9586909&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5419[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5420</li>

5421<li id="section_6.3">

5422Barrington SF, Mikhaeel NG, Kostakoglu L, et al.: Role of imaging in the staging and response assessment of lymphoma: consensus of the International Conference on Malignant Lymphomas Imaging Working Group. 5496</div>

5497

5498 </section>

5499

5500

5501

5502 <section id="_993">

5503

5504 <h2>

5505Treatment Option Overview for NHL</h2>

5506

5507 <div id="_section_993" class="pdq-sections">

5508<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

5509<h6>

5510In This Section</h6>

5511<ul>

5512<li>

5513<a href="#_1433_toc">

5514Castleman Disease</a>

5515</li>

5516<li>

5517<a href="#_TrialSearch_993_sid_7_toc">

5518Current Clinical Trials</a>

5519</li>

5520</ul>

5521</nav>

5522<p id="_994" tabindex="-1">

5523Treatment of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) depends on the histological type and stage. Many of the improvements in survival have been made using clinical trials (experimental therapy) that have attempted to improve on the best available accepted therapy (conventional or standard therapy).

5524

5525</p>

5526<p id="_995" tabindex="-1">

5527In asymptomatic patients with indolent forms of advanced NHL, treatment may be

5528deferred until the patient becomes symptomatic as the disease progresses. When

5529treatment is deferred, the clinical course of patients with indolent NHL

5530varies; frequent and careful observation is required so that effective

5531treatment can be initiated when the clinical course of the disease accelerates.

5532Some patients have a prolonged indolent course, but others have disease that

5533rapidly evolves into more aggressive types of NHL that require immediate

5534treatment.</p>

5535<p id="_996" tabindex="-1">

5536Radiation techniques differ somewhat from those used in the treatment of

5537Hodgkin lymphoma. The dose of radiation therapy usually varies from 25 Gy to

553850 Gy and is dependent on factors that include the histological type of

5539lymphoma, the patient&#8217;s stage and overall condition, the goal of treatment

5540(curative or palliative), the proximity of sensitive surrounding organs, and

5541whether the patient is being treated with radiation therapy alone or in

5542combination with chemotherapy. Given the patterns of

5543disease presentations and relapse, treatment may need to include unusual sites

5544such as Waldeyer ring, epitrochlear nodes, or mesenteric nodes. The

5545associated morbidity of the treatment must be considered carefully. Most patients who receive radiation are treated on only one side

5546of the diaphragm. Localized presentations of extranodal NHL may be treated

5547with involved-field techniques with significant (&gt;50%) success.</p>

5548<table id="_200" class="table-default expandable-container">

5549<caption>

5550Table 4. Treatment Options for Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL)</caption>

5551<colgroup>

5552<col width="34.24%">

5553<col width="65.75%">

5554</colgroup>

5555<THead>

5556<tr>

5557<th align="Center" scope="col">

5558Stage</th>

5559<th align="Center" scope="col">

5560Treatment Options</th>

5561</tr>

5562</THead>

5563<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

5564<tr>

5565<td colspan="2">

5566BMT = bone marrow transplantation; CAR = chimeric antigen receptor; CNS = central nervous system; IF-XRT = involved-field radiation therapy; PI3K = phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase; R-ACVBP = rituximab, doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, vindesine, bleomycin, prednisone; R-CHOP = rituximab, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone; SCT = stem cell transplantation.</td>

5567</tr>

5568</TFoot>

5569<tbody>

5570<tr>

5850<tr>

5851<td>

5852<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1258">

5853Palliative radiation therapy</a>

5854</td>

5855</tr>

5856</tbody>

5857</table>

5858<p id="_997" tabindex="-1">

5859Even though existing treatments cure a significant fraction of patients with lymphoma, numerous clinical trials that explore treatment improvements are in progress. If possible, patients can be included in these studies. Standardized guidelines for response assessment have been suggested for use in clinical trials.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

58601</a>

5861]</p>

5862<p id="_998" tabindex="-1">

5863Several retrospective reviews suggest that routine surveillance scans offer little to no value in patients with diffuse-large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) who have attained a clinical complete remission after induction therapy. Prognostic value is also difficult to identify for an interim positron emission tomography-computed tomography scan during induction therapy for DLBCL.[<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

58642</a>

5865-<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

58665</a>

5867]</p>

5868<p id="_999" tabindex="-1">

5869Aggressive lymphomas are increasingly seen in HIV-positive patients. Treatment

5870of these patients requires special consideration. For more information, see

5871<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/aids-related-treatment-pdq">

5872AIDS-Related Lymphoma Treatment</a>

5873.</p>

5874<p id="_1000" tabindex="-1">

5875In addition to screening for HIV among patients with aggressive lymphomas, active hepatitis B or hepatitis C can be assessed before treatment with rituximab and/or chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

58766</a>

5877,<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

58787</a>

5879] Patients with detectable hepatitis B viral loads benefit from prophylaxis with entecavir in the context of rituximab therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

58808</a>

5881,<a href="#cit/section_7.9">

58829</a>

5883] Patients with a resolved hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection (defined as hepatitis B surface antigen-negative but hepatitis B core antibody-positive) are at risk of reactivation of HBV and require monitoring of HBV DNA. Prophylactic nucleoside therapy lowered HBV reactivation from 10.8% to 2.1% in a retrospective study of 326 patients.[<a href="#cit/section_7.10">

588410</a>

5885] Similarly, prophylaxis for herpes zoster with acyclovir or valacyclovir and prophylaxis for pneumocystis with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole or dapsone are usually applied with rituximab with or without combination chemotherapy. Long-term impaired immune health was evaluated in a retrospective cohort study of 21,690 survivors of DLBCL from the California Cancer Registry. Elevated incidence rate ratios were found up to 10 years later for pneumonia (10.8-fold), meningitis (5.3-fold), immunoglobulin deficiency (17.6-fold), and autoimmune cytopenias (12-fold).[<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

588611</a>

5887]</p>

5888<p id="_1211" tabindex="-1">

5889Among 2,508 patients in a Danish registry, the incidence of doxorubicin-induced congestive heart failure increased for 115 NHL survivors with a history of cardiac disease (hazard ratio [HR], 2.71; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.15&#8722;6.36) and/or multiple cardiovascular risk factors (HR, 2.86; 95% CI, 1.56&#8722;5.23).[<a href="#cit/section_7.12">

589012</a>

5891]</p>

5892<p id="_1002" tabindex="-1">

5893Several unusual presentations of lymphoma occur that often require somewhat modified approaches to staging and therapy. The reader is referred to reviews for a more detailed description of extranodal presentations in the gastrointestinal system,[<a href="#cit/section_7.13">

589413</a>

5895-<a href="#cit/section_7.21">

589621</a>

5897] thyroid,[<a href="#cit/section_7.22">

589822</a>

5899,<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

590023</a>

5901] spleen,[<a href="#cit/section_7.24">

590224</a>

5903] testis,[<a href="#cit/section_7.25">

590425</a>

5905-<a href="#cit/section_7.27">

590627</a>

5907] paranasal sinuses,[<a href="#cit/section_7.28">

590828</a>

5909-<a href="#cit/section_7.31">

591031</a>

5911] bone,[<a href="#cit/section_7.32">

591232</a>

5913,<a href="#cit/section_7.33">

591433</a>

5915] orbit,[<a href="#cit/section_7.34">

591634</a>

5917-<a href="#cit/section_7.38">

591838</a>

5919] and skin.[<a href="#cit/section_7.39">

592039</a>

5921-<a href="#cit/section_7.48">

592248</a>

5923]</p>

5924<p id="_1003" tabindex="-1">

5925For more information, see <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/primary-cns-lymphoma-treatment-pdq">

5926Primary CNS Lymphoma Treatment</a>

5927.</p>

5928<section id="_1433">

5929<h3 id="_1433_toc">

5930Castleman Disease</h3>

5931<p id="_1434" tabindex="-1">

5932A biopsy of localized or multifocal collections of lymph nodes may lead to a diagnosis of Castleman disease (CD), although it is an uncommon diagnosis. Strictly speaking, this is not a lymphoma, nor is it even a malignancy. Yet, many patients with CD may be seen and treated by hematologists or oncologists.</p>

5933<p id="_1435" tabindex="-1">

5934Localized or unicentric CD is usually asymptomatic and occurs in the mediastinum, which is the most common presentation for CD.[<a href="#cit/section_7.49">

593549</a>

5936] Watchful waiting, surgery, or radiation therapy can be used for this indolent form. Multicentric CD (30% of CD patients) presents with lymphadenopathy in multiple sites; symptoms such as fever, night sweats, weight loss, and fatigue; and laboratory abnormalities such as anemia, low albumin, elevated C-reactive protein, and high fibrinogen.[<a href="#cit/section_7.49">

593749</a>

5938] Multicentric CD (MCD) is subdivided into human herpes virus-8&#8211;associated MCD (usually with HIV or with severe immunocompromise) or idiopathic MCD. Cytopenias and cytokine storm are attributed to interleukin-6 (IL-6) overproduction. MCD is a feature seen in POEMS (polyneuropathy, organomegaly, endocrinopathy, monoclonal gammopathy, and skin abnormalities) syndrome [<a href="#cit/section_7.50">

593950</a>

5940] and TAFRO (thrombocytopenia, anasarca, fever, reticulin fibrosis, and organomegaly) syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_7.51">

594151</a>

5942,<a href="#cit/section_7.52">

594352</a>

5944] Therapy with siltuximab (an anti&#8211;IL-6 monoclonal antibody), rituximab (an anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody), or chemotherapeutic agents has been presented in anecdotal nonrandomized series.[<a href="#cit/section_7.53">

594553</a>

5946-<a href="#cit/section_7.56">

594756</a>

5948]</p>

5949</section>

5950<section id="_TrialSearch_993_sid_7">

5951<h3 id="_TrialSearch_993_sid_7_toc">

5952Current Clinical Trials</h3>

5953<p id="_TrialSearch_993_22" tabindex="-1">

5954Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

5955advanced clinical trial search</a>

5956 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

5957General information</a>

5958 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

5959</section>

6069[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6071<li id="section_7.28">

6072Liang R, Todd D, Chan TK, et al.: Treatment outcome and prognostic factors for primary nasal lymphoma. J Clin Oncol 13 (3): 666-70, 1995.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7884427&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7884427&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6073[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6074</li>

6075<li id="section_7.29">

6076Cheung MM, Chan JK, Lau WH, et al.: Primary non-Hodgkin's lymphoma of the nose and nasopharynx: clinical features, tumor immunophenotype, and treatment outcome in 113 patients. J Clin Oncol 16 (1): 70-7, 1998.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9440725&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9440725&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6077[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6078</li>

6079<li id="section_7.30">

6080Hausdorff J, Davis E, Long G, et al.: Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma of the paranasal sinuses: clinical and pathological features, and response to combined-modality therapy. Cancer J Sci Am 3 (5): 303-11, 1997 Sep-Oct.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9327155&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9327155&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6081[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6082</li>

6188</div>

6189

6190 </section>

6191

6192

6193

6194 <section id="_183">

6195

6196 <h2>

6197Treatment of Indolent Stage I and Indolent, Contiguous Stage II NHL</h2>

6198

6199 <div id="_section_183" class="pdq-sections">

6200<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

6201<h6>

6202In This Section</h6>

6203<ul>

6204<li>

6205<a href="#_185_toc">

6206Treatment Options for Indolent Stage I and Indolent, Contiguous Stage II NHL<ul>

6207<li>

6208<a href="#_326_toc">

6209Radiation therapy</a>

6210</li>

6211<li>

6212<a href="#_330_toc">

6213Rituximab with or without chemotherapy</a>

6214</li>

6215<li>

6216<a href="#_327_toc">

6217Watchful waiting</a>

6218</li>

6219<li>

6220<a href="#_328_toc">

6221Other therapies as designated for patients with advanced-stage disease</a>

6222</li>

6223</ul>

6224</a>

6225</li>

6226<li>

6227<a href="#_TrialSearch_183_sid_8_toc">

6228Current Clinical Trials</a>

6229</li>

6230</ul>

6231</nav>

6232<p id="_184" tabindex="-1">

6233Although localized presentations are uncommon in non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), the goal of treatment is to cure the disease in patients who are shown to have truly localized occurrence after undergoing appropriate staging.</p>

6234<section id="_185">

6235<h3 id="_185_toc">

6236Treatment Options for Indolent Stage I and Indolent, Contiguous Stage II NHL</h3>

6237<p id="_431" tabindex="-1">

6238Treatment options for indolent stage I and indolent, contiguous stage II NHL include the following:</p>

6239<div class="pdq-content-list">

6240<ol id="_430">

6241<li>

6242<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_326">

6243 Radiation therapy</a>

6244.</li>

6245<li>

6246<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_330">

6247Rituximab with or without chemotherapy</a>

6248.</li>

6249<li>

6250<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_327">

6251Watchful waiting</a>

6252.</li>

6253<li>

6254<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_328">

6255Other therapies as designated for patients with advanced-stage disease</a>

6256.</li>

6257</ol>

6258</div>

6259<p id="_1012" tabindex="-1">

6260In a prospective randomized trial, 150 patients with stage I or stage II follicular lymphoma were randomly assigned to 30 Gy of involved-field radiation therapy alone or radiation therapy plus six cycles of R-CVP (rituximab, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, prednisolone). With a median follow-up of 9.6 years, the 10-year progression-free survival (PFS) rate favored combined-modality therapy, at 59% (95% confidence interval [CI], 46%&#8211;74%) versus 41% for radiation therapy alone (95% CI, 30%&#8211;57%) (<em>

6261P</em>

6262 = .033). There was no difference in overall survival (OS) (87% and 95%, <em>

6263P</em>

6264 = .40).[<a href="#cit/section_8.1">

62651</a>

6266][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6267Level of evidence B1</a>

6268]</p>

6269<p id="_649" tabindex="-1">

6270The National Lymphocare Study identified 471 patients with stage I follicular lymphoma. Of those patients, 206 were rigorously staged with a bone marrow aspirate and biopsy, and computed tomography (CT) scans or positron emission tomography (PET)-CT scans.[<a href="#cit/section_8.2">

62712</a>

6272] Nonrandomized treatments included radiation therapy (27%), rituximab-chemotherapy (R-chemotherapy) (28%), watchful waiting (17%), R-chemotherapy plus radiation therapy (13%), and rituximab alone (12%), although more than one-third of the patients started with expectant therapy. With a median follow-up of 57 months, PFS favored R-chemotherapy or R-chemotherapy plus radiation therapy, but OS was nearly identical, all over 90%.[<a href="#cit/section_8.2">

62732</a>

6274][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6275Level of evidence C2</a>

6276] Clinical trials are required to answer questions such as the following:[<a href="#cit/section_8.3">

62773</a>

6278]</p>

6279<div class="pdq-content-list">

6280<ul id="_675">

6281<li>

6282If the PET-CT scan is clear after excisional biopsy, is watchful waiting or radiation therapy preferred?</li>

6283<li>

6284Should rituximab be added to radiation therapy for stage I follicular lymphoma?</li>

6285<li>

6286Is there any role for R-chemotherapy plus radiation therapy?</li>

6287</ul>

6288</div>

6289<section id="_326">

6290<h4 id="_326_toc">

6291Radiation therapy</h4>

6292<p id="_186" tabindex="-1">

6293 Long-term disease control within radiation fields can be achieved in a significant number of patients with indolent stage I or stage II NHL by using dosages of radiation that usually range from 25 Gy to 40 Gy to involved sites or to extended fields that cover adjacent nodal sites.[<a href="#cit/section_8.1">

62941</a>

6295,<a href="#cit/section_8.4">

62964</a>

6297-<a href="#cit/section_8.6">

62986</a>

6299] Almost half of all patients treated with radiation therapy alone will relapse out-of-field within 10 years.[<a href="#cit/section_8.1">

63001</a>

6301,<a href="#cit/section_8.6">

63026</a>

6303,<a href="#cit/section_8.7">

63047</a>

6305] </p>

6306<p id="_1226" tabindex="-1">

6307A retrospective review of 512 patients from an international consortium evaluated patients with early-stage follicular lymphoma who received at least 24 Gy of localized radiation therapy at initial presentation. With a median follow-up of 52 months, 29.1% of patients developed recurrent lymphoma at a median of 23 months (range, 1&#8722;143 months).[<a href="#cit/section_8.8">

63088</a>

6309] With a median follow-up of 33 months after relapse, the 3-year OS rate was 91.4% after patients received subsequent systemic chemotherapy that involved rituximab, usually with chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.8">

63108</a>

6311]</p>

6312<p id="_1227" tabindex="-1">

6313Very low-dose radiation therapy with 4 Gy (2 Gy &#215; 2 fractions) can result in 50% remission rates for patients who cannot tolerate higher doses.[<a href="#cit/section_8.9">

63149</a>

6315] In a multicenter, randomized, prospective trial, 548 patients with follicular or marginal zone lymphoma received radiation therapy, either 4 Gy in 2 fractions or 24 Gy in 12 fractions.[<a href="#cit/section_8.10">

631610</a>

6317] </p>

6318<div class="pdq-content-list">

6319<ul id="_1332">

6320<li>

6321At a median follow-up of 73.8 months, the 5-year local complete response rate was 89.9% (85.5%&#8211;93.1%) after 24 Gy and 70.4% (64.7%&#8211;75.4%) after 4 Gy (HR, 3.46; 95% CI, 2.25&#8211;5.33, <em>

6322P</em>

6323 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_8.10">

632410</a>

6325]</li>

6326<li>

6327Although durable local control was superior for patients who received 24 Gy in 12 fractions, the 4 Gy (2 Gy x 2 fractions) regimen was nearly comparable with less radiation exposure, less time undergoing therapy, and less cost.</li>

6328</ul>

6329</div>

6330<p id="_1333" tabindex="-1">

6331In situations in which mediastinal radiation would encompass the left side of the heart or would increase breast cancer risk in young female patients, proton therapy may be considered to reduce the radiation dose to organs at risk.[<a href="#cit/section_8.11">

633211</a>

6333]</p>

6334</section>

6335<section id="_330">

6336<h4 id="_330_toc">

6337Rituximab with or without chemotherapy</h4>

6338<p id="_232" tabindex="-1">

6339For symptomatic patients who require therapy, when radiation therapy is contraindicated, or when an alternative treatment is preferred, rituximab with or without chemotherapy can be used (as outlined below for more advanced-stage patients). The value of adjuvant treatment with radiation to decrease relapse, plus rituximab (an anti&#8211;CD20 monoclonal antibody) either alone or in combination with chemotherapy, has been extrapolated from trials of patients with advanced-stage disease and has not been confirmed.[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

634012</a>

6341,<a href="#cit/section_8.13">

634213</a>

6343]</p>

6344</section>

6345<section id="_327">

6346<h4 id="_327_toc">

6347Watchful waiting</h4>

6348<p id="_227" tabindex="-1">

6349Watchful waiting can be considered for asymptomatic patients.[<a href="#cit/section_8.14">

635014</a>

6351] Watchful waiting has never been compared with up-front radiation therapy in a prospective randomized trial; a retrospective analysis of the Surveillance, Epidemiology and End Results (SEER) Program database over 30 years showed improved outcomes for up-front radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.15">

635215</a>

6353]</p>

6354</section>

6355<section id="_328">

6356<h4 id="_328_toc">

6357Other therapies as designated for patients with advanced-stage disease</h4>

6358<p id="_230" tabindex="-1">

6359Patients with involvement that is not able to be encompassed by radiation therapy are treated as outlined for patients with stage III or stage IV low-grade lymphoma. </p>

6360</section>

6361</section>

6362<section id="_TrialSearch_183_sid_8">

6363<h3 id="_TrialSearch_183_sid_8_toc">

6364Current Clinical Trials</h3>

6365<p id="_TrialSearch_183_22" tabindex="-1">

6366Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

6367advanced clinical trial search</a>

6368 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

6369General information</a>

6370 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

6371</section>

6413[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

Blood 132 (16): 1635-1646, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=30108066&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=30108066&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6426</li>

6429[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6430</li>
