Cancer 116 (16): 3843-51, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20564102&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20564102&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6433[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6434</li>

6435</ol>

6436</div>

6437

6438 </section>

6439

6440

6441

6442 <section id="_193">

6443

6444 <h2>

6445Treatment of Indolent, Noncontiguous Stage II/III/IV NHL</h2>

6446

6447 <div id="_section_193" class="pdq-sections">

6448<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

6449<h6>

6450In This Section</h6>

6451<ul>

6452<li>

6453<a href="#_195_toc">

6454Treatment Options for Indolent, Noncontiguous Stage II/III/IV NHL<ul>

6455<li>

6456<a href="#_333_toc">

6457Watchful waiting for asymptomatic patients</a>

6458</li>

6459<li>

6460<a href="#_334_toc">

6461Rituximab alone or in combination with cytotoxic agents used in front-line therapy</a>

6462</li>

6463<li>

6464<a href="#_1183_toc">

6465Lenalidomide and rituximab</a>

6466</li>

6467<li>

6468<a href="#_1017_toc">

6469Maintenance rituximab</a>

6470</li>

6471<li>

6472<a href="#_960_toc">

6473Obinutuzumab alone or in combination with cytotoxic agents used in front-line therapy</a>

6474</li>

6475<li>

6476<a href="#_1032_toc">

6477Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor</a>

6478</li>

6479<li>

6480<a href="#_1347_toc">

6481EZH2 inhibitor</a>

6482</li>

6483<li>

6484<a href="#_339_toc">

6485Radiolabeled anti-CD20 monoclonal antibodies</a>

6486</li>

6487</ul>

6488</a>

6489</li>

6490<li>

6491<a href="#_TrialSearch_193_sid_9_toc">

6492Current Clinical Trials</a>

6493</li>

6494</ul>

6495</nav>

6496<p id="_345" tabindex="-1">

6497Optimal treatment of advanced stages of low-grade non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) is controversial because of low cure rates with the current therapeutic options. Numerous clinical trials are in progress to evaluate treatment issues, and patients are urged to participate. The rate of relapse is fairly constant over time, even in patients who have achieved complete response to treatment. Indeed, relapse may occur many years after treatment. Currently, no randomized trials provide guidance to clinicians about the initial choice of watchful waiting, rituximab, nucleoside analogues, alkylating agents, combination chemotherapy, radiolabeled monoclonal antibodies, or combinations of these options.[<a href="#cit/section_9.1">

64981</a>

6499]; [<a href="#cit/section_9.2">

65002</a>

6501][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6502Level of evidence B1</a>

6503]</p>

6504<p id="_434" tabindex="-1">

6505For patients with indolent, noncontiguous stage II and stage III NHL, central lymphatic radiation therapy has been proposed but is not usually recommended as a form of treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_9.3">

65063</a>

6507,<a href="#cit/section_9.4">

65084</a>

6509]</p>

6510<p id="_1394" tabindex="-1">

6511Patients with a resolved hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection (defined as hepatitis B surface antigen-negative but hepatitis B core antibody-positive) are at risk of reactivation of HBV and require monitoring of HBV DNA. Prophylactic nucleoside therapy lowered HBV reactivation from 10.8% to 2.1% in a retrospective study of 326 patients.[<a href="#cit/section_9.5">

65125</a>

6513]</p>

6514<section id="_195">

6515<h3 id="_195_toc">

6516Treatment Options for Indolent, Noncontiguous Stage II/III/IV NHL</h3>

6517<p id="_437" tabindex="-1">

6518Treatment options for indolent, noncontiguous stage II/III/IV NHL include the following:</p>

6519<div class="pdq-content-list">

6520<ol id="_438">

6521<li>

6522<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_333">

6523Watchful waiting for asymptomatic patients</a>

6524.</li>

6525<li>

6526<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_334">

6527Rituximab alone or in combination with cytotoxic agents used in front-line therapy</a>

6528.</li>

6529<li>

6530<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1183">

6531Lenalidomide and rituximab</a>

6532.</li>

6533<li>

6534<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1017">

6535Maintenance rituximab</a>

6536.</li>

6537<li>

6538<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_960">

6539Obinutuzumab alone or in combination with cytotoxic agents used in front-line therapy</a>

6540.</li>

6541<li>

6542<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1032">

6543Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor</a>

6544.<div class="pdq-content-list">

6545<ul id="_1289">

6546<li>

6547<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1082">

6548Copanlisib</a>

6549.</li>

6550</ul>

6551</div>

6552</li>

6553<li>

6554<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1347">

6555EZH2 inhibitor</a>

6556.<div class="pdq-content-list">

6557<ul id="_1375">

6558<li>

6559<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1348">

6560Tazemetostat</a>

6561.</li>

6562</ul>

6563</div>

6564</li>

6565<li>

6566<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_339">

6567Radiolabeled anti-CD20 monoclonal antibodies</a>

6568.</li>

6569<li>

6570Intensive therapy with chemotherapy with or without total-body irradiation or high-dose radioimmunotherapy followed by autologous or allogeneic bone marrow transplantation or peripheral stem cell transplantation (under clinical evaluation).[<a href="#cit/section_9.6">

65716</a>

6572-<a href="#cit/section_9.15">

657315</a>

6574]</li>

6575<li>

6576Phase III clinical trials comparing chemotherapy alone versus chemotherapy followed by anti-idiotype vaccine.[<a href="#cit/section_9.16">

657716</a>

6578-<a href="#cit/section_9.18">

657918</a>

6580]</li>

6581<li>

6582Extended-field radiation therapy (stage III patients only) (under clinical evaluation).[<a href="#cit/section_9.19">

658319</a>

6584]</li>

6585<li>

6586Ofatumumab&#8212;human anti&#8211;CD20 monoclonal antibody (under clinical evaluation).[<a href="#cit/section_9.20">

658720</a>

6588]</li>

6589<li>

6590Short-course low-dose, palliative radiation therapy (2 &#215; 2 Gy) (under clinical evaluation).[<a href="#cit/section_9.21">

659121</a>

6592,<a href="#cit/section_9.22">

659322</a>

6594]</li>

6595</ol>

6596</div>

6597<p id="_1486" tabindex="-1">

6598Because none of the therapies listed above are curative for advanced-stage disease, innovative approaches are under clinical evaluation.</p>

6599<section id="_333">

6600<h4 id="_333_toc">

6601Watchful waiting for asymptomatic patients</h4>

6602<p id="_439" tabindex="-1">

6603The rate of relapse is fairly constant over time, even in patients who have achieved complete responses (CR) to treatment. Indeed, relapse may occur many years after treatment. In this category, deferred treatment (i.e., watchful waiting until the patient becomes symptomatic before initiating treatment) can be considered.[<a href="#cit/section_9.2">

66042</a>

6605,<a href="#cit/section_9.23">

660623</a>

6607-<a href="#cit/section_9.25">

660825</a>

6609] The Follicular Lymphoma International Prognostic Index (FLIPI) and the revised FLIPI-2 can predict progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS), but the scores cannot be used to establish the need for therapy in asymptomatic patients.[<a href="#cit/section_9.26">

661026</a>

6611,<a href="#cit/section_9.27">

661227</a>

6613]</p>

6614<p id="_440" tabindex="-1">

6615Evidence (watchful waiting):</p>

6616<div class="pdq-content-list">

6617<ol id="_441">

6618<li>

6619Three randomized trials compared watchful waiting with immediate chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.24">

662024</a>

6621,<a href="#cit/section_9.28">

662228</a>

6623]; [<a href="#cit/section_9.29">

662429</a>

6625][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6626Level of evidence A1</a>

6627]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6628<ul id="_442">

6629<li>

6630All three trials showed no difference in cause-specific or OS.</li>

6631<li>

6632For patients randomly assigned to watchful waiting, the median time to require therapy was 2 to 3 years and one-third of patients receiving watchful waiting never required treatment with watchful waiting (half died of other causes and half remained progression free after 10 years).</li>

6633</ul>

6634</div>

6635</li>

6636<li>

6637 A selected group of 107 patients with advanced-stage follicular lymphoma were managed with initial watchful waiting; with a median delay of 55 months, subsequent therapy resulted in equivalent freedom from treatment failure and OS compared with a similar cohort treated immediately with rituximab.[<a href="#cit/section_9.30">

663830</a>

6639][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6640Level of evidence C2</a>

6641] This implies that watchful waiting remains a relevant approach even in the rituximab era.</li>

6642</ol>

6643</div>

6644</section>

6645<section id="_334">

6646<h4 id="_334_toc">

6647Rituximab alone or in combination with cytotoxic agents used in front-line therapy</h4>

6648<p id="_235" tabindex="-1">

6649 Standard therapy includes rituximab, an anti&#8211;CD20 monoclonal antibody, either alone, as was shown in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00075946">

6650ECOG-E4402</a>

6651 trial (NCT00075946),[<a href="#cit/section_9.31">

665231</a>

6653-<a href="#cit/section_9.35">

665435</a>

6655] or in combination with purine nucleoside analogues, such as fludarabine or cladribine, alkylating agents (with or without steroids), or combination chemotherapy. Rituximab may be considered as first-line therapy, either alone or in combination with other agents. Rituximab may be given intravenously or subcutaneously, and biosimilar versions, such as CT-P10 and GP2013, have shown equivalent efficacy and safety.[<a href="#cit/section_9.36">

665636</a>

6657-<a href="#cit/section_9.38">

665838</a>

6659] Combinations include the following:</p>

6660<div class="pdq-content-list">

6661<ul id="_236">

6662<li>

6663R-bendamustine: rituximab + bendamustine.[<a href="#cit/section_9.39">

666439</a>

6665-<a href="#cit/section_9.41">

666641</a>

6667]</li>

6668<li>

6669R-F: rituximab + fludarabine.[<a href="#cit/section_9.42">

667042</a>

6671]</li>

6672<li>

6673R-CVP: rituximab + cyclophosphamide + vincristine + prednisone.[<a href="#cit/section_9.43">

667443</a>

6675-<a href="#cit/section_9.46">

667646</a>

6677]</li>

6678<li>

6679R-CHOP: rituximab + cyclophosphamide + doxorubicin + vincristine + prednisone.[<a href="#cit/section_9.45">

668045</a>

6681-<a href="#cit/section_9.49">

668249</a>

6683] A Cochrane meta-analysis could not identify any OS benefit of adding doxorubicin to chemotherapy regimens with rituximab or to chemotherapy regimens without rituximab.[<a href="#cit/section_9.50">

668450</a>

6685][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6686Level of evidence A1</a>

6687]</li>

6688<li>

6689R-FM: rituximab + fludarabine + mitoxantrone.[<a href="#cit/section_9.45">

669045</a>

6691,<a href="#cit/section_9.46">

669246</a>

6693,<a href="#cit/section_9.51">

669451</a>

6695]</li>

6696<li>

6697R-FCM: rituximab + fludarabine + cyclophosphamide + mitoxantrone.[<a href="#cit/section_9.52">

669852</a>

6699]</li>

6700</ul>

6701</div>

6702<p id="_1099" tabindex="-1">

6703Evidence (rituximab with or without chemotherapy):</p>

6704<div class="pdq-content-list">

6705<ol id="_1100">

6706<li>

6707A prospective, randomized trial of 534 patients with previously untreated, advanced-stage follicular lymphoma compared R-CHOP, R-FM, and R-CVP.[<a href="#cit/section_9.45">

670845</a>

6709] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6710<ul id="_1101">

6711<li>

6712With a median follow-up of 84 months, there was no difference in OS (8-year OS rate, 83%; 95% confidence interval (CI), 79%&#8211;87%), but the 8-year PFS rates favored R-CHOP (52%) and R-FM (49%) over R-CVP (42%) (<em>

6713P</em>

6714 for the three regimens = .037).[<a href="#cit/section_9.45">

671545</a>

6716][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6717Level of evidence B1</a>

6718]</li>

6719</ul>

6720</div>

6721</li>

6722<li>

6723Four randomized prospective studies of previously untreated patients (involving more than 1,300 patients) and one Cochrane meta-analysis that included both untreated and previously treated patients (involving almost 1,000 patients) have compared rituximab plus combination chemotherapy with chemotherapy alone.[<a href="#cit/section_9.44">

672444</a>

6725,<a href="#cit/section_9.49">

672649</a>

6727,<a href="#cit/section_9.53">

672853</a>

6729]; [<a href="#cit/section_9.54">

673054</a>

6731,<a href="#cit/section_9.55">

673255</a>

6733][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6734Level of evidence A1</a>

6735]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6736<ul id="_1102">

6737<li>

6738Rituximab plus chemotherapy was superior in terms of event-free survival (EFS) or PFS (ranging from 2&#8211;3 years) in all of the studies and in terms of OS in all but one study (absolute benefit ranging from 6%&#8211;13% at 4 years, <em>

6739P</em>

6740 &lt; .04 and hazard ratio [HR] = 0.63 [0.51&#8211;0.79] for the meta-analysis).</li>

6741<li>

6742All of these trials were performed in symptomatic patients who required therapy. These results do not negate watchful waiting when appropriate.</li>

6743<li>

6744Fluorine F 18-fludeoxyglucose positron emission tomography&#8211;computed tomography (18F-FDG PET-CT) scan status at the completion of rituximab plus chemotherapy induction therapy is strongly predictive of outcome. It is not yet known whether acting on the results of the scans translates into better outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_9.56">

674556</a>

6746,<a href="#cit/section_9.57">

674757</a>

6748]</li>

6749</ul>

6750</div>

6751</li>

6752<li>

6753In a prospective randomized trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00991211">

6754NCT00991211</a>

6755), 527 patients with indolent and mantle cell lymphoma were randomly assigned to a bendamustine-and-rituximab arm versus an R-CHOP arm.[<a href="#cit/section_9.40">

675640</a>

6757][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6758Level of evidence B1</a>

6759]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6760<ul id="_1103">

6761<li>

6762With a median follow-up of 45 months, the median PFS favored the bendamustine arm (69 months vs. 31 months [HR, 0.58; 95% CI, 0.44&#8211;0.74; <em>

6763P</em>

6764 &lt; .0001]) but with no difference in OS.</li>

6765<li>

6766The bendamustine arm was associated with significantly lower rates of alopecia, hematologic toxicity, stomatitis, peripheral neuropathy, and infections than was the R-CHOP arm.</li>

6767</ul>

6768</div>

6769</li>

6770<li>

6771In a similar prospective randomized trial, 447 patients with indolent and mantle cell lymphoma were assigned to bendamustine and rituximab versus R-CHOP or R-CVP.[<a href="#cit/section_9.41">

677241</a>

6773][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6774Level of evidence B1</a>

6775]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6776<ul id="_1162">

6777<li>

6778With a median follow-up of 65 months, the 5-year PFS rate favored bendamustine and rituximab, 65.5% versus 55.8% (HR, 0.61; 95% CI, 0.45&#8211;0.85; <em>

6779P</em>

6780 = .0025), but with no difference in OS.</li>

6781<li>

6782Increased deaths in the bendamustine-and-rituximab arm from cardiovascular causes (seven versus one) and from secondary malignancies other than lymphoma (five versus three) may have contributed to the lack of OS advantage.</li>

6783</ul>

6784</div>

6785</li>

6786</ol>

6787</div>

6788</section>

6789<section id="_1183">

6790<h4 id="_1183_toc">

6791Lenalidomide and rituximab</h4>

6792<p id="_1184" tabindex="-1">

6793The combination of the immunomodulating agent lenalidomide with rituximab (the so-called <em>

6794R<span class="sup">

67952</span>

6796 regimen</em>

6797) has been proposed as an alternative regimen to combinations involving cytotoxic agents and their subsequent short- and long-term toxicities.</p>

6798<p id="_1185" tabindex="-1">

6799Evidence (lenalidomide and rituximab):</p>

6800<div class="pdq-content-list">

6801<ol id="_1186">

6802<li>

6803In a randomized prospective trial (RELEVANCE) of 1,030 patients with previously untreated follicular lymphoma, rituximab plus lenalidomide for 18 months was compared with rituximab plus chemotherapy (usually R-CHOP).[<a href="#cit/section_9.58">

680458</a>

6805,<a href="#cit/section_9.59">

680659</a>

6807] All patients received rituximab maintenance for up to 2 years. <div class="pdq-content-list">

6808<ul id="_1187">

6809<li>

6810With a median follow-up of 72 months, the 6-year PFS (60% and 59%) and 3-year OS (89%) were identical (HR, 1.03; 95% CI, 0.84&#8211;1.27; <em>

6811P</em>

6812 = .78 for PFS) (HR for OS was not reported).[<a href="#cit/section_9.58">

681358</a>

6814,<a href="#cit/section_9.59">

681559</a>

6816][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6817Level of evidence A1</a>

6818]</li>

6819<li>

6820This trial established that the R<span class="sup">

68212</span>

6822 regimen is as effective as rituximab plus cytotoxic chemotherapy options. The transformation rate to aggressive lymphoma per year was 0.68% in the R<span class="sup">

68232</span>

6824 group and 0.45% in the R-chemotherapy group. With a median follow-up of 72 months, there were no new safety signals.[<a href="#cit/section_9.59">

682559</a>

6826]</li>

6827</ul>

6828</div>

6829</li>

6830<li>

6831In a randomized prospective trial of 358 patients with resistant/refractory indolent lymphoma (usually follicular lymphoma), the R<span class="sup">

68322</span>

6833 regimen was compared with rituximab alone.[<a href="#cit/section_9.60">

683460</a>

6835] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6836<ul id="_1189">

6837<li>

6838With a median follow-up of 28 months, the median PFS was 39.4 months for R<span class="sup">

68392</span>

6840 and 14.1 months for rituximab alone (<em>

6841P</em>

6842 &lt; .0001), with no difference in OS.[<a href="#cit/section_9.60">

684360</a>

6844][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6845Level of evidence B1</a>

6846]</li>

6847</ul>

6848</div>

6849</li>

6850</ol>

6851</div>

6852</section>

6853<section id="_1017">

6854<h4 id="_1017_toc">

6855Maintenance rituximab</h4>

6856<p id="_1018" tabindex="-1">

6857After induction therapy with rituximab only or with rituximab plus chemotherapy, rituximab can be used once every 2 to 3 months. Several studies have evaluated this approach.</p>

6858<p id="_1019" tabindex="-1">

6859Evidence (maintenance rituximab <strong>

6860for previously untreated patients</strong>

6861):</p>

6862<div class="pdq-content-list">

6863<ol id="_1020">

6864<li>

6865In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00140582">

6866PRIMA</a>

6867 study (NCT00140582), 1,018 high-risk, previously untreated, symptomatic patients achieved CR or partial response (PR) after induction therapy with immunochemotherapy (usually R-CHOP) and were then randomly assigned to 2 years of maintenance rituximab versus no maintenance.[<a href="#cit/section_9.61">

686861</a>

6869][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6870Level of evidence B1</a>

6871] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6872<ul id="_1021">

6873<li>

6874With a median follow-up of 9.0 years, median PFS favored rituximab maintenance (10.5 years) compared with observation (4.1 years) (HR, 0.61; 95% CI, 0.52&#8722;0.73; <em>

6875P</em>

6876 &lt; .001), but with no difference in OS.</li>

6877</ul>

6878</div>

6879</li>

6880<li>

6881In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00112931">

6882United Kingdom/International Study</a>

6883 (NCT00112931), 379 previously untreated patients with asymptomatic, low-burden disease were randomly assigned to watchful waiting versus rituximab induction only versus rituximab induction followed by 2 years of rituximab maintenance.[<a href="#cit/section_9.62">

688462</a>

6885][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6886Level of evidence A3</a>

6887]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6888<ul id="_1022">

6889<li>

6890Although OS and histological transformation rates were no different at 3 years, maintenance rituximab was favored based on quality-of-life (QOL) studies (Mental Adjustment to Cancer Scale <em>

6891P</em>

6892 = .0004 at 7 months; Illness Coping Score <em>

6893P</em>

6894 = .0012 at 7 months) and time-to-initiation of new treatment by 3 years (54% for watchful waiting vs. 12% for rituximab maintenance [HR, 0.21; 95% CI, 0.14&#8211;0.31; <em>

6895P</em>

6896 &lt; .0001]).[<a href="#cit/section_9.62">

689762</a>

6898][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6899Level of evidence A3</a>

6900]</li>

6901<li>

6902This study suggested that for some patients, <em>

6903watch and wait</em>

6904 resulted in <em>

6905watch and worry</em>

6906.[<a href="#cit/section_9.63">

690763</a>

6908] However, from the perspective of OS and histological transformation rates, no benefit could be seen with rituximab maintenance.</li>

6909</ul>

6910</div>

6911</li>

6912<li>

6913In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00075946">

6914RESORT</a>

6915 study (NCT00075946), 289 previously untreated patients with asymptomatic, low-burden disease were randomly assigned to rituximab induction alone, with a re-treatment strategy that used rituximab at relapse, or rituximab induction plus maintenance rituximab every 13 weeks until treatment failure.[<a href="#cit/section_9.34">

691634</a>

6917][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6918Level of evidence A3</a>

6919]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6920<ul id="_1023">

6921<li>

6922With a median follow-up of 4.5 years, there was no difference in median time-to-treatment failure (defined as failing rituximab alone) or in health-related QOL. A re-treatment strategy achieved comparable disease control using significantly fewer doses of rituximab.</li>

6923</ul>

6924</div>

6925<p id="_1024" tabindex="-1">

6926These three randomized trials in previously untreated patients show no advantage for the use of rituximab maintenance versus observation and reinduction of therapy at the time of relapse. The trials suggest a benefit for maintenance rituximab after reinduction for relapsed disease. Many questions remain about rituximab maintenance, particularly about truncating therapy at 2 years and long-term safety and efficacy. A trial extending rituximab maintenance to 5 years showed similar EFS or OS versus 1 year of maintenance after induction therapy with rituximab in previously untreated patients.[<a href="#cit/section_9.64">

692764</a>

6928][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6929Level of evidence A1</a>

6930]</p>

6931</li>

6932<li>

6933The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02063685">

6934FOLL12</a>

6935 study (NCT02063685) included 807 patients with previously untreated high-tumor burden follicular lymphoma. Patients received rituximab plus chemotherapy induction and were randomly assigned to either standard rituximab maintenance (every 8 weeks for 2 years) or to postinduction treatment (monitoring, rituximab maintenance, or radioimmunotherapy) based on their complete metabolic response and measurable residual disease&#8211;negative status.[<a href="#cit/section_9.65">

693665</a>

6937]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6938<ul id="_1473">

6939<li>

6940With a median follow-up of 53 months, the 3-year PFS rate was 86% for patients who received standard maintenance and 72% for patients who received response-based treatment (<em>

6941P</em>

6942 &lt; .001). The 3-year OS was the same in both groups (98% vs. 97%; <em>

6943P</em>

6944 = .238).[<a href="#cit/section_9.65">

694565</a>

6946][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6947Level of evidence B1</a>

6948]</li>

6949<li>

6950This trial does not support the use of an end-of-treatment PET-CT scan to guide the use of maintenance rituximab.</li>

6951</ul>

6952</div>

6953</li>

6954</ol>

6955</div>

6956<p id="_1026" tabindex="-1">

6957For previously untreated patients, all of the studies showed improvement of PFS, with no change in OS.</p>

6958<p id="_1027" tabindex="-1">

6959Evidence (maintenance rituximab <strong>

6960for previously treated patients</strong>

6961):</p>

6962<div class="pdq-content-list">

6963<ol id="_1028">

6964<li>

6965In a prospective randomized trial of 465 patients with relapsed follicular lymphoma, responders to R-CHOP or CHOP were further randomly assigned to receive rituximab maintenance (1 dose every 3 months for 2 years) or no maintenance.[<a href="#cit/section_9.66">

696666</a>

6967][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6968Level of evidence B1</a>

6969]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6970<ul id="_1029">

6971<li>

6972At a median follow-up of 6 years, rituximab maintenance was better for median PFS (44 months vs. 16 months, <em>

6973P</em>

6974 &lt; .001) and borderline for 5-year OS (74% vs. 64%, <em>

6975P</em>

6976 = .07).</li>

6977<li>

6978This benefit for maintenance was evident even for patients who received rituximab during induction therapy. Most patients in both arms received extensive rituximab during postprotocol salvage treatment.

6979

6980</li>

6981</ul>

6982</div>

6983</li>

6984<li>

6985 In a prospective randomized trial of 280 patients with relapsed follicular lymphoma, responders to chemotherapy and autologous stem cell transplantation consolidation were randomly assigned to receive four doses of rituximab maintenance or no maintenance.[<a href="#cit/section_9.67">

698667</a>

6987][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6988Level of evidence B1</a>

6989]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6990<ul id="_1030">

6991<li>

6992With an 8.3-year median follow-up, the 10-year PFS rates favored maintenance (54% vs. 37% [HR, 0.66; 95% CI, 0.47&#8211;0.91; <em>

6993P</em>

6994 = .012]), but there was no difference in OS.</li>

6995</ul>

6996</div>

6997</li>

6998<li>

6999A meta-analysis of nine randomized clinical trials with a total of 2,586 patients with follicular lymphoma, most of whom had relapsed disease, compared rituximab maintenance with no maintenance and showed improved OS for rituximab maintenance in previously treated patients (HR<sub>

7000death</sub>

7001, 0.72; 95% CI, 0.57&#8211;0.91).[<a href="#cit/section_9.68">

700268</a>

7003][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7004Level of evidence A1</a>

7005]</li>

7006</ol>

7007</div>

7008<p id="_1031" tabindex="-1">

7009For previously treated patients, there is more evidence to suggest an OS advantage with the use of rituximab maintenance.</p>

7010</section>

7011<section id="_960">

7012<h4 id="_960_toc">

7013Obinutuzumab alone or in combination with cytotoxic agents used in front-line therapy</h4>

7014<p id="_961" tabindex="-1">

7015Obinutuzumab is a glycoengineered type II anti&#8211;CD20 monoclonal antibody with greater antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity than rituximab.</p>

7016<p id="_1111" tabindex="-1">

7017Evidence (obinutuzumab):</p>

7018<div class="pdq-content-list">

7019<ol id="_962">

7020<li>

7021A prospective randomized trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01332968">

7022NCT01332968</a>

7023) of 1,202 patients with previously untreated follicular lymphoma compared obinutuzumab combined with bendamustine (50%), cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone (CHOP) (33%), or cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and prednisone (CVP) (10%) with rituximab combined with the same chemotherapy regimens (based on investigator choice).[<a href="#cit/section_9.69">

702469</a>

7025] After six cycles of combination therapy, patients had 2 years of maintenance therapy, receiving the same antibody every 2 months.<div class="pdq-content-list">

7026<ul id="_973">

7027<li>

7028With a median follow-up of 34.5 months, the 3-year PFS rate was 80% in the obinutuzumab group and 73.3% in the rituximab group (HR, 0.66; 95% CI, 0.51&#8211;0.85, <em>

7029P</em>

7030 = .001).[<a href="#cit/section_9.69">

703169</a>

7032][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7033Level of evidence B1</a>

7034]</li>

7035<li>

7036There was no difference in OS.</li>

7037<li>

7038There was a high rate of toxic deaths among patients using bendamustine in the obinutuzumab arm (5.6%) and in the rituximab arm (4.4%) compared with what has been seen historically. For patients with indolent low-grade lymphoma, with median survivals exceeding 15 years, the number of toxic deaths during first-line therapy seems excessive. By comparison, the toxic death rate was 1% to 2% when either antibody was combined with CHOP or CVP.</li>

7039</ul>

7040</div>

7041<p id="_964" tabindex="-1">

7042Several issues have been raised about this study:</p>

7043<div class="pdq-content-list">

7044<ul id="_965">

7045<li>

7046The side effects were significantly higher with obinutuzumab in terms of infusion reactions and subsequent adverse events.</li>

7047<li>

7048Obinutuzumab costs significantly more than rituximab.</li>

7049</ul>

7050</div>

7051<p id="_966" tabindex="-1">

7052In summary, in the absence of any change in OS, switching from rituximab to obinutuzumab in combination with chemotherapy for previously untreated follicular lymphoma is a difficult choice. The PFS differences may be attributable to the imbalance in monoclonal antibody dosing, and the increased side effects and costs are mitigating factors. In this trial, bendamustine combined with either antibody led to unacceptable rates of toxic death.</p>

7053</li>

7054</ol>

7055</div>

7056</section>

7057<section id="_1032">

7058<h4 id="_1032_toc">

7059Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor</h4>

7060<section id="_1082">

7061<h5 id="_1082_toc">

7062Copanlisib</h5>

7063<p id="_1112" tabindex="-1">

7064Evidence (copanlisib):</p>

7065<div class="pdq-content-list">

7066<ol id="_1113">

7067<li>

7068A double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled study assigned 307 patients with recurrent indolent lymphoma to copanlisib plus rituximab and 151 patients to placebo plus rituximab (2:1 randomization).[<a href="#cit/section_9.70">

706970</a>

7070]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7071<ul id="_1334">

7072<li>

7073With a median follow-up of 19.2 months, the median PFS was 21.5 months for patients in the copanlisib-plus-rituximab arm (95% CI, 17.8&#8211;33.0) versus 13.8 months (95% CI, 10.2&#8211;17.5) for patients in the placebo-plus-rituximab arm (HR, 0.52; 95% CI, 0.39&#8211;0.69; <em>

7074P</em>

7075 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_9.70">

707670</a>

7077][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7078Level of evidence B1</a>

7079]</li>

7080<li>

7081Hyperglycemia and hypertension were the most common grade 3 to 4 adverse events, occurring in half of the patients who received copanlisib.</li>

7082</ul>

7083</div>

7084</li>

7085</ol>

7086</div>

7087</section>

7088<p id="_1038" tabindex="-1">

7089The PI3K inhibitors have significant adverse effects, including pneumonitis, colitis, transaminitis, hypertension, hyperglycemia, rash, and increased risk of infections. These adverse events have affected the use of these agents until confirmatory trial results can establish their efficacy and safety.[<a href="#cit/section_9.71">

709071</a>

7091] They are currently approved for treatment of relapsed and refractory follicular lymphoma after two previously received lines of therapy.</p>

7092</section>

7093<section id="_1347">

7094<h4 id="_1347_toc">

7095EZH2 inhibitor</h4>

7096<section id="_1348">

7097<h5 id="_1348_toc">

7098Tazemetostat</h5>

7099<p id="_1349" tabindex="-1">

7100Tazemetostat is an inhibitor of EZH2, a histone methyltransferase essential to the formation of lymph node germinal centers, especially with activating mutations of <em class="gene-name">

7101EZH2</em>

7102.</p>

7103<p id="_1350" tabindex="-1">

7104Evidence (tazemetostat):</p>

7105<div class="pdq-content-list">

7106<ol id="_1351">

7107<li>

7108A phase II study included 99 patients with relapsed or refractory follicular lymphoma, 45 of whom had activating mutations of <em class="gene-name">

7109EZH2</em>

7110, and 54 of whom had normal wild-type <em class="gene-name">

7111EZH2</em>

7112.[<a href="#cit/section_9.72">

711372</a>

7114]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7115<ul id="_1352">

7116<li>

7117Treatment with tazemetostat resulted in an objective response rate of 69% (95% CI, 53%&#8211;82%) for patients with activating mutations versus 35% (95% CI, 23%&#8211;49%) for patients with wild-type <em class="gene-name">

7118EZH2</em>

7119.[<a href="#cit/section_9.72">

712072</a>

7121]</li>

7122<li>

7123With a median follow-up of 22 months, the median PFS was 13.8 months (95% CI, 10.7&#8211;22.0) for patients with activating mutations and 11.1 months (95% CI, 3.7&#8211;14.6) for patients with wild-type <em class="gene-name">

7124EZH2</em>

7125.[<a href="#cit/section_9.72">

712672</a>

7127][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7128Level of evidence C3</a>

7129]</li>

7130<li>

7131Grade 3 or 4 treatment-related adverse events were seen in 4% of patients.</li>

7132</ul>

7133</div>

7134</li>

7135</ol>

7136</div>

7137</section>

7138</section>

7139<section id="_339">

7140<h4 id="_339_toc">

7141Radiolabeled anti-CD20 monoclonal antibodies</h4>

7142<p id="_243" tabindex="-1">

7143Yttrium Y 90 (90Y)-ibritumomab tiuxetan (Zevalin) is available for previously untreated and relapsing patients with minimal (&lt;25%) or no marrow involvement with lymphoma (iodine I 131 [131I]-tositumomab [Bexxar] is no longer available because of commercial disengagement).[<a href="#cit/section_9.73">

714473</a>

7145,<a href="#cit/section_9.74">

714674</a>

7147] </p>

7148<p id="_1106" tabindex="-1">

7149Evidence (radiolabeled anti-CD20 monoclonal antibodies):</p>

7150<div class="pdq-content-list">

7151<ol id="_1107">

7152<li>

7153In a randomized, prospective trial, 554 patients with previously untreated advanced-stage follicular lymphoma received either R-CHOP times six cycles or CHOP times six cycles followed by 131I-tositumomab radioimmunotherapy (RIT).[<a href="#cit/section_9.75">

715475</a>

7155] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7156<ul id="_1108">

7157<li>

7158With a median follow-up of 10.3 years, there was improvement in PFS for RIT (56% vs. 42%, <em>

7159P</em>

7160 = .01) but no significant difference in 10-year OS (OS R-CHOP, 81%; CHOP-RIT, 75%; <em>

7161P </em>

7162 = 0.13).[<a href="#cit/section_9.75">

716375</a>

7164][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7165Level of evidence B1</a>

7166] </li>

7167<li>

7168In this trial, the cumulative incidence of death from myelodysplastic syndrome or acute myeloid leukemia is higher for the RIT arm (4% vs. 1%, <em>

7169P</em>

7170 = .02). </li>

7171</ul>

7172</div>

7173<p id="_1109" tabindex="-1">

7174131I-tositumomab became commercially unavailable in 2013.</p>

7175</li>

7176<li>

7177In a randomized trial of 409 patients with stage III or IV follicular lymphoma who achieved a CR or PR, 90Y-ibritumomab tiuxetan consolidation versus no consolidation was evaluated.[<a href="#cit/section_9.76">

717876</a>

7179] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7180<ul id="_1110">

7181<li>

7182The radiolabeled antibody consolidation improved median PFS by 3 years (<em>

7183P</em>

7184 &lt; .001), and median time to next treatment was improved by 5.1 years (<em>

7185P</em>

7186 &lt; .001); however, there was no change in OS.[<a href="#cit/section_9.76">

718776</a>

7188][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7189Level of evidence B1</a>

7190]</li>

7191</ul>

7192</div>

7193</li>

7194</ol>

7195</div>

7196<p id="_1078" tabindex="-1">

7197Durable responses to radiolabeled monoclonal antibodies, such as 90Y-ibritumomab tiuxetan (commercially available) and iodine I 131-tositumomab (commercially unavailable), have also been reported before and after cytotoxic chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.75">

719875</a>

7199,<a href="#cit/section_9.77">

720077</a>

7201,<a href="#cit/section_9.78">

720278</a>

7203][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7204Level of evidence B1</a>

7205]

7206

7207However, the cumulative incidence of death resulting from myelodysplastic syndrome or acute myeloid leukemia is higher (4% vs. 1%; <em>

7208P</em>

7209 = .02) in one of the randomized trials versus nonradiolabeled antibody with chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.75">

721075</a>

7211]</p>

7212</section>

7213</section>

7214<section id="_TrialSearch_193_sid_9">

7215<h3 id="_TrialSearch_193_sid_9_toc">

7216Current Clinical Trials</h3>

7217<p id="_TrialSearch_193_22" tabindex="-1">

7218Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

7219advanced clinical trial search</a>

7220 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

7221General information</a>

7222 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

7223</section>

7342Solal-C&#233;ligny P, Bellei M, Marcheselli L, et al.: Watchful waiting in low-tumor burden follicular lymphoma in the rituximab era: results of an F2-study database. J Clin Oncol 30 (31): 3848-53, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23008294&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23008294&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7343[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

N Engl J Med 377 (14): 1331-1344, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28976863&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28976863&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7495[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7496</li>

7497<li id="section_9.70">

7498Matasar MJ, Capra M, &#214;zcan M, et al.: Copanlisib plus rituximab versus placebo plus rituximab in patients with relapsed indolent non-Hodgkin lymphoma (CHRONOS-3): a double-blind, randomised, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial. Lancet Oncol 22 (5): 678-689, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33848462&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33848462&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7499[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7500</li>

7501<li id="section_9.71">

7502Richardson NC, Kasamon Y, Pazdur R, et al.: The saga of PI3K inhibitors in haematological malignancies: survival is the ultimate safety endpoint. Lancet Oncol 23 (5): 563-566, 2022.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35429996&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35429996&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7503[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7504</li>

7505<li id="section_9.72">

7506Morschhauser F, Tilly H, Chaidos A, et al.: Tazemetostat for patients with relapsed or refractory follicular lymphoma: an open-label, single-arm, multicentre, phase 2 trial. Lancet Oncol 21 (11): 1433-1442, 2020.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33035457&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33035457&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7507[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7508</li>

7509<li id="section_9.73">

7510Press OW, Unger JM, Braziel RM, et al.: Phase II trial of CHOP chemotherapy followed by tositumomab/iodine I-131 tositumomab for previously untreated follicular non-Hodgkin's lymphoma: five-year follow-up of Southwest Oncology Group Protocol S9911. J Clin Oncol 24 (25): 4143-9, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16896003&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16896003&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7511[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7512</li>

7513<li id="section_9.74">

7514Scholz CW, Pinto A, Linkesch W, et al.: (90)Yttrium-ibritumomab-tiuxetan as first-line treatment for follicular lymphoma: 30 months of follow-up data from an international multicenter phase II clinical trial. J Clin Oncol 31 (3): 308-13, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23233718&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23233718&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7515[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7516</li>

7517<li id="section_9.75">

7518Shadman M, Li H, Rimsza L, et al.: Continued Excellent Outcomes in Previously Untreated Patients With Follicular Lymphoma After Treatment With CHOP Plus Rituximab or CHOP Plus 131I-Tositumomab: Long-Term Follow-Up of Phase III Randomized Study SWOG-S0016. J Clin Oncol 36 (7): 697-703, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29356608&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29356608&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7519[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7520</li>

7521<li id="section_9.76">

7522Morschhauser F, Radford J, Van Hoof A, et al.: 90Yttrium-ibritumomab tiuxetan consolidation of first remission in advanced-stage follicular non-Hodgkin lymphoma: updated results after a median follow-up of 7.3 years from the International, Randomized, Phase III First-LineIndolent trial. J Clin Oncol 31 (16): 1977-83, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23547079&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23547079&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7523[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7524</li>

7525<li id="section_9.77">

7526Fisher RI, Kaminski MS, Wahl RL, et al.: Tositumomab and iodine-131 tositumomab produces durable complete remissions in a subset of heavily pretreated patients with low-grade and transformed non-Hodgkin's lymphomas. J Clin Oncol 23 (30): 7565-73, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16186600&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16186600&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7527[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7528</li>

7529<li id="section_9.78">

7530Leahy MF, Seymour JF, Hicks RJ, et al.: Multicenter phase II clinical study of iodine-131-rituximab radioimmunotherapy in relapsed or refractory indolent non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. J Clin Oncol 24 (27): 4418-25, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16940276&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16940276&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7531[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7532</li>

7533</ol>

7534</div>

7535

7536 </section>

7537

7538

7539

7540 <section id="_212">

7541

7542 <h2>

7543Treatment of Indolent, Recurrent NHL</h2>

7544

7545 <div id="_section_212" class="pdq-sections">

7546<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

7547<h6>

7548In This Section</h6>

7549<ul>

7550<li>

7551<a href="#_215_toc">

7552Treatment Options for Indolent, Recurrent NHL<ul>

7553<li>

7554<a href="#_349_toc">

7555Rituximab alone or in combination with cytotoxic agents used in front-line therapy</a>

7556</li>

7557<li>

7558<a href="#_892_toc">

7559Obinutuzumab alone or in combination with cytotoxic agents used in front-line therapy</a>

7560</li>

7561<li>

7562<a href="#_351_toc">

7563Lenalidomide and rituximab</a>

7564</li>

7565<li>

7566<a href="#_1313_toc">

7567Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor</a>

7568</li>

7569<li>

7570<a href="#_1353_toc">

7571EZH2 inhibitor</a>

7572</li>

7573<li>

7574<a href="#_356_toc">

7575Palliative radiation therapy</a>

7576</li>

7577<li>

7578<a href="#_348_toc">

7579Chemotherapy (single agent or combination)</a>

7580</li>

7581<li>

7582<a href="#_352_toc">

7583Radiolabeled anti-CD20 monoclonal antibodies</a>

7584</li>

7585<li>

7586<a href="#_1395_toc">

7587Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy</a>

7588</li>

7589<li>

7590<a href="#_1479_toc">

7591Bispecific T-cell engagers</a>

7592</li>

7593<li>

7594<a href="#_1401_toc">

7595Stem cell transplantation</a>

7596</li>

7597</ul>

7598</a>

7599</li>

7600<li>

7601<a href="#_TrialSearch_212_sid_10_toc">

7602Current Clinical Trials</a>

7603</li>

7604</ul>

7605</nav>

7606<p id="_213" tabindex="-1">

7607In general, treatment with standard agents rarely produces a cure in patients whose disease has relapsed. Sustained remissions after relapse can often be obtained in patients with indolent lymphomas, but relapse will usually ensue. Favorable survival after relapse has been associated with an age younger than 60 years, complete remission rather than partial remission, and duration of response longer than 2 years.[<a href="#cit/section_10.1">

76081</a>

7609] Even the most favorable subset, however, has a tenfold greater mortality compared with age-adjusted U.S. population rates.[<a href="#cit/section_10.2">

76102</a>

7611] </p>

7612<p id="_750" tabindex="-1">

7613Patients who experience a relapse with indolent lymphoma can often have their disease controlled with single agent or combination chemotherapy, rituximab (an anti&#8211;CD20 monoclonal antibody), lenalidomide, radiolabeled anti&#8211;CD20 monoclonal antibodies, or palliative radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.3">

76143</a>

7615,<a href="#cit/section_10.4">

76164</a>

7617] Long-term freedom from second relapse, however, is uncommon and multiple relapses will usually occur. Patients with indolent lymphoma may experience a relapse with a more aggressive histology. If the clinical pattern of relapse suggests that the disease is behaving in a more aggressive manner, a biopsy can be performed. Documentation of conversion to a more aggressive histology requires an appropriate change to therapy applicable to that histological type.[<a href="#cit/section_10.5">

76185</a>

7619] Rapid growth or discordant growth between various disease sites may indicate a histological conversion.</p>

7620<p id="_451" tabindex="-1">

7621In a retrospective review of 325 patients between 1972 and 1999, the risk of histological transformation was 30% by 10 years from diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_10.6">

76226</a>

7623] In this series, high-risk factors for subsequent histological transformation were advanced stage, high-risk Follicular Lymphoma International Prognostic Index, and expectant management. The median survival after transformation was 1 to 2 years, with 25% of patients alive at 5 years and with approximately 10% to 20% of patients alive 10 years after re-treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_10.7">

76247</a>

7625]</p>

7626<p id="_695" tabindex="-1">

7627A prospective trial of 631 patients with follicular lymphoma and with a median follow-up of 60 months in the rituximab era (2002&#8211;2009) found a 5-year transformation rate (11%) to a higher-grade histology.[<a href="#cit/section_10.8">

76288</a>

7629] The median overall survival (OS) after transformation was 50 months, and the 5-year OS rate was 66%, if the transformation occurred more than 18 months after a diagnosis of follicular lymphoma. This series describes a better prognosis for patients with transformation than was experienced by patients in the prerituximab era.</p>

7630<p id="_452" tabindex="-1">

7631For descriptions of the regimens used to treat histological conversions, see the <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1228">

7632Treatment of Aggressive, Recurrent NHL</a>

7633 section. The durability of the second remission may be short, and clinical trials can be considered.</p>

7634<section id="_215">

7635<h3 id="_215_toc">

7636Treatment Options for Indolent, Recurrent NHL</h3>

7637<p id="_453" tabindex="-1">

7638Treatment options for indolent, recurrent non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) include the following:</p>

7639<div class="pdq-content-list">

7640<ol id="_497">

7641<li>

7642<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_349">

7643Rituximab alone or in combination with cytotoxic agents used in front-line therapy</a>

7644.</li>

7645<li>

7646<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_892">

7647Obinutuzumab alone or in combination with cytotoxic agents used in front-line therapy</a>

7648.</li>

7649<li>

7650<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_351">

7651Lenalidomide and rituximab</a>

7652.</li>

7653<li>

7654<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1313">

7655Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor</a>

7656.<div class="pdq-content-list">

7657<ul id="_1282">

7658<li>

7659<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1314">

7660Copanlisib</a>

7661.</li>

7662</ul>

7663</div>

7664</li>

7665<li>

7666<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1353">

7667EZH2 inhibitor</a>

7668.<div class="pdq-content-list">

7669<ul id="_1376">

7670<li>

7671<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1354">

7672Tazemetostat</a>

7673.</li>

7674</ul>

7675</div>

7676</li>

7677<li>

7678<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_356">

7679Palliative radiation therapy</a>

7680.</li>

7681<li>

7682<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_348">

7683Chemotherapy (single agent or combination)</a>

7684.</li>

7685<li>

7686<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_352">

7687Radiolabeled anti-CD20 monoclonal antibodies</a>

7688.</li>

7689<li>

7690<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1395">

7691Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy</a>

7692.</li>

7693<li>

7694<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1479">

7695Bispecific T-cell engagers</a>

7696.</li>

7697<li>

7698<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1401">

7699Stem cell transplantation (SCT)</a>

7700.</li>

7701</ol>

7702</div>

7703<section id="_349">

7704<h4 id="_349_toc">

7705Rituximab alone or in combination with cytotoxic agents used in front-line therapy</h4>

7706<p id="_217" tabindex="-1">

7707 Rituximab results in a 40% to 50% response rate in patients who relapse with indolent B-cell lymphomas.[<a href="#cit/section_10.9">

77089</a>

7709-<a href="#cit/section_10.13">

771013</a>

7711] Rituximab can also be combined with combination chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.14">

771214</a>

7713,<a href="#cit/section_10.15">

771415</a>

7715]</p>

7716<p id="_455" tabindex="-1">

7717Evidence (rituximab):</p>

7718<div class="pdq-content-list">

7719<ol id="_1126">

7720<li>

7721In three randomized, prospective studies involving previously treated patients with relapsed indolent lymphoma, patients were randomly assigned to rituximab maintenance after re-treatment with combination chemotherapy (with or without rituximab during induction) or rituximab alone.[<a href="#cit/section_10.16">

772216</a>

7723-<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

772418</a>

7725]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7726<ul id="_1127">

7727<li>

7728 All trials showed prolongation of response duration,[<a href="#cit/section_10.16">

772916</a>

7730-<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

773118</a>

7732] and one trial demonstrated improvement in median progression-free survival (PFS) (3.7 years vs. 1.3 years, <em>

7733P</em>

7734 &lt; .001) and OS rate (74% vs. 64%, <em>

7735P</em>

7736 = .07) at 5 years with a median follow-up of 39 months favoring maintenance rituximab.[<a href="#cit/section_10.17">

773717</a>

7738]</li>

7739</ul>

7740</div>

7741</li>

7742</ol>

7743</div>

7744</section>

7745<section id="_892">

7746<h4 id="_892_toc">

7747Obinutuzumab alone or in combination with cytotoxic agents used in front-line therapy</h4>

7748<p id="_893" tabindex="-1">

7749Obinutuzumab is a CD20-binding monoclonal antibody with alternative epitope binding. </p>

7750<p id="_894" tabindex="-1">

7751Evidence (obinutuzumab):</p>

7752<div class="pdq-content-list">

7753<ol id="_895">

7754<li>

7755In a randomized prospective trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01059630">

7756NCT01059630</a>

7757) involving 396 patients with rituximab-refractory indolent lymphoma (mostly follicular lymphoma), patients received obinutuzumab plus bendamustine followed by obinutuzumab maintenance therapy for 2 years versus bendamustine alone with no maintenance therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.19">

775819</a>

7759,<a href="#cit/section_10.20">

776020</a>

7761][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7762Level of evidence A1</a>

7763]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7764<ul id="_896">

7765<li>

7766With a median follow-up of 31.8 months, the 2-year OS rate favored the obinutuzumab combination (74.5% vs. 65.1%) (hazard ratio [HR], 0.67; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.47&#8211;0.96; <em>

7767P</em>

7768 = .027). The median PFS also favored the obinutuzumab combination (25.8 months [95% CI, 19.5&#8211;41.1 months] vs. 14.1 months [95% CI, 12.6&#8211;16.0 months]) (HR, 0.57; 95% CI, 0.44&#8211;0.73; <em>

7769P</em>

7770 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_10.20">

777120</a>

7772][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7773Level of evidence A1</a>

7774]</li>

7775<li>

7776The contribution of maintenance therapy to the outcome could not be assessed in this design.</li>

7777</ul>

7778</div>

7779</li>

7780</ol>

7781</div>

7782</section>

7783<section id="_351">

7784<h4 id="_351_toc">

7785Lenalidomide and rituximab</h4>

7786<p id="_219" tabindex="-1">

7787 Responses of 20% to 56% have been reported for lenalidomide, especially in patients with follicular lymphoma and small lymphocytic lymphoma, with even higher responses noted for the combination of lenalidomide and rituximab.[<a href="#cit/section_10.21">

778821</a>

7789,<a href="#cit/section_10.22">

779022</a>

7791][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7792Level of evidence C3</a>

7793]</p>

7794</section>

7795<section id="_1313">

7796<h4 id="_1313_toc">

7797Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor</h4>

7798<section id="_1314">

7799<h5 id="_1314_toc">

7800Copanlisib</h5>

7801<p id="_1315" tabindex="-1">

7802Evidence (copanlisib):</p>

7803<div class="pdq-content-list">

7804<ol id="_1316">

7805<li>

7806A double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled study assigned 307 patients with recurrent indolent lymphoma to copanlisib plus rituximab and 151 patients to placebo plus rituximab (2:1 randomization).[<a href="#cit/section_10.23">

780723</a>

7808]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7809<ul id="_1335">

7810<li>

7811With a median follow-up of 19.2 months, the median PFS was 21.5 months for patients in the copanlisib-plus-rituximab arm (95% CI, 17.8&#8211;33.0) versus 13.8 months (95% CI, 10.2&#8211;17.5) for patients in the placebo-plus-rituximab arm (HR, 0.52; 95% CI, 0.39&#8211;0.69; <em>

7812P</em>

7813 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_10.23">

781423</a>

7815][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7816Level of evidence B1</a>

7817]</li>

7818<li>

7819Hyperglycemia and hypertension were the most common grade 3 to 4 adverse events, occurring in half of the patients who received copanlisib.</li>

7820</ul>

7821</div>

7822</li>

7823<li>

7824A phase II study included 142 patients with relapsed and refractory indolent lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_10.24">

782524</a>

7826]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7827<ul id="_1317">

7828<li>

7829Treatment with intravenous copanlisib resulted in a 59% objective response rate (12% CR), with a median duration of response of 22.6 months.[<a href="#cit/section_10.24">

783024</a>

7831][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7832Level of evidence C3</a>

7833]</li>

7834</ul>

7835</div>

7836</li>

7837</ol>

7838</div>

7839</section>

7840<p id="_1330" tabindex="-1">

7841The PI3K inhibitors have significant adverse effects, including pneumonitis, colitis, transaminitis, hypertension, hyperglycemia, rash, and increased risk of infections. These adverse events have affected the use of these agents until confirmatory trials can establish their efficacy in combinations. They are currently approved for treatment of relapsed and refractory follicular lymphoma after two previously received lines of therapy.</p>

7842</section>

7843<section id="_1353">

7844<h4 id="_1353_toc">

7845EZH2 inhibitor</h4>

7846<section id="_1354">

7847<h5 id="_1354_toc">

7848Tazemetostat</h5>

7849<p id="_1355" tabindex="-1">

7850Tazemetostat is an inhibitor of EZH2, a histone methyltransferase essential to the formation of lymph node germinal centers, especially with activating mutations of <em class="gene-name">

7851EZH2</em>

7852.</p>

7853<p id="_1356" tabindex="-1">

7854Evidence (tazemetostat):</p>

7855<div class="pdq-content-list">

7856<ol id="_1357">

7857<li>

7858A phase II study included 99 patients with relapsed or refractory follicular lymphoma, 45 of whom had activating mutations of <em class="gene-name">

7859EZH2</em>

7860, and 54 of whom had normal wild-type <em class="gene-name">

7861EZH2</em>

7862.[<a href="#cit/section_10.25">

786325</a>

7864]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7865<ul id="_1358">

7866<li>

7867Treatment with tazemetostat resulted in an objective response rate of 69% (95% CI, 53%&#8211;82%) for patients with activating mutations versus 35% (95% CI, 23%&#8211;49%) for patients with wild-type <em class="gene-name">

7868EZH2</em>

7869.[<a href="#cit/section_10.25">

787025</a>

7871]</li>

7872<li>

7873With a median follow-up of 22 months, the median PFS was 13.8 months (95% CI, 10.7&#8211;22.0) for patients with activating mutations and 11.1 months (95% CI, 3.7&#8211;14.6) for patients with wild-type <em class="gene-name">

7874EZH2</em>

7875.[<a href="#cit/section_10.25">

787625</a>

7877][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7878Level of evidence C3</a>

7879]</li>

7880<li>

7881Grade 3 or 4 treatment-related adverse events were seen in 4% of patients.</li>

7882</ul>

7883</div>

7884</li>

7885</ol>

7886</div>

7887</section>

7888</section>

7889<section id="_356">

7890<h4 id="_356_toc">

7891Palliative radiation therapy</h4>

7892<p id="_222" tabindex="-1">

7893Palliation may be achieved with very low-dose (4 Gy) involved-field radiation therapy in two fractions for patients with indolent and aggressive relapsed disease.[<a href="#cit/section_10.26">

789426</a>

7895] In a prospective randomized trial, treatment with 4 Gy was inferior to treatment with 24 Gy in 12 fractions in PFS (77% vs. 92%, <em>

7896P</em>

7897 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_10.27">

789827</a>

7899][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7900Level of evidence B1</a>

7901]</p>

7902</section>

7903<section id="_348">

7904<h4 id="_348_toc">

7905Chemotherapy (single agent or combination)</h4>

7906<p id="_216" tabindex="-1">

7907 Patients may respond to the original induction regimen again, especially if the duration of remission exceeds 1 year. For relapsing patients, rituximab alone or in combination with agents not previously used may induce remissions. For more information, see the <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_349">

7908Rituximab alone or in combination with cytotoxic agents used in front-line therapy</a>

7909 section.</p>

7910</section>

7911<section id="_352">

7912<h4 id="_352_toc">

7913Radiolabeled anti-CD20 monoclonal antibodies</h4>

7914<p id="_220" tabindex="-1">

7915 Durable responses to radiolabeled monoclonal antibodies, such as yttrium Y 90 (90Y)-ibritumomab tiuxetan (commercially available) and iodine I 131-tositumomab (commercially unavailable), have also been reported before and after cytotoxic chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.28">

791628</a>

7917-<a href="#cit/section_10.30">

791830</a>

7919][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7920Level of evidence B1</a>

7921]

7922

7923However, the cumulative incidence of death resulting from myelodysplastic syndrome or acute myeloid leukemia is higher (4% vs. 1%; <em>

7924P</em>

7925 = .02) in one of the randomized trials versus nonradiolabeled antibody with chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.30">

792630</a>

7927]</p>

7928<p id="_1128" tabindex="-1">

7929Evidence (radiolabeled anti-CD20 monoclonal antibodies):</p>

7930<div class="pdq-content-list">

7931<ol id="_1129">

7932<li>

7933In a prospective trial of 409 patients with follicular lymphoma who responded to induction chemotherapy, patients were randomly assigned to 90Y-ibritumomab tiuxetan or no further consolidation.[<a href="#cit/section_10.31">

793431</a>

7935]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7936<ul id="_1130">

7937<li>

7938 With a median follow-up of 7.3 years, the 8-year PFS rate favored 90Y-ibritumomab tiuxetan (41% vs. 22% [hazard ratio, 0.47; <em>

7939P</em>

7940 &lt; .001]), but there was no difference in OS.[<a href="#cit/section_10.31">

794131</a>

7942][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7943Level of evidence B1</a>

7944]

7945

7946</li>

7947</ul>

7948</div>

7949</li>

7950</ol>

7951</div>

7952</section>

7953<section id="_1395">

7954<h4 id="_1395_toc">

7955Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy</h4>

7956<p id="_1396" tabindex="-1">

7957CAR T-cell therapy, with the autologous anti-CD19 therapeutics axicabtagene ciloleucel, lisocabtagene maraleucel, or tisagenlecleucel, has been approved for patients with relapsed follicular lymphoma after two or more lines of prior therapy.</p>

7958<p id="_1397" tabindex="-1">

7959Evidence (CAR T-cell therapy):</p>

7960<div class="pdq-content-list">

7961<ol id="_1398">

7962<li>

7963In a phase II trial, 153 patients with relapsed or refractory follicular lymphoma or marginal zone lymphoma received axicabtagene ciloleucel.[<a href="#cit/section_10.32">

796432</a>

7965]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7966<ul id="_1399">

7967<li>

7968With a median follow-up of 17.5 months, the overall response rate was 92% (95% CI, 85%&#8211;97%) and the CR rate was 74%.</li>

7969<li>

7970The 18-month PFS rate was 64.8% (95% CI, 54.2%&#8211;73.5%).[<a href="#cit/section_10.32">

797132</a>

7972][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7973Level of evidence C3</a>

7974]</li>

7975<li>

7976Cytokine release syndrome occurred in 78% of patients and was grade 3 or 4 in 6% of patients. </li>

7977<li>

7978Tocilizumab was required in 50% of all patients, and 5% required vasopressors. Grade 3 or 4 neurological events occurred in 15% of patients.</li>

7979</ul>

7980</div>

7981</li>

7982<li>

7983In a phase II trial, 98 patients with relapsed or refractory follicular lymphoma after two or more lines of prior therapy received anti-CD19 CAR T-cell therapy with tisagenlecleucel.[<a href="#cit/section_10.33">

798433</a>

7985]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7986<ul id="_1478">

7987<li>

7988With a median follow-up of 16.6 months, the complete response rate was 69.1% (95% CI, 58.8%&#8211;78.3%), and the overall response rate was 86.2% (77.5%&#8211;92.4%).[<a href="#cit/section_10.33">

798933</a>

7990][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7991Level of evidence C3</a>

7992]</li>

7993<li>

7994Grade 3 or 4 cytokine release syndrome occurred in 48.5% of patients, and 37.1% had grade 3 or 4 neurotoxicity.</li>

7995</ul>

7996</div>

7997</li>

7998</ol>

7999</div>

8000<p id="_1400" tabindex="-1">

8001CAR T cells are being used for high-risk patients whose disease has relapsed rapidly after chemoimmunotherapy. Such an approach is considered in the context of numerous other available agents.</p>

8002</section>

8003<section id="_1479">

8004<h4 id="_1479_toc">

8005Bispecific T-cell engagers</h4>

8006<p id="_1480" tabindex="-1">

8007Bispecific T-cell engagers bind to CD20 (or CD19) and to CD3 to direct T cells to eliminate malignant B cells.[<a href="#cit/section_10.34">

800834</a>

8009,<a href="#cit/section_10.35">

801035</a>

8011] Similar to CAR T-cell therapy, almost one-half of patients who receive this therapy experience cytokine release syndrome.</p>

8012<section id="_1516">

8013<h5 id="_1516_toc">

8014Mosunetuzumab</h5>

8015<p id="_1517" tabindex="-1">

8016Evidence (mosunetuzumab):</p>

8017<div class="pdq-content-list">

8018<ol id="_1518">

8019<li>

8020In a single-arm, multicenter, phase II study, 90 patients with relapsed or refractory follicular lymphoma after two or more prior lines of therapy (including an anti-CD20 therapy and an alkylating agent) received mosunetuzumab.[<a href="#cit/section_10.34">

802134</a>

8022]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8023<ul id="_1519">

8024<li>

8025 With a median follow up of 27 months, the objective response rate was 77.8% (95% CI, 67.8%&#8211;85.9%), and the complete response rate was 60.0% (95% CI, 49.1%&#8211;70.2%), per investigator assessment. The median PFS per investigator assessment was not reached. The 24-month PFS was 51.4 months (95% CI, 39.4&#8211;63.3) after receiving mosunetuzumab, compared with 23.5 months (95% CI, 14.5&#8211;32.5) for patients' last prior therapy (63% chemoimmunotherapy, 8% PI3K inhibitor, 2% CAR T-cell therapy, 2% anti-CD20 antibody plus lenalidomide, and others).</li>

8026<li>

8027Cytokine release syndrome occurred in 44.4% of patients; 97.2% of cases were grade 1 or 2 in severity.[<a href="#cit/section_10.36">

802836</a>

8029][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8030Level of evidence C3</a>

8031]</li>

8032</ul>

8033</div>

8034</li>

8035</ol>

8036</div>

8037</section>

8038</section>

8039<section id="_1401">

8040<h4 id="_1401_toc">

8041Stem cell transplantation</h4>

8042<p id="_1402" tabindex="-1">

8043In many institutions, autologous or allogeneic SCTs are being used for high-risk patients whose disease has relapsed rapidly after chemoimmunotherapy. Such an approach is considered in the context of numerous other available agents.[<a href="#cit/section_10.37">

804437</a>

8045-<a href="#cit/section_10.41">

804641</a>

8047]</p>

8048<p id="_1403" tabindex="-1">

8049Evidence (SCT):</p>

8050<div class="pdq-content-list">

8051<ol id="_1404">

8052<li>

8053The German Low-Grade Lymphoma Study Group treated 307 patients with follicular lymphoma with two cycles of CHOP (cyclophosphamide,

8054doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone)-like induction chemotherapy and then randomly assigned them to autologous SCT versus interferon maintenance.[<a href="#cit/section_10.42">

805542</a>

8056] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8057<ul id="_1405">

8058<li>

8059With a median follow-up of 4.2 years, the 5-year PFS rate was 65% for patients who received transplantation versus 33% for patients who received interferon (<em>

8060P</em>

8061 &lt; .001). There was no difference in OS.[<a href="#cit/section_10.42">

806242</a>

8063][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8064Level of evidence B1</a>

8065]</li>

8066</ul>

8067</div>

8068</li>

8069</ol>

8070</div>

8071</section>

8072</section>

8073<section id="_TrialSearch_212_sid_10">

8074<h3 id="_TrialSearch_212_sid_10_toc">

8075Current Clinical Trials</h3>

8076<p id="_TrialSearch_212_22" tabindex="-1">

8077Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

8078advanced clinical trial search</a>

8079 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

8080General information</a>

8081 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

8082</section>

8159Sehn LH, Chua N, Mayer J, et al.: Obinutuzumab plus bendamustine versus bendamustine monotherapy in patients with rituximab-refractory indolent non-Hodgkin lymphoma (GADOLIN): a randomised, controlled, open-label, multicentre, phase 3 trial. 8161</li>

8162<li id="section_10.20">

8163Cheson BD, Chua N, Mayer J, et al.: Overall Survival Benefit in Patients With Rituximab-Refractory Indolent Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma Who Received Obinutuzumab Plus Bendamustine Induction and Obinutuzumab Maintenance in the GADOLIN Study. J Clin Oncol 36 (22): 2259-2266, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29584548&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29584548&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8164[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8165</li>

8166<li id="section_10.21">

8167Witzig TE, Wiernik PH, Moore T, et al.: Lenalidomide oral monotherapy produces durable responses in relapsed or refractory indolent non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma. J Clin Oncol 27 (32): 5404-9, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19805688&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19805688&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8168[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8169</li>

8170<li id="section_10.22">

8172[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8173</li>

8189</li>

8193</li>

8197</li>

J Clin Oncol 24 (27): 4418-25, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16940276&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16940276&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8201</li>

8202<li id="section_10.30">

8203Shadman M, Li H, Rimsza L, et al.: Continued Excellent Outcomes in Previously Untreated Patients With Follicular Lymphoma After Treatment With CHOP Plus Rituximab or CHOP Plus 131I-Tositumomab: Long-Term Follow-Up of Phase III Randomized Study SWOG-S0016. [Abstract] Blood 140 (Suppl 1): A-610, 1467-70, 2022.</li>
