8253</div>

8254

8255 </section>

8256

8257

8258

8259 <section id="_244">

8260

8261 <h2>

8262Treatment of Aggressive Stage I and Aggressive, Contiguous Stage II NHL</h2>

8263

8264 <div id="_section_244" class="pdq-sections">

8265<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

8266<h6>

8267In This Section</h6>

8268<ul>

8269<li>

8270<a href="#_246_toc">

8271Treatment Options for Aggressive Stage I and Aggressive, Contiguous Stage II NHL<ul>

8272<li>

8273<a href="#_248_toc">

8274R-CHOP with or without IF-XRT</a>

8275</li>

8276</ul>

8277</a>

8278</li>

8279<li>

8280<a href="#_TrialSearch_244_sid_11_toc">

8281Current Clinical Trials</a>

8282</li>

8283</ul>

8284</nav>

8285<p id="_245" tabindex="-1">

8286Patients with aggressive stage I or aggressive, contiguous stage II diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) are candidates for combination chemotherapy with or without involved-field radiation therapy (IF-XRT).</p>

8287<p id="_1406" tabindex="-1">

8288Patients with a resolved hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection (defined as hepatitis B surface antigen-negative but hepatitis B core antibody-positive) are at risk of reactivation of HBV and require monitoring of HBV DNA. Prophylactic nucleoside therapy lowered HBV reactivation from 10.8% to 2.1% in a retrospective study of 326 patients.[<a href="#cit/section_11.1">

82891</a>

8290]</p>

8291<section id="_246">

8292<h3 id="_246_toc">

8293Treatment Options for Aggressive Stage I and Aggressive, Contiguous Stage II NHL</h3>

8294<p id="_457" tabindex="-1">

8295Treatment options for aggressive stage I and aggressive, contiguous stage II non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) include the following:</p>

8296<div class="pdq-content-list">

8297<ol id="_506">

8298<li>

8299<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_248">

8300R-CHOP (rituximab, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone) with or without IF-XRT</a>

8301.</li>

8302<li>

8303R-ACVBP (rituximab, doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, vindesine, bleomycin, prednisone) (under clinical evaluation).[<a href="#cit/section_11.2">

83042</a>

8305,<a href="#cit/section_11.3">

83063</a>

8307]</li>

8308</ol>

8309</div>

8310<section id="_248">

8311<h4 id="_248_toc">

8312R-CHOP with or without IF-XRT</h4>

8313<p id="_252" tabindex="-1">

8314The confirmation of efficacy for rituximab in advanced-stage disease has suggested the use of R-CHOP with or without radiation therapy but its use is only supported by retrospective comparisons.[<a href="#cit/section_11.4">

83154</a>

8316][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8317Level of evidence C2</a>

8318]</p>

8319<div class="pdq-content-list">

8320<ul id="_460">

8321<li>

8322R-CHOP (four to six cycles).</li>

8323<li>

8324R-CHOP (three to six cycles) + IF-XRT.</li>

8325</ul>

8326</div>

8327<p id="_1131" tabindex="-1">

8328Evidence (R-CHOP with or without IF-XRT):</p>

8329<div class="pdq-content-list">

8330<ol id="_1132">

8331<li>

8332In a randomized prospective trial of 334 patients with nonbulky (&#8804;7 cm) stage I or stage II DLBCL, after receiving four to six cycles of R-CHOP-14 (R-CHOP delivered every 2 weeks), patients were randomly assigned to receive or not receive 40 Gy of radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.5">

83335</a>

8334] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8335<ul id="_1133">

8336<li>

8337After a median follow-up of 64 months, the 5-year event-free survival (89%&#8211;92%, <em>

8338P</em>

8339 = .18) and 5-year overall survival (OS) (92%&#8211;96%, <em>

8340P</em>

8341 = .32) were the same.[<a href="#cit/section_11.5">

83425</a>

8343][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8344Level of evidence A1</a>

8345] </li>

8346</ul>

8347</div>

8348<p id="_1134" tabindex="-1">

8349Similar to the results of randomized studies of radiation therapy in the prerituximab era, radiation therapy can be deferred in nonbulky early-stage patients. For patients unable to tolerate prolonged-course chemotherapy, three cycles of R-CHOP plus radiation therapy has produced equivalent results based on single-arm retrospective trials.[<a href="#cit/section_11.4">

83504</a>

8351]</p>

8352</li>

8353<li>

8354In a randomized prospective trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00278421">

8355NCT00278421</a>

8356) of 592 patients younger than 60 years with nonbulky (&lt;7.5 cm) stage I or stage II DLBCL, patients were randomly assigned to receive either four or six cycles of R-CHOP (with an extra two cycles of rituximab after four cycles).[<a href="#cit/section_11.6">

83576</a>

8358]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8359<ul id="_1222">

8360<li>

8361With a median follow-up of 66 months, the 3-year progression-free survival (PFS) rate was 96% (95% CI, 94%&#8722;99%)for patients who received four cycles of R-CHOP, which was 3% better (lower limit of one-sided 95% CI was zero) than the PFS rate for patients who received six cycles, establishing noninferiority for the four-cycle regimen.[<a href="#cit/section_11.6">

83626</a>

8363][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8364Level of evidence B1</a>

8365] </li>

8366</ul>

8367</div>

8368</li>

8369<li>

8370A retrospective analysis at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center between 2001 and 2015 included 341 patients with stage I disease. The analysis found that 66% of patients had an extranodal presentation. After R-CHOP (or a similar regimen), with or without radiation therapy, the 5-year disease-free survival rate was 77%, and the 5-year OS rate was 94%.[<a href="#cit/section_11.7">

83717</a>

8372][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8373Level of evidence C3</a>

8374] A multivariate analysis suggested that radiation therapy may improve outcomes for patients with extranodal disease that is positron emission tomography (PET)&#8211;positive at the end of therapy. This hypothesis needs confirmation in a prospective randomized trial.[<a href="#cit/section_11.7">

83757</a>

8376]</li>

8377</ol>

8378</div>

8379<p id="_1060" tabindex="-1">

8380In summary, for patients with favorable prognosis nonbulky (&lt;7 cm) stage I or stage II DLBCL, four cycles of R-CHOP is sufficient. For patients with unfavorable prognosis, six cycles of R-CHOP or three cycles of R-CHOP and 40 Gy of radiation therapy can be used. Early-stage patients with bulky disease (&gt;7.5 cm) have not been studied in randomized trials; combined-modality therapy with R-CHOP for four to six cycles plus radiation therapy is usually chosen. Although a retrospective study suggested that patients with stage I extranodal disease and a positive PET scan at the end of therapy may benefit from radiation therapy, this hypothesis must be confirmed in a prospective randomized trial.</p>

8381</section>

8382</section>

8383<section id="_TrialSearch_244_sid_11">

8384<h3 id="_TrialSearch_244_sid_11_toc">

8385Current Clinical Trials</h3>

8386<p id="_TrialSearch_244_22" tabindex="-1">

8387Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

8388advanced clinical trial search</a>

8389 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

8390General information</a>

8391 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

8392</section>

8408<li id="section_11.4">

8409Persky DO, Unger JM, Spier CM, et al.: Phase II study of rituximab plus three cycles of CHOP and involved-field radiotherapy for patients with limited-stage aggressive B-cell lymphoma: Southwest Oncology Group study 0014. J Clin Oncol 26 (14): 2258-63, 2008.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18413640&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18413640&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8410[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8411</li>

8412<li id="section_11.5">

8413Lamy T, Damaj G, Soubeyran P, et al.: R-CHOP 14 with or without radiotherapy in nonbulky limited-stage diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Blood 131 (2): 174-181, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29061568&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29061568&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8414[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8415</li>

8416<li id="section_11.6">

8417Poeschel V, Held G, Ziepert M, et al.: Four versus six cycles of CHOP chemotherapy in combination with six applications of rituximab in patients with aggressive B-cell lymphoma with favourable prognosis (FLYER): a randomised, phase 3, non-inferiority trial. Lancet 394 (10216): 2271-2281, 2019.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31868632&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31868632&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8418[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8419</li>

8420<li id="section_11.7">

8421Bobillo S, Joffe E, Lavery JA, et al.: Clinical characteristics and outcomes of extranodal stage I diffuse large B-cell lymphoma in the rituximab era. Blood 137 (1): 39-48, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32730585&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32730585&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8422[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8423</li>

8424</ol>

8425</div>

8426

8427 </section>

8428

8429

8430

8431 <section id="_258">

8432

8433 <h2>

8434Treatment of Aggressive, Noncontiguous Stage II/III/IV NHL</h2>

8435

8436 <div id="_section_258" class="pdq-sections">

8437<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

8438<h6>

8439In This Section</h6>

8440<ul>

8441<li>

8442<a href="#_260_toc">

8443Treatment Options for Aggressive, Noncontiguous Stage II/III/IV NHL<ul>

8444<li>

8445<a href="#_264_toc">

8446R-CHOP</a>

8447</li>

8448<li>

8449<a href="#_647_toc">

8450Stage IE or IIE gastric DLBCL</a>

8451</li>

8452<li>

8453<a href="#_588_toc">

8454Prognostic factors</a>

8455</li>

8456<li>

8457<a href="#_592_toc">

8458Treatment of tumor lysis syndrome</a>

8459</li>

8460<li>

8461<a href="#_594_toc">

8462CNS prophylaxis</a>

8463</li>

8464<li>

8465<a href="#_1487_toc">

8466BMT or SCT</a>

8467</li>

8468<li>

8469<a href="#_1490_toc">

8470Radiation therapy consolidation to sites of bulky disease</a>

8471</li>

8472</ul>

8473</a>

8474</li>

8475<li>

8476<a href="#_TrialSearch_258_sid_12_toc">

8477Current Clinical Trials</a>

8478</li>

8479</ul>

8480</nav>

8481<p id="_259" tabindex="-1">

8482The treatment of choice for patients with advanced stages of aggressive non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) is combination chemotherapy, either alone or supplemented by local-field radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_12.1">

84831</a>

8484]</p>

8485<div class="pdq-content-list">

8486<p class="pdq-list-title">

8487The following drug combinations are referred to in this section:</p>

8488<ul id="_261">

8489<li>

8490R-CHOP: rituximab + cyclophosphamide + doxorubicin + vincristine + prednisone.

8491</li>

8492<li>

8493R-ACVBP: rituximab, an anti&#8211;CD20 monoclonal antibody, + doxorubicin + cyclophosphamide + vindesine + bleomycin + prednisone.</li>

8494</ul>

8495</div>

8496<section id="_260">

8497<h3 id="_260_toc">

8498Treatment Options for Aggressive, Noncontiguous Stage II/III/IV NHL</h3>

8499<p id="_466" tabindex="-1">

8500Treatment options for aggressive, noncontiguous stage II/III/IV NHL include the following:</p>

8501<div class="pdq-content-list">

8502<ol id="_539">

8503<li>

8504<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_264">

8505R-CHOP</a>

8506.</li>

8507<li>

8508Other combination chemotherapy.</li>

8509<li>

8510<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1487">

8511Bone marrow transplantation (BMT) or stem cell transplantation (SCT)</a>

8512 (under clinical evaluation).</li>

8513<li>

8514<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1490">

8515Radiation therapy consolidation to sites of bulky disease</a>

8516 (under clinical evaluation). </li>

8517</ol>

8518</div>

8519<section id="_264">

8520<h4 id="_264_toc">

8521R-CHOP</h4>

8522<p id="_468" tabindex="-1">

8523The following studies established R-CHOP as the standard regimen for newly diagnosed patients with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL).[<a href="#cit/section_12.2">

85242</a>

8525] Dose intensification of R-CHOP by a 14-day versus a 21-day cycle did not result in improved outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_12.3">

85263</a>

8527]</p>

8528<p id="_370" tabindex="-1">

8529Evidence (R-CHOP):</p>

8530<div class="pdq-content-list">

8531<ol id="_372">

8532<li>

8533R-CHOP showed improvement in event-free survival (EFS) and overall survival (OS) compared with CHOP (cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone) alone in 399 advanced-stage patients with DLBCL older than 60 years (EFS rate, 57% vs. 38%; <em>

8534P</em>

8535 = .002, and OS rate, 70% vs. 57%; <em>

8536P</em>

8537 = .007 at 2 years).[<a href="#cit/section_12.4">

85384</a>

8539][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8540Level of evidence A1</a>

8541] At a median follow-up of 10 years, the OS rate of patients who received R-CHOP compared with patients who received CHOP was 44% versus 28% (<em>

8542P</em>

8543 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_12.5">

85445</a>

8545] </li>

8546<li>

8547Similarly, for 326 evaluable patients younger than 61 years, R-CHOP showed improvement in EFS and OS compared with CHOP alone (EFS rate, 79% vs. 59%, <em>

8548P</em>

8549 = .001, and OS rate, 93% vs. 84%, <em>

8550P</em>

8551 = .001 at 3 years).[<a href="#cit/section_12.6">

85526</a>

8553][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8554Level of evidence A1</a>

8555] </li>

8556<li>

8557A randomized study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00052936">

8558DSHNHL-1999-1A</a>

8559 [NCT00052936]) of 1,222 patients older than 60 years compared R-CHOP given every 2 weeks for six or eight cycles with CHOP given every 2 weeks for six or eight cycles.[<a href="#cit/section_12.7">

85607</a>

8561] With a median follow-up of 72 months, the EFS favored R-CHOP given every 2 weeks for six or eight cycles (EFS rate at 6 years, 74% vs. 56%; <em>

8562P</em>

8563 &lt; .0001). The OS favored R-CHOP for only six cycles because of increased toxicity in the eight-cycle arm (OS rate at 6 years, 90% vs. 80%; <em>

8564P</em>

8565 = .0004).[<a href="#cit/section_12.7">

85667</a>

8567][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8568Level of evidence A1</a>

8569] There was no comparison with standard R-CHOP or CHOP given every 3 weeks.

8570

8571</li>

8572<li>

8573A trial <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00140595">

8574(NCT00140595)</a>

8575 of 380 patients younger than 60 years with DLBCL and an age-adjusted International Prognostic Index (IPI) rating of 1 randomly assigned treatment of patients to ACVBP and R-ACVBP plus consolidation with methotrexate, ifosfamide, etoposide, and cytarabine versus CHOP and rituximab.[<a href="#cit/section_12.8">

85768</a>

8577] With a median follow-up of 44 months, 3-year OS rates favored R-ACVBP (92% vs. 84%; hazard ratio [HR], 0.44; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.28&#8211;0.81, <em>

8578P</em>

8579 = .007).[<a href="#cit/section_12.8">

85808</a>

8581][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8582Level of evidence A1</a>

8583] The significantly worse toxicities with R-ACVBP, the narrow target population (&lt;60 years with either elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) or stage III-stage IV disease, but not both), and the lack of a confirmatory trial may inhibit adoption of R-ACVBP as a new standard of care.[<a href="#cit/section_12.9">

85849</a>

8585]</li>

8586</ol>

8587</div>

8588<p id="_1407" tabindex="-1">

8589Modifications to R-CHOP to achieve improved efficacy continue to be explored in clinical trials. For over 2 decades, no modification has replaced R-CHOP as the worldwide standard induction therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_12.10">

859010</a>

8591]</p>

8592<p id="_1408" tabindex="-1">

8593<strong>

8594Pola-R-CHP</strong>

8595</p>

8596<p id="_1409" tabindex="-1">

8597R-CHOP has been compared to Pola-R-CHP (polatuzumab vedotin, rituximab, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, and prednisone). Polatuzumab is an antibody-drug conjugate composed of an anti-CD79B monoclonal antibody attached to vedotin (monomethyl auristatin E), a microtubule inhibitor.</p>

8598<p id="_1410" tabindex="-1">

8599Evidence (Pola-R-CHP):</p>

8600<div class="pdq-content-list">

8601<ol id="_1411">

8602<li>

8603A provocative, prospective, randomized study of 879 patients with previously untreated DLBCL compared R-CHOP with Pola-R-CHP.[<a href="#cit/section_12.11">

860411</a>

8605] Polatuzumab vedotin was substituted for vincristine to mitigate neurological toxicity.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8606<ul id="_1412">

8607<li>

8608At a median follow-up of 28.2 months, the 2-year PFS rate was significantly higher in the Pola-R-CHP group than in the R-CHOP group: 76.7% (95% CI, 72.7%&#8211;80.0%) versus 70.2% (95% CI, 65.8%&#8211;74.6%) (HR, 0.73; 95% CI, 0.57&#8211;0.95; <em>

8609P</em>

8610 = .02).[<a href="#cit/section_12.11">

861111</a>

8612][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8613Level of evidence B1</a>

8614]</li>

8615<li>

8616The 2-year OS rate was 88.7% (95% CI, 85.7%&#8211;91.6%) for patients who received Pola-R-CHP and 88.6% (95% CI, 85.6%&#8211;91.6%) for patients who received R-CHOP (HR, 0.94; 95% CI, 0.65&#8211;1.37; <em>

8617P</em>

8618 = .75).</li>

8619</ul>

8620</div>

8621</li>

8622</ol>

8623</div>

8624<p id="_1413" tabindex="-1">

8625The follow-up interval was too short to establish whether the 6% improvement in the PFS rate will plateau or improve after 2 years, and there is no evidence of OS advantage. Nonetheless, physician advisory panels are considering whether this represents a new standard regimen to replace R-CHOP. The new regimen is more than twice the cost of R-CHOP using acquisition prices in 2022.</p>

8626<p id="_269" tabindex="-1">

8627There is no validated trial for interim positron emission tomography&#8211;based treatment intensification.[<a href="#cit/section_12.12">

862812</a>

8629] R-CHOP has curative potential even in patients older than 80 years who are frail and require reduced dosage of R-CHOP components. In a retrospective review of 239 patients, the 5-year cause-specific survival rate was 48% (95% CI, 41%&#8722;55%).[<a href="#cit/section_12.13">

863013</a>

8631][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8632Level of evidence C3</a>

8633] </p>

8634<p id="_1190" tabindex="-1">

8635Less than 10% of patients with DLBCL present with a concurrent indolent lymphoma at diagnosis, and these are predominantly of germinal center B-cell phenotype. A retrospective review of 1,324 patients showed similar EFS (HR, 1.19) and OS (HR, 1.09).[<a href="#cit/section_12.14">

863614</a>

8637][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8638Level of evidence C3</a>

8639] For 847 patients who were treated with R-CHOP and free of disease 24 months after therapy, the rate of indolent lymphoma relapse by 5 years was higher with a concurrent diagnosis of follicular lymphoma (7.4% vs. 2.1% at 5 years, <em>

8640P</em>

8641 &lt; .01) and with a germinal center B-cell phenotype (3.9% vs. 0.0% at 5 years, <em>

8642P</em>

8643 = .02).[<a href="#cit/section_12.15">

864415</a>

8645]</p>

8646</section>

8647<section id="_647">

8648<h4 id="_647_toc">

8649Stage IE or IIE gastric DLBCL</h4>

8650<p id="_648" tabindex="-1">

8651Four case series involving more than 100 patients with stage IE or IIE disease (with or without associated mucosa-associated lymphatic tissue) and with positive <em>

8652Helicobacter pylori</em>

8653 infection reported that more than 50% of patients attained a durable complete remission after appropriate antibiotic therapy to eradicate <em>

8654H. pylori</em>

8655.[<a href="#cit/section_12.16">

865616</a>

8657-<a href="#cit/section_12.19">

865819</a>

8659][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8660Level of evidence C3</a>

8661]</p>

8662</section>

8663<section id="_588">

8664<h4 id="_588_toc">

8665Prognostic factors</h4>

8666<p id="_1052" tabindex="-1">

8667The National Comprehensive Cancer Network IPI for aggressive NHL (diffuse large cell lymphoma) identifies the following five significant risk factors prognostic of OS and their associated risk scores:[<a href="#cit/section_12.20">

866820</a>

8669]</p>

8670<div class="pdq-content-list">

8671<p class="pdq-list-title">

8672</p>

8673<ul id="_1053">

8674<li>

8675Age.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8676<ul id="_1381" class="list-dash">

8677<li>

8678&lt;40 years: 0.</li>

8679<li>

868041&#8211;60 years: 1.</li>

8681<li>

868261&#8211;75 years: 2.</li>

8683<li>

8684&gt;75 years: 3.</li>

8685</ul>

8686</div>

8687</li>

8688<li>

8689Stage III/IV: 1.</li>

8690<li>

8691Performance status 2/3/4: 1.</li>

8692<li>

8693Serum LDH.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8694<ul id="_1382" class="list-dash">

8695<li>

8696Normalized: 0.</li>

8697<li>

8698&gt;1x to 3x: 1.</li>

8699<li>

8700&gt;3x: 2.</li>

8701</ul>

8702</div>

8703</li>

8704<li>

8705Number of extranodal sites &#8805;2: 1.</li>

8706</ul>

8707</div>

8708<p id="_1061" tabindex="-1">

8709Risk scores:</p>

8710<div class="pdq-content-list">

8711<ul id="_1062">

8712<li>

8713Low (0 or 1): 5-year OS, 96%; progression-free survival (PFS), 91%.</li>

8714<li>

8715Low intermediate (2 or 3): 5-year OS, 82%; PFS, 74%.</li>

8716<li>

8717High intermediate (4 or 5): 5-year OS, 64%; PFS, 51%.</li>

8718<li>

8719High (&gt;6): 5-year OS, 33%; PFS, 30%.</li>

8720</ul>

8721</div>

8722<p id="_1054" tabindex="-1">

8723Age-adjusted and stage-adjusted modifications of this IPI are used for younger patients with localized disease.[<a href="#cit/section_12.21">

872421</a>

8725] Shorter intervals of time between diagnosis and treatment appear to be a surrogate for poor prognostic biological factors.[<a href="#cit/section_12.22">

872622</a>

8727]</p>

8728<p id="_591" tabindex="-1">

8729The <em class="gene-name">

8730BCL2</em>

8731 gene and rearrangement of the <em class="gene-name">

8732MYC</em>

8733 gene or dual overexpression of the <em class="gene-name">

8734MYC</em>

8735 gene, or both, confer a particularly poor prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_12.23">

873623</a>

8737-<a href="#cit/section_12.26">

873826</a>

8739] Patients at high risk of relapse may be considered for clinical trials.[<a href="#cit/section_12.27">

874027</a>

8741] Molecular profiles of gene expression using DNA microarrays may help to stratify patients in the future for therapies directed at specific targets and to better predict survival after standard chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_12.28">

874228</a>

8743]</p>

8744</section>

8745<section id="_592">

8746<h4 id="_592_toc">

8747Treatment of tumor lysis syndrome</h4>

8748<p id="_593" tabindex="-1">

8749Patients with bulky and extensive lymphadenopathy and elevations of serum uric acid and LDH are at increased risk of tumor lysis syndrome resulting in metabolic derangements such as hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and subsequent acute renal failure.[<a href="#cit/section_12.29">

875029</a>

8751] Treatment options include: alkaline hydration, allopurinol, and rasburicase, a recombinant urate oxidase.[<a href="#cit/section_12.30">

875230</a>

8753]</p>

8754</section>

8755<section id="_594">

8756<h4 id="_594_toc">

8757CNS prophylaxis</h4>

8758<p id="_1359" tabindex="-1">

8759The CNS-IPI tool predicts which patients have a CNS relapse risk exceeding 10%. It was developed by the German Lymphoma Study Group and validated by the British Columbia Cancer Agency database. The presence of four to six of the CNS-IPI risk factors (age &gt;60 years, performance status &#8805;2, elevated LDH, stage III or IV disease, &gt;1 extranodal site, or involvement of the kidneys or adrenal glands) was used to define a high-risk group for CNS recurrence (a 12% risk of CNS involvement by 2 years).[<a href="#cit/section_12.31">

876031</a>

8761]</p>

8762<p id="_1336" tabindex="-1">

8763CNS prophylaxis (usually with four to six doses of intrathecal methotrexate) is often recommended for patients with testicular involvement.[<a href="#cit/section_12.32">

876432</a>

8765-<a href="#cit/section_12.34">

876634</a>

8767][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8768Level of evidence C3</a>

8769] A retrospective analysis of the German RICOVER studies compared intrathecal methotrexate with no prophylaxis in patients with DLBCL. This study was completed during the R-CHOP treatment era. With the possible exception of patients with testicular involvement, the analysis showed that intrathecal methotrexate did not reduce the risk of CNS disease.[<a href="#cit/section_12.35">

877035</a>

8771][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8772Level of evidence C3</a>

8773] Some clinicians employ high-dose intravenous (IV) methotrexate (usually four doses) as an alternative to intrathecal therapy because drug delivery is improved and patient morbidity is decreased.[<a href="#cit/section_12.36">

877436</a>

8775] Five retrospective studies and one network meta-analysis evaluating high-dose methotrexate alone in patients with high-risk DLBCL also showed no improvement in CNS relapse rate.[<a href="#cit/section_12.37">

877637</a>

8777-<a href="#cit/section_12.42">

877842</a>

8779][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8780Level of evidence C3</a>

8781] Patients deemed at high risk for CNS relapse (e.g., patients with four to six CNS-IPI risk factors) may receive intrathecal methotrexate or high-dose IV methotrexate, but the lack of confirmatory randomized studies calls this standard into question and shows an urgent need for better therapeutics verified in clinical trials. Although patients with testicular involvement or kidney/adrenal involvement are considered an exception, there is only anecdotal benefit from intrathecal or high-dose IV methotrexate in reducing CNS recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_12.32">

878232</a>

8783-<a href="#cit/section_12.34">

878434</a>

8785][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8786Level of evidence C3</a>

8787]</p>

8788<p id="_1339" tabindex="-1">

8789The addition of rituximab to CHOP-based regimens has significantly reduced the risk of CNS relapse in retrospective analyses.[<a href="#cit/section_12.35">

879035</a>

8791,<a href="#cit/section_12.43">

879243</a>

8793][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8794Level of evidence C3</a>

8795] Patients with CNS dissemination at diagnosis or at relapse usually receive rituximab and high doses of methotrexate and/or cytarabine followed by autologous stem cell transplantation (SCT), but this approach has not been assessed in randomized trials.[<a href="#cit/section_12.44">

879644</a>

8797,<a href="#cit/section_12.45">

879845</a>

8799][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8800Level of evidence C3</a>

8801] </p>

8802</section>

8803<section id="_1487">

8804<h4 id="_1487_toc">

8805BMT or SCT</h4>

8806<p id="_1488" tabindex="-1">

8807Several randomized prospective trials evaluated the role of autologous BMT or SCT consolidation versus chemotherapy alone in patients with diffuse large cell lymphoma in first remission.[<a href="#cit/section_12.46">

880846</a>

8809-<a href="#cit/section_12.53">

881053</a>

8811]; [<a href="#cit/section_12.54">

881254</a>

8813-<a href="#cit/section_12.56">

881456</a>

8815][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8816Level of evidence A1</a>

8817] Although some of these trials demonstrated significant increases in EFS (by 10% to 20%) among patients who received high-dose therapy, significant differences in OS could not be demonstrated prospectively in any of the series.</p>

8818<p id="_1489" tabindex="-1">

8819Retrospective analyses of high-intermediate (two risk factors) or high-risk (more than three risk factors) patients as defined by IPI suggest improved survival with BMT in two of the trials.[<a href="#cit/section_12.47">

882047</a>

8821,<a href="#cit/section_12.53">

882253</a>

8823] These studies do not establish that high-dose consolidation is of value to patients with aggressive lymphoma who are truly at high risk of relapse, and they also demonstrate that EFS may be a poor surrogate for OS for these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_12.57">

882457</a>

8825]</p>

8826</section>

8827<section id="_1490">

8828<h4 id="_1490_toc">

8829Radiation therapy consolidation to sites of bulky disease</h4>

8830<p id="_1491" tabindex="-1">

8831After R-CHOP induction chemotherapy (or similar regimens), the addition of involved-field radiation therapy to sites of initial bulky disease (&#8805;5&#8211;10 cm) or to extralymphatic sites remains controversial.[<a href="#cit/section_12.58">

883258</a>

8833-<a href="#cit/section_12.60">

883460</a>

8835] Increased risks, such as long-term toxicities (e.g., second malignancies), must be considered.</p>

8836</section>

8837</section>

8838<section id="_TrialSearch_258_sid_12">

8839<h3 id="_TrialSearch_258_sid_12_toc">

8840Current Clinical Trials</h3>

8841<p id="_TrialSearch_258_22" tabindex="-1">

8842Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

8843advanced clinical trial search</a>

8844 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

8845General information</a>

8846 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

8847</section>

Blood 113 (17): 3896-902, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19144985&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19144985&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8989[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8990</li>

8991<li id="section_12.36">

8992Glantz MJ, Cole BF, Recht L, et al.: High-dose intravenous methotrexate for patients with nonleukemic leptomeningeal cancer: is intrathecal chemotherapy necessary? J Clin Oncol 16 (4): 1561-7, 1998.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9552066&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9552066&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8993[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8994</li>

9092

9093

9094 <section id="_1228">

9095

9096 <h2>

9097Treatment of Aggressive, Recurrent NHL</h2>

9098

9099 <div id="_section_1228" class="pdq-sections">

9100<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

9101<h6>

9102In This Section</h6>

9103<ul>

9104<li>

9105<a href="#_1229_toc">

9106Treatment Options for Aggressive, Recurrent NHL<ul>

9107<li>

9108<a href="#_1416_toc">

9109CAR T-cell therapy for primary refractory disease or relapse within one year</a>

9110</li>

9111<li>

9112<a href="#_1233_toc">

9113Bone marrow/stem cell transplantation consolidation</a>

9114</li>

9115<li>

9116<a href="#_1248_toc">

9117CAR T-cell therapy for relapse after autologous SCT</a>

9118</li>

9119<li>

9120<a href="#_1341_toc">

9121Tafasitamab plus lenalidomide</a>

9122</li>

9123<li>

9124<a href="#_1250_toc">

9125Rituximab plus lenalidomide</a>

9126</li>

9127<li>

9128<a href="#_1253_toc">

9129Polatuzumab vedotin plus rituximab and bendamustine</a>

9130</li>

9131<li>

9132<a href="#_1428_toc">

9133Loncastuximab tesirine</a>

9134</li>

9135<li>

9136<a href="#_1514_toc">

9137Bispecific T-cell engagers</a>

9138</li>

9139<li>

9140<a href="#_1258_toc">

9141Palliative radiation therapy</a>

9142</li>

9143</ul>

9144</a>

9145</li>

9146<li>

9147<a href="#_TrialSearch_1228_sid_13_toc">

9148Current Clinical Trials</a>

9149</li>

9150</ul>

9151</nav>

9152<section id="_1229">

9153<h3 id="_1229_toc">

9154Treatment Options for Aggressive, Recurrent NHL</h3>

9155<p id="_1230" tabindex="-1">

9156In a retrospective review of multiple international trials, 636 patients were identified as having refractory diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), which was defined as progression or stable disease during or just at completion of full-course chemotherapy or relapse within 1 year after autologous stem cell transplantation (SCT).[<a href="#cit/section_13.1">

91571</a>

9158] With subsequent therapy the objective response rate was 26%, complete response (CR) rate was 7%, median overall survival (OS) was 6.3 months, and only 20% of patients were alive at 2 years. Even with reinduction chemotherapy with planned autologous SCT, outcomes remain poor.[<a href="#cit/section_13.2">

91592</a>

9160]</p>

9161<p id="_1231" tabindex="-1">

9162Treatment options for aggressive, recurrent non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) include the following:</p>

9163<div class="pdq-content-list">

9164<ol id="_1415">

9165<li>

9166<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1416">

9167Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy for primary refractory disease or relapse within one year</a>

9168.</li>

9169<li>

9170<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1233">

9171Bone marrow transplantation (BMT)/SCT consolidation</a>

9172.</li>

9173<li>

9174<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1248">

9175CAR T-cell therapy for relapse after autologous SCT</a>

9176.</li>

9177<li>

9178<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1341">

9179Tafasitamab plus lenalidomide</a>

9180.</li>

9181<li>

9182<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1250">

9183Rituximab plus lenalidomide</a>

9184.</li>

9185<li>

9186<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1253">

9187Polatuzumab vedotin plus rituximab and bendamustine</a>

9188.</li>

9189<li>

9190<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1428">

9191Loncastuximab tesirine</a>

9192.</li>

9193<li>

9194<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1514">

9195Bispecific T-cell engagers</a>

9196.</li>

9197<li>

9198<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1258">

9199Palliative radiation therapy</a>

9200.</li>

9201</ol>

9202</div>

9203<section id="_1416">

9204<h4 id="_1416_toc">

9205CAR T-cell therapy for primary refractory disease or relapse within one year</h4>

9206<p id="_1417" tabindex="-1">

9207Patients with DLBCL who relapse during or within 2 months of receiving R-CHOP (rituximab, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone) chemotherapy have primary refractory disease. Any patient with disease relapse within 1 year of R-CHOP chemotherapy or with primary refractory disease has a poor prognosis even with reinduction using chemoimmunotherapy followed by autologous SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_13.1">

92081</a>

9209,<a href="#cit/section_13.2">

92102</a>

9211] Patients who received CAR T-cell therapy had a 40% to 50% 3-year progression-free survival (PFS) rate with a 40-month follow-up, a result equivalent retrospectively to autologous SCT in bone marrow registries.[<a href="#cit/section_13.3">

92123</a>

9213-<a href="#cit/section_13.6">

92146</a>

9215]</p>

9216<p id="_1418" tabindex="-1">

9217Three randomized trials compared chemoimmunotherapy followed by autologous SCT with CAR T-cell therapy with or without bridging chemoimmunotherapy for patients with high-risk relapsed disease defined as primary refractory disease or relapse within 12 months of initial R-CHOP therapy.</p>

9218<p id="_1419" tabindex="-1">

9219Evidence (CAR T-cell therapy):</p>

9220<div class="pdq-content-list">

9221<ol id="_1420">

9222<li>

9223A prospective randomized trial included 359 patients with primary refractory disease or relapse within 12 months of initial R-CHOP chemotherapy. Patients received the CAR T-cell therapy axicabtagene ciloleucel with only bridging steroids or second-line chemoimmunotherapy (usually R-ICE [rituximab, ifosfamide, etoposide, and carboplatin] or R-DHAP [rituximab, dexamethasone, high-dose cytarabine, and cisplatin]) followed by autologous SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_13.7">

92247</a>

9225]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9226<ul id="_1421">

9227<li>

9228With a median follow-up of 24.9 months, the 2-year event-free survival (EFS) rate was 40.5% for patients who received axicabtagene ciloleucel and 16.3% for patients who received chemoimmunotherapy followed by autologous SCT (hazard ratio [HR], 0.398; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.308&#8211;0.514; <em>

9229P</em>

9230 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_13.7">

92317</a>

9232][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9233Level of evidence B1</a>

9234]</li>

9235<li>

9236The OS was not significantly better at 2 years, with an HR of 0.73 (95% CI, 0.53&#8211;1.01; <em>

9237P</em>

9238 = .027).</li>

9239<li>

9240On the chemoimmunotherapy arm of the study, 64% of patients never received autologous SCT because of inadequate response, progression, or death.</li>

9241<li>

9242Clinically meaningful and statistically significant differences in quality of life were obtained in the CAR T-cell arm at day 100 and day 150, compared with the standard of care.[<a href="#cit/section_13.8">

92438</a>

9244][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810019&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810019&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9245Level of evidence A2</a>

9246]</li>

9247<li>

9248Grade 3 or 4 cytokine release syndrome occurred in 6% of patients and grade 3 or 4 neurotoxicity occurred in 21% of patients.</li>

9249</ul>

9250</div>

9251</li>

9252<li>

9253A prospective randomized trial included 184 patients with primary refractory disease or relapse within 12 months of initial R-CHOP chemotherapy. Patients received the CAR T-cell therapy lisocabtagene maraleucel, with 63% of patients receiving bridging therapy or second-line chemoimmunotherapy followed by autologous SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_13.9">

92549</a>

9255]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9256<ul id="_1422">

9257<li>

9258With a median follow-up of 6.2 months, the median PFS was 14.8 months for patients who received lisocabtagene maraleucel and 5.7 months for patients who received chemoimmunotherapy followed by autologous SCT (HR, 0.41; <em>

9259P</em>

9260 = .001).[<a href="#cit/section_13.9">

92619</a>

9262][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9263Level of evidence B1</a>

9264]</li>

9265<li>

9266On the chemoimmunotherapy arm of the study, 53% of patients never received autologous SCT because of inadequate response, progression, or death.[<a href="#cit/section_13.9">

92679</a>

9268]</li>

9269<li>

9270Grade 3 cytokine release syndrome occurred in 1% of patients, and grade 3 neurotoxicity occurred in 4% of patients. There were no grade 4 or 5 occurrences.</li>

9271</ul>

9272</div>

9273</li>

9274<li>

9275A prospective randomized trial included 322 patients with primary refractory disease or relapse within 12 months of initial R-CHOP chemotherapy. Patients received the CAR T-cell therapy tisagenlecleucel, with most patients receiving bridging therapy to achieve response, or second-line chemoimmunotherapy followed by autologous SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_13.10">

927610</a>

9277]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9278<ul id="_1423">

9279<li>

9280There was no difference in EFS for patients in either arm (HR, 1.07; 95% CI, 0.82&#8211;1.40; <em>

9281P</em>

9282 = .69).[<a href="#cit/section_13.10">

928310</a>

9284][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9285Level of evidence B1</a>

9286]</li>

9287<li>

9288In the CAR T-cell therapy arm, 48% of patients received two or more cycles of chemoimmunotherapy as part of bridging therapy. This approach to bridging therapy may have led to an unacceptable number of cases of progressive disease.</li>

9289</ul>

9290</div>

9291</li>

9292</ol>

9293</div>

9294<p id="_1424" tabindex="-1">

9295In summary:</p>

9296<div class="pdq-content-list">

9297<ul id="_1425">

9298<li>

9299For patients with high-risk relapsing DLBCL with primary refractory disease or relapse within 12 months of R-CHOP-based chemotherapy, axicabtagene ciloleucel and lisocabtagene maraleucel are superior induction regimens compared with chemoimmunotherapy with regimens like R-ICE, R-DHAP, and R-GDP (rituximab, gemcitabine, dexamethasone, and cisplatin).</li>

9300<li>

9301The interval until patients receive CAR T cells must be minimized, optimally by using only steroids, eliminating bridging chemoimmunotherapy, and infusing the CAR T-cell product as quickly as possible.</li>

9302<li>

9303The preference for CAR T-cell therapy over chemoimmunotherapy followed by autologous SCT does not apply to patients who relapse more than 12 months after R-CHOP therapy.</li>

9304<li>

9305The American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) has compiled guidelines for the management of adverse events in patients treated with CAR T-cell therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_13.11">

930611</a>

9307]</li>

9308</ul>

9309</div>

9310</section>

9311<section id="_1233">

9312<h4 id="_1233_toc">

9313Bone marrow/stem cell transplantation consolidation</h4>

9314<p id="_1234" tabindex="-1">

9315BMT consolidation is a treatment for patients whose lymphoma has relapsed.[<a href="#cit/section_13.12">

931612</a>

9317] Preliminary studies indicate that approximately 20% to 40% of patients will have a long-term disease-free status, but the precise percentage depends on patient selection and the specific treatment used. Preparative drug regimens have varied; some investigators also use total-body irradiation. Similar success has been achieved using autologous marrow, with or without marrow purging, and allogeneic marrow.[<a href="#cit/section_13.13">

931813</a>

9319-<a href="#cit/section_13.17">

932017</a>

9321]</p>

9322<p id="_1235" tabindex="-1">

9323Evidence (BMT):</p>

9324<div class="pdq-content-list">

9325<ol id="_1236">

9326<li>

9327In a prospective randomized study, (EORTC-PARMA), 215 patients in first or second relapse of aggressive lymphoma, younger than 60 years, and with no bone marrow or central nervous system involvement, were given two cycles of intensive combination chemotherapy. The 109 patients who responded were randomly assigned to receive four more cycles of chemotherapy and involved-field radiation therapy (IF-XRT) versus autologous BMT followed by IF-XRT. With a 5-year median follow-up, the EFS rate was significantly improved with transplantation (46% vs. 12%). The OS rate was also significantly better with transplantation (53% vs. 32%).[<a href="#cit/section_13.18">

932818</a>

9329][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9330Level of evidence A1</a>

9331] Salvage BMT was unsuccessful for patients on the nontransplant arm whose disease relapsed.<p id="_1237" tabindex="-1">

9332In general, patients who responded to initial therapy and who responded to conventional therapy for relapse before the BMT have had the best results.[<a href="#cit/section_13.19">

933319</a>

9334]</p>

9335</li>

9336<li>

9337In a prospective trial, patients who relapsed late (&gt;12 months after diagnosis) had better OS than patients who relapsed earlier (the 8-year survival rate was 29% vs. 13%, <em>

9338P</em>

9339 = .001).[<a href="#cit/section_13.20">

934020</a>

9341][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9342Level of evidence C1</a>

9343]</li>

9344</ol>

9345</div>

9346<p id="_1238" tabindex="-1">

9347Peripheral SCT has yielded results equivalent to standard autologous SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_13.21">

934821</a>

9349,<a href="#cit/section_13.22">

935022</a>

9351] Even patients who never experienced complete remission with conventional chemotherapy may have prolonged PFS (31% at 5 years) after high-dose chemotherapy and hematopoietic SCT if they retain chemosensitivity to reinduction therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_13.23">

935223</a>

9353][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9354Level of evidence C2</a>

9355] Some patients who relapse after a previous autologous SCT can have durable remissions after myeloablative or nonmyeloablative allogeneic SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_13.24">

935624</a>

9357,<a href="#cit/section_13.25">

935825</a>

9359]; [<a href="#cit/section_13.26">

936026</a>

9361][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9362Level of evidence C3</a>

9363] Reduced-intensity conditioning for allogeneic SCT typically involves fludarabine plus busulfan or fludarabine plus cyclophosphamide, with or without 2 Gy of total-body irradiation.[<a href="#cit/section_13.27">

936427</a>

9365]</p>

9366<p id="_1239" tabindex="-1">

9367Evidence (peripheral SCT):</p>

9368<div class="pdq-content-list">

9369<ol id="_1240">

9370<li>

9371In a randomized prospective trial, 396 patients with DLBCL in first relapse or who were refractory to first-line therapy received either R-ICE or R-DHAP followed by autologous SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_13.28">

937228</a>

9373]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9374<ul id="_1241">

9375<li>

9376There was no difference in 3-year EFS or OS.[<a href="#cit/section_13.28">

937728</a>

9378][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9379Level of evidence A1</a>

9380]</li>

9381</ul>

9382</div>

9383</li>

9384<li>

9385In a randomized prospective trial, 619 patients with relapsed or refractory aggressive lymphoma received either R-DHAP or R-GDP followed by autologous SCT.[<a href="#cit/section_13.29">

938629</a>

9387]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9388<ul id="_1242">

9389<li>

9390At a median follow-up of 53 months, there was no difference in EFS or OS, but patients who received R-GDP reported less toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_13.29">

939129</a>

9392][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9393Level of evidence A3</a>

9394] </li>

9395</ul>

9396</div>

9397</li>

9398</ol>

9399</div>

9400</section>

9401<section id="_1248">

9402<h4 id="_1248_toc">

9403CAR T-cell therapy for relapse after autologous SCT</h4>

9404<p id="_1340" tabindex="-1">

9405In the event of disease relapse after autologous SCT, many patients receive consolidation with CAR T-cell therapy.</p>

9406<p id="_1249" tabindex="-1">

9407Multiple trials describe patients with refractory large B-cell lymphoma who underwent an infusion of T cells that were engineered to express a CAR to target the CD19 antigen expressed on the malignant B cells using three different constructs: axicabtagene ciloleucel, tisagenlecleucel, and lisocabtagene maraleucel.[<a href="#cit/section_13.30">

940830</a>

9409-<a href="#cit/section_13.34">

941034</a>

9411] Each study reported a CR rate of 50% to 60% and a 2-year OS rate of 40% to 50%, but the long-term durability of response has yet to be determined in these highly-selected patients.[<a href="#cit/section_13.30">

941230</a>

9413-<a href="#cit/section_13.32">

941432</a>

9415][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9416Level of evidence C3</a>

9417] This therapy is an option for patients with otherwise refractory or resistant disease. These results have been verified off-study in two reports that included 397 patients treated after U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approval.[<a href="#cit/section_13.35">

941835</a>

9419,<a href="#cit/section_13.36">

942036</a>

9421][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9422Level of evidence C3</a>

9423] The highest risk patients who respond adequately may receive a subsequent allogeneic SCT consolidation in some cases if eligible.</p>

9424<p id="_1426" tabindex="-1">

9425ASCO has compiled guidelines for the management of adverse events in patients treated with CAR T-cell therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_13.11">

942611</a>

9427]</p>

9428</section>

9429<section id="_1341">

9430<h4 id="_1341_toc">

9431Tafasitamab plus lenalidomide</h4>

9432<p id="_1342" tabindex="-1">

9433Evidence (tafasitamab plus lenalidomide):</p>

9434<div class="pdq-content-list">

9435<ol id="_1343">

9436<li>

9437In a phase II study, 80 patients with relapsed or refractory DLBCL were treated with tafasitamab, a CD19-directed humanized monoclonal antibody combined with lenalidomide.[<a href="#cit/section_13.37">

943837</a>

9439]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9440<ul id="_1344">

9441<li>

9442The CR rate was 43% and the objective response rate was 60%.</li>

9443</ul>

9444</div>

9445</li>

9446</ol>

9447</div>

9448<p id="_1345" tabindex="-1">

9449The FDA approved the combination of tafasitamab and lenalidomide for patients with relapsed or refractory DLBCL.[<a href="#cit/section_13.37">

945037</a>

9451][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9452Level of evidence C3</a>

9453] It is unclear if using this CD19-directed therapy would interfere with consolidation using CD19-CAR T cells.</p>

9454</section>

9455<section id="_1250">

9456<h4 id="_1250_toc">

9457Rituximab plus lenalidomide</h4>

9458<p id="_1251" tabindex="-1">

9459Evidence (rituximab plus lenalidomide):</p>

9460<div class="pdq-content-list">

9461<ol id="_1252">

9462<li>

9463In two phase II trials, 49 patients showed a 19% to 35% overall response rate to lenalidomide with rituximab.[<a href="#cit/section_13.38">

946438</a>

9465,<a href="#cit/section_13.39">

946639</a>

9467][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9468Level of evidence C3</a>

9469]</li>

9470</ol>

9471</div>

9472</section>

9473<section id="_1253">

9474<h4 id="_1253_toc">

9475Polatuzumab vedotin plus rituximab and bendamustine</h4>

9476<p id="_1427" tabindex="-1">

9477Polatuzumab vedotin is a CD79b-directed monoclonal antibody conjugated to the cytotoxic agent vedotin (an antibody-drug conjugate).</p>

9478<p id="_1254" tabindex="-1">

9479Evidence (polatuzumab vedotin plus rituximab and bendamustine):</p>

9480<div class="pdq-content-list">

9481<ol id="_1255">

9482<li>

9483In a randomized, prospective trial, 80 patients with relapsed or refractory DLBCL were treated with either polatuzumab vedotin combined with bendamustine and rituximab (BR) or BR alone, with a primary end point of complete response.[<a href="#cit/section_13.40">

948440</a>

9485] <div class="pdq-content-list">

9486<ul id="_1256">

9487<li>

9488The CR rate by positron emission tomography&#8722;computed tomography scan was 40% for the polatuzumab vedotin-BR combination, compared with 18% for BR alone (<em>

9489P</em>

9490 = .026).[<a href="#cit/section_13.40">

949140</a>

9492] </li>

9493<li>

9494Similarly, the median PFS was higher for patients who received the polatuzumab vedotin combination (9.5 months) than for the patients who received BR alone (3.7 months) (HR, 0.36; 95% CI, 0.21&#8722;0.63; <em>

9495P</em>

9496 &lt; .001); the OS was 12.4 months for patients who received the polatuzumab vedotin combination versus 4.7 months for the patients who received BR alone (HR, 0.42; 95% CI, 0.24&#8722;0.75; <em>

9497P</em>

9498 = .002).[<a href="#cit/section_13.40">

949940</a>

9500][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9501Level of evidence C1</a>

9502]</li>

9503</ul>

9504</div>

9505</li>

9506</ol>

9507</div>

9508<p id="_1257" tabindex="-1">

9509The FDA approved the combination of polatuzumab vedotin and BR for patients with relapsed or refractory DLBCL.</p>

9510</section>

9511<section id="_1428">

9512<h4 id="_1428_toc">

9513Loncastuximab tesirine</h4>

9514<p id="_1429" tabindex="-1">

9515Loncastuximab tesirine is a CD19-directed antibody conjugated to a pyrrolobenzodiazepine dimer cytotoxin (an antibody-drug conjugate).[<a href="#cit/section_13.41">

951641</a>

9517]</p>

9518<p id="_1430" tabindex="-1">

9519Evidence (loncastuximab tesirine):</p>

9520<div class="pdq-content-list">

9521<ol id="_1431">

9522<li>

9523A phase I and subsequent phase II trial included 184 patients with relapsed or refractory disease.<div class="pdq-content-list">

9524<ul id="_1432">

9525<li>

9526The overall response rate was 48.3% (95% CI, 39.9%&#8211;56.7%) and the CR rate was 24%.[<a href="#cit/section_13.42">

952742</a>

9528,<a href="#cit/section_13.43">

952943</a>

9530][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9531Level of evidence C3</a>

9532]</li>

9533</ul>

9534</div>

9535</li>

9536</ol>

9537</div>

9538</section>

9539<section id="_1514">

9540<h4 id="_1514_toc">

9541Bispecific T-cell engagers</h4>

9542<p id="_1515" tabindex="-1">

9543Bispecific T-cell engagers bind to CD20 (or CD19) and to CD3 to direct T cells to eliminate malignant B cells.[<a href="#cit/section_13.44">

954444</a>

9545] As with CAR T-cell therapy, almost one-half of patients who receive this therapy experience cytokine release syndrome.</p>

9546</section>

9547<section id="_1258">

9548<h4 id="_1258_toc">

9549Palliative radiation therapy</h4>

9550<p id="_1259" tabindex="-1">

9551In general, patients with aggressive lymphoma who relapse with indolent histology will benefit from palliative therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_13.45">

955245</a>

9553] Palliation may be achieved with very low-dose (4 Gy) IF-XRT for patients with indolent and aggressive relapsed disease.[<a href="#cit/section_13.46">

955446</a>

9555]</p>

9556</section>

9557</section>

9558<section id="_TrialSearch_1228_sid_13">

9559<h3 id="_TrialSearch_1228_sid_13_toc">

9560Current Clinical Trials</h3>

9561<p id="_TrialSearch_1228_22" tabindex="-1">

9562Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

9563advanced clinical trial search</a>

9564 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

9565General information</a>

9566 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

9567</section>

Lancet 399 (10343): 2294-2308, 2022.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35717989&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35717989&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9605[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9764 <h2>

9765Treatment of Lymphoblastic Lymphoma (LBL)/Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL)</h2>

9766

9767 <div id="_section_279" class="pdq-sections">

9768<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

9770In This Section</h6>

9771<ul>

9772<li>

9782</li>

9784</a>

9785</li>

9791</nav>

9792<p id="_280" tabindex="-1">

9793LBL is a very aggressive form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), which often occurs in young patients but not exclusively. LBL is the lymphomatous manifestation of ALL. The treatment paradigms are based on trials for ALL because LBL and ALL are considered different manifestations of the same biological disease. LBL is commonly associated with large mediastinal masses and has a high predilection for disseminating to bone marrow and the central nervous system (CNS). Intensive combination chemotherapy with CNS prophylaxis is the standard treatment of this aggressive histological type of NHL. Radiation therapy is sometimes given to areas of bulky tumor masses. Because these forms of NHL tend to progress quickly, combination chemotherapy is instituted rapidly once the diagnosis has been confirmed. For more information, see <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/adult-all-treatment-pdq">

9794Adult Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment</a>

9795.</p>

9796<p id="_478" tabindex="-1">

9797The most important aspects of the pretreatment staging workup include careful review of the following pathological specimens:</p>

9798<div class="pdq-content-list">

9799<ul id="_479">

9800<li>

9801Bone marrow aspirate.</li>

9802<li>

9803Biopsy specimen.</li>

9804<li>

9805Cerebrospinal fluid cytology.</li>

9806<li>

9807Lymphocyte marker.</li>

9808</ul>

9809</div>

9810<section id="_281">

9811<h3 id="_281_toc">

9812Treatment Options for LBL/ALL</h3>

9813<p id="_282" tabindex="-1">

9814Treatment options for LBL include the following:</p>

9815<div class="pdq-content-list">

9816<ol id="_480">

9817<li>

9818<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_283">

9819Intensive therapy</a>

9820.</li>

9821<li>

9822<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_285">

9823Radiation therapy</a>

9824.</li>

9825</ol>

9826</div>

9827<p id="_1492" tabindex="-1">

9828New treatment approaches are being developed by the national cooperative groups. Other approaches include the use of bone marrow transplantation for consolidation.</p>

9829<p id="_598" tabindex="-1">

9830For more information, see <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/adult-all-treatment-pdq">

9831Adult Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment</a>

9832.

9833

9834</p>

9835<section id="_283">

9836<h4 id="_283_toc">

9837Intensive therapy</h4>

9838<p id="_284" tabindex="-1">

9839Standard treatment is intensive combination chemotherapy with CNS prophylaxis.</p>

9840</section>

9841<section id="_285">

9842<h4 id="_285_toc">

9843Radiation therapy</h4>

9844<p id="_286" tabindex="-1">

9845Radiation therapy is sometimes given to areas of bulky tumor masses.</p>

9846</section>

9847</section>

9848<section id="_TrialSearch_279_sid_14">

9849<h3 id="_TrialSearch_279_sid_14_toc">

9850Current Clinical Trials</h3>

9851<p id="_TrialSearch_279_22" tabindex="-1">

9852Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

9853advanced clinical trial search</a>

9854 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

9855General information</a>

9856 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

9857</section>

9858</div>

9859

9860 </section>

9861

9862

9863

9864 <section id="_289">

9865

9866 <h2>

9867Treatment of Diffuse, Small Noncleaved-Cell/Burkitt Lymphoma</h2>

9868

9869 <div id="_section_289" class="pdq-sections">

9870<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

9871<h6>

9872In This Section</h6>

9873<ul>

9874<li>

9875<a href="#_290_toc">

9876Treatment Options for Diffuse, Small Noncleaved-Cell/Burkitt Lymphoma<ul>

9877<li>

9878<a href="#_291_toc">

9879Aggressive multidrug regimens</a>

9880</li>

9881<li>

9882<a href="#_293_toc">

9883CNS prophylaxis </a>

9884</li>

9885</ul>

9886</a>

9887</li>

9888<li>

9889<a href="#_TrialSearch_289_sid_15_toc">

9890Current Clinical Trials</a>

9891</li>

9892</ul>

9893</nav>

9894<p id="_481" tabindex="-1">

9895Diffuse, small noncleaved-cell/Burkitt lymphoma typically involves younger patients and represents the most common type of pediatric non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL).[<a href="#cit/section_15.1">

98961</a>

9897,<a href="#cit/section_15.2">

98982</a>

9899] High-grade B-cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified, includes lymphomas with Burkitt-like or blastoid morphology without double hit cytogenetics, and with germinal center B-cell phenotype.[<a href="#cit/section_15.3">

99003</a>

9901] Up to one-half of patients have a single <em class="gene-name">

9902MYC</em>

9903 rearrangement. Optimal treatment is poorly defined because the diagnosis is rare. Burkitt lymphoma regimens with central nervous system (CNS) prophylaxis are usually chosen.[<a href="#cit/section_15.3">

99043</a>

9905]</p>

9906<section id="_290">

9907<h3 id="_290_toc">

9908Treatment Options for Diffuse, Small Noncleaved-Cell/Burkitt Lymphoma</h3>

9909<p id="_482" tabindex="-1">

9910Treatment options for diffuse, small, noncleaved-cell/Burkitt lymphoma include the following:</p>

9911<div class="pdq-content-list">

9912<ol id="_483">

9913<li>

9914<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_291">

9915Aggressive multidrug regimens</a>

9916.</li>

9917<li>

9918<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_293">

9919CNS prophylaxis</a>

9920.</li>

9921</ol>

9922</div>

9923<section id="_291">

9924<h4 id="_291_toc">

9925Aggressive multidrug regimens</h4>

9926<p id="_377" tabindex="-1">

9927Treatment for diffuse, small noncleaved-cell/Burkitt lymphoma is usually an aggressive multidrug regimen similar to those used for the advanced-stage aggressive lymphomas (such as diffuse large cell).[<a href="#cit/section_15.4">

99284</a>

9929-<a href="#cit/section_15.6">

99306</a>

9931] Adverse prognostic factors include age older than 40 years, high serum lactate dehydrogenase (&gt;3 times normal), Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status of 2 or greater, and CNS involvement.[<a href="#cit/section_15.2">

99322</a>

9933] A retrospective review of 641 adult patients with Burkitt lymphoma from 30 U.S. cancer centers found a 3-year progression-free survival (PFS) rate of 64%. Nineteen percent of patients had CNS involvement, 14% had primary refractory disease, and the treatment-related mortality rate was 10%.[<a href="#cit/section_15.2">

99342</a>

9935]</p>

9936<p id="_378" tabindex="-1">

9937Evidence (aggressive multidrug regimens):</p>

9938<div class="pdq-content-list">

9939<ul id="_501">

9940<li>

9941Aggressive combination chemotherapy patterned after that used in childhood Burkitt lymphoma has been very successful for adult patients. More than 60% of advanced-stage patients were free of disease at 5 years.[<a href="#cit/section_15.6">

99426</a>

9943-<a href="#cit/section_15.9">

99449</a>

9945]</li>

9946<li>

9947Rituximab has been incorporated into these aggressive combination chemotherapy regimens. A nonrandomized, single-arm, prospective, multicenter trial of 363 patients, aged 16 years to 85 years, showed a 5-year PFS rate of 71% and a 5-year overall survival rate of 80%.[<a href="#cit/section_15.5">

99485</a>

9949][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9950Level of evidence C1</a>

9951]</li>

9952</ul>

9953</div>

9954</section>

9955<section id="_293">

9956<h4 id="_293_toc">

9957CNS prophylaxis </h4>

9958<p id="_380" tabindex="-1">

9959Patients with diffuse, small noncleaved-cell/Burkitt lymphoma have a 20% to 30% lifetime risk of CNS involvement. CNS prophylaxis with methotrexate is recommended for all patients, usually given as four to six intrathecal injections.[<a href="#cit/section_15.10">

996010</a>

9961] For more information, see <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/adult-all-treatment-pdq">

9962Adult Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment</a>

9963.</p>

9964<p id="_381" tabindex="-1">

9965Evidence (CNS prophylaxis):</p>

9966<div class="pdq-content-list">

9967<ul id="_502">

9968<li>

9969In a series of 41 patients treated with systemic and intrathecal chemotherapy, 44% of those who presented with CNS disease and 13% of those who relapsed with CNS involvement became long-term disease-free survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_15.11">

997011</a>

9971] CNS relapse patterns were similar whether or not patients received radiation therapy, but increased neurological deficits were noted among those patients who received radiation therapy.</li>

9972</ul>

9973</div>

9974</section>

9975</section>

9976<section id="_TrialSearch_289_sid_15">

9977<h3 id="_TrialSearch_289_sid_15_toc">

9978Current Clinical Trials</h3>

9979<p id="_TrialSearch_289_22" tabindex="-1">

9980Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

9981advanced clinical trial search</a>

9982 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

9983General information</a>

9984 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

9985</section>

9986<h6 do-not-show="toc">

10037

10038

10039

10040 <section id="_315">

10041

10042 <h2>

10043Treatment of NHL During Pregnancy</h2>

10044

10045 <div id="_section_315" class="pdq-sections">

10046<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

10047<h6>

10048In This Section</h6>

10049<ul>

10050<li>

10051<a href="#_316_toc">

10052General Information About NHL During Pregnancy</a>

10053</li>

10054<li>

10055<a href="#_318_toc">

10056Stage Information for NHL During Pregnancy</a>

10057</li>

10058<li>

10059<a href="#_320_toc">

10060Treatment Option Overview for NHL During Pregnancy</a>

10061</li>

10062<li>

10063<a href="#_599_toc">

10064Indolent NHL During Pregnancy</a>

10065</li>

10066<li>

10067<a href="#_490_toc">

10068Aggressive NHL During Pregnancy<ul>

10069<li>

10070<a href="#_491_toc">

10071Immediate therapy</a>

10072</li>

10073<li>

10074<a href="#_601_toc">

10075Early delivery when feasible</a>

10076</li>

10077<li>

10078<a href="#_603_toc">

10079Termination of pregnancy</a>

10080</li>

10081</ul>

10082</a>

10083</li>

10084</ul>

10085</nav>

10086<section id="_316">

10087<h3 id="_316_toc">

10088General Information About NHL During Pregnancy</h3>

10089<p id="_317" tabindex="-1">

10090Non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHL) occur more frequently than Hodgkin lymphoma in an older population. This age difference may account for fewer reports of NHL in pregnant patients.[<a href="#cit/section_16.1">

100911</a>

10092]</p>

10093</section>

10094<section id="_318">

10095<h3 id="_318_toc">

10096Stage Information for NHL During Pregnancy</h3>

10097<p id="_607" tabindex="-1">

10098To avoid exposure to ionizing radiation, magnetic resonance imaging is the preferred tool for staging evaluation.[<a href="#cit/section_16.2">

100992</a>

10100] For more information, see the <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_152">

10101Stage Information for NHL</a>

10102 section.</p>

10103</section>

10104<section id="_320">

10105<h3 id="_320_toc">

10106Treatment Option Overview for NHL During Pregnancy</h3>

10107<table id="_487" class="table-default expandable-container">

10108<caption>

10109Table 5. Treatment Options for Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL) During Pregnancy</caption>

10110<colgroup>

10111<col width="50.00%">

10112<col width="50.00%">

10113</colgroup>

10114<THead>

10115<tr>

10116<th align="Center" scope="col">

10117Stage</th>

10118<th align="Center" scope="col">

10119Treatment Options</th>

10120</tr>

10121</THead>

10122<tbody>

10123<tr>

10124<td>

10125<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_599">

10126Indolent NHL During Pregnancy</a>

10127</td>

10128<td>

10129Delay treatment until after delivery</td>

10130</tr>

10131<tr>

10132<td rowspan="3">

10133<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_490">

10134Aggressive NHL During Pregnancy</a>

10135</td>

10136<td>

10137<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_491">

10138Immediate therapy</a>

10139</td>

10140</tr>

10141<tr>

10142<td>

10143<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_601">

10144Early delivery, when feasible</a>

10145</td>

10146</tr>

10147<tr>

10148<td>

10149<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_603">

10150Termination of pregnancy</a>

10151</td>

10152</tr>

10153</tbody>

10154</table>

10155</section>

10156<section id="_599">

10157<h3 id="_599_toc">

10158Indolent NHL During Pregnancy</h3>

10159<p id="_600" tabindex="-1">

10160Treatment may be delayed for those women with an indolent NHL.</p>

10161</section>

10162<section id="_490">

10163<h3 id="_490_toc">

10164Aggressive NHL During Pregnancy</h3>

10165<section id="_491">

10166<h4 id="_491_toc">

10167Immediate therapy</h4>

10168<p id="_321" tabindex="-1">

10169According to anecdotal case series, most NHLs in pregnant patients are aggressive, and delay of therapy until after delivery appears to have poor outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_16.1">

101701</a>

10171,<a href="#cit/section_16.3">

101723</a>

10173-<a href="#cit/section_16.5">

101745</a>

10175] Consequently, some investigators favor immediate therapy, even during pregnancy.[<a href="#cit/section_16.5">

101765</a>

10177] In a review of 121 patient case reports from 74 papers, one-half of the patients had very aggressive lymphomas, such as Burkitt lymphoma, and one-half of the patients had involvement of the breast, ovaries, uterus, or placenta.[<a href="#cit/section_16.6">

101786</a>

10179] One-half of the patients received therapy antepartum, and the 6-month survival rate was reported at 53%, with a live-birth rate of 83%.[<a href="#cit/section_16.6">

101806</a>

10181][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10182Level of evidence C3</a>

10183]</p>

10184<p id="_815" tabindex="-1">

10185A multicenter retrospective analysis of 50 patients described pregnancy termination in 3 patients, deferral of therapy to postpartum in 15 patients (median 30 weeks gestation), and antenatal therapy applied to the remaining 32 patients (median 21 weeks gestation, all done after the first trimester).[<a href="#cit/section_16.7">

101867</a>

10187] With a median follow-up of 41 months, the 3-year progression-free survival rate was 53%, and the overall survival rate was 82%, using R-CHOP (rituximab, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin hydrochloride, vincristine sulfate, and prednisone) or modifications of this regimen.[<a href="#cit/section_16.7">

101887</a>

10189][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10190Level of evidence C3</a>

10191]</p>

10192</section>

10193<section id="_601">

10194<h4 id="_601_toc">

10195Early delivery when feasible</h4>

10196<p id="_602" tabindex="-1">

10197For some women, early delivery, when feasible, may minimize or avoid exposure to chemotherapy or radiation therapy. </p>

10198</section>

10199<section id="_603">

10200<h4 id="_603_toc">

10201Termination of pregnancy</h4>

10202<p id="_604" tabindex="-1">

10203Termination of pregnancy in the first trimester may be an option that allows immediate therapy for women with aggressive NHL.</p>

10204<p id="_605" tabindex="-1">

10205Evidence (treatment effect on children exposed in utero):</p>

10206<div class="pdq-content-list">

10207<ul id="_606">

10208<li>

10209With follow-up ranging from several months to 11 years, children who were exposed to high-dose doxorubicin-containing combination chemotherapy in utero (especially during the second and third trimester) had normal growth and no evidence of congenital malformations.[<a href="#cit/section_16.5">

102105</a>

10211,<a href="#cit/section_16.8">

102128</a>

10213-<a href="#cit/section_16.10">

1021410</a>

10215] For most of the chemotherapeutic agents used for the treatment of NHL, there are no data regarding long-term effects on children exposed in utero.</li>

10216<li>

10217In one anecdotal case, a newborn exposed to a rituximab-containing regimen in utero was born with no circulating B lymphocytes. The newborn was otherwise healthy and recovered the circulating B lymphocytes by age 6 months with no unusual or persisting intercurrent infections.[<a href="#cit/section_16.11">

1021811</a>

10219] </li>

10220</ul>

10221</div>

10222</section>

10223</section>

10224<h6 do-not-show="toc">
