10273

10274 </section>

10275

10276

10277

10278 <section id="_324">

10279

10280 <h2>

10281Changes to This Summary (05/18/2023)</h2>

10282

10283 <div id="_section_324" class="pdq-sections">

10284<p id="_640" tabindex="-1">

10285The PDQ cancer information summaries are reviewed regularly and updated as

10286new information becomes available. This section describes the latest

10287changes made to this summary as of the date above.</p>

10288<p id="_1520" tabindex="-1">

10289<strong>

10290<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_608">

10291Indolent Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL}</a>

10292</strong>

10293</p>

10294<p id="_1521" tabindex="-1">

10295Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1044">

10296text</a>

10297 to state that CD19-directed chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells may be used in patients who have disease progression after two or more prior lines of therapy (cited Jacobson et al. as reference 30). Also added text to state that mosunetuzumab may also be used in this setting (cited Bartlett et al. as reference 31).</p>

10298<p id="_1522" tabindex="-1">

10299Added Gertz as <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_568">

10300reference 48</a>

10301. Also revised text to state that symptomatic patients with a serum viscosity of four or lower are usually started directly on chemoimmunotherapy or biologically directed therapies. Therapy may be required to correct hemolytic anemia in patients with chronic cold agglutinin disease; rituximab, bendamustine, and steroids are often used. Sutimlimab can reduce hemolysis when therapies directed at the lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma prove ineffective (cited R&#246;th et al. as reference 49).</p>

10302<p id="_1523" tabindex="-1">

10303Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_572">

10304text</a>

10305 to state that splenic marginal zone lymphoma is a distinct clinical entity that usually presents with massive splenomegaly. A variant form of mucosa-associated lymphatic tissue lymphoma is known as immunoproliferative small intestinal disease (cited Rossi et al. as reference 80).</p>

10306<p id="_1524" tabindex="-1">

10307Revised <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_578">

10308text</a>

10309 to state that among patients with concomitant hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection, 40% to 60% attained a complete or partial remission after loss of detectable HCV RNA with antiviral treatment (cited Merli et al. as reference 119).</p>

10310<p id="_1525" tabindex="-1">

10311<strong>

10312<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_81">

10313Aggressive NHL</a>

10314</strong>

10315</p>

10316<p id="_1526" tabindex="-1">

10317Revised <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_87">

10318text</a>

10319 to state that, among patients with advanced-stage disease, 50% are cured with doxorubicin-based combination chemotherapy and rituximab, typically R-CHOP (rituximab, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone).</p>

10320<p id="_1527" tabindex="-1">

10321Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_898">

10322text</a>

10323 to state that true anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK)&#8211;positive large B-cell lymphomas are extremely rare, and they do not respond well to conventional R-CHOP therapy. Anecdotal responses to ALK inhibitors like lorlatinib or alectinib have been reported (cited Soumerai et al. as reference 22 and level of evidence C3).</p>

10324<p id="_1528" tabindex="-1">

10325Added Savage as <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_93">

10326reference 37</a>

10327.</p>

10328<p id="_1530" tabindex="-1">

10329Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1474">

10330text</a>

10331 to state that among patients with primary mediastinal large B-cell lymphoma who had received two prior lines of therapy, more than one-half of patients who received CAR T-cell therapy with lisocabtagene maraleucel had disease response (cited Abramson et al. as reference 53 and level of evidence C3).</p>

10332<p id="_1529" tabindex="-1">

10333Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1475">

10334text</a>

10335 to state that among patients with follicular large cell lymphoma who had received two prior lines of therapy, more than one-half of patients who received CAR T-cell therapy with lisocabtagene maraleucel had disease response.</p>

10336<p id="_1531" tabindex="-1">

10337Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1476">

10338text</a>

10339 to state that a retrospective review of 84 patients with ALK-negative anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL) suggested a survival benefit with autologous stem cell transplantation. This hypothesis requires confirmation in a randomized prospective trial (cited Brink et al. as reference 72).</p>

10340<p id="_1532" tabindex="-1">

10341Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1477">

10342text</a>

10343 to state that primary cutaneous ALCL is a distinct entity that is typically ALK-negative and has a very indolent/low-grade clinical course.</p>

10344<p id="_1533" tabindex="-1">

10345Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1391">

10346text</a>

10347 about a phase II trial of 131 previously untreated patients with mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) aged 65 years or younger. One year of ibrutinib plus 4 weeks of rituximab resulted in a complete response (CR) rate of 89% prior to any chemotherapy consolidation (cited 2022 Wang et al. as reference 210 and level of evidence C3). Another phase II trial using ibrutinib plus rituximab included asymptomatic patients with previously untreated MCL; the CR rate was 87% (cited Gin&#233; et al. as reference 211 and level of evidence C3).</p>

10348<p id="_1534" tabindex="-1">

10349Added Hermine et al. as <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_891">

10350reference 220</a>

10351.</p>

10352<p id="_1535" tabindex="-1">

10353Revised <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1210">

10354text</a>

10355 about the results of phase II trial of brexucabtagene autoleucel in patients with relapsed or refractory MCL whose disease did not respond to ibrutinib or acalabrutinib (cited 2023 Wang et al. as reference 232).</p>

10356<p id="_1536" tabindex="-1">

10357<strong>

10358<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_152">

10359Stage Information for NHL</a>

10360</strong>

10361</p>

10362<p id="_1537" tabindex="-1">

10363Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_157">

10364text</a>

10365 to state that in a retrospective review of over 32,000 cases of lymphoma, up to 40% of diagnoses were made by core needle biopsy, and 60% were made by excisional biopsy (cited Syrykh et al. as reference 1). Core needle biopsy provided a definite diagnosis in 92.3% of cases, and excisional biopsy provided a definite diagnosis in 98.1% of cases.</p>

10366<p id="_1538" tabindex="-1">

10367Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_812">

10368text</a>

10369 about retrospective study of 580 patients with follicular lymphoma that showed no improvement in assessing response to therapy when bone marrow biopsy was added to radiological imaging (cited Rutherford et al. as reference 10).</p>

10370<p id="_1539" tabindex="-1">

10371<strong>

10372<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_193">

10373Treatment of Indolent, Noncontiguous Stage II/III/IV NHL</a>

10374</strong>

10375</p>

10376<p id="_1540" tabindex="-1">

10377Added Morschhauser et al. as <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1186">

10378reference 59</a>

10379.</p>

10380<p id="_1541" tabindex="-1">

10381Revised <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1187">

10382text</a>

10383 about the results of the RELEVANCE trial, which included 1,030 patients with previously untreated follicular lymphoma who were treated with rituximab plus lenalidomide for 18 months or rituximab plus chemotherapy (usually R-CHOP).</p>

10384<p id="_1542" tabindex="-1">

10385<strong>

10386<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_212">

10387Treatment of Indolent, Recurrent NHL</a>

10388</strong>

10389</p>

10390<p id="_1543" tabindex="-1">

10391Revised the <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_497">

10392list</a>

10393 of treatment options for indolent, recurrent NHL to include bispecific T-cell engagers.</p>

10394<p id="_1544" tabindex="-1">

10395Revised <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1396">

10396text</a>

10397 to state that CAR T-cell therapy, with the autologous anti-CD19 therapeutics axicabtagene ciloleucel, lisocabtagene maraleucel, or tisagenlecleucel, has been approved for patients with relapsed follicular lymphoma after two or more lines of prior therapy.</p>

10398<p id="_1545" tabindex="-1">

10399Revised <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1399">

10400results</a>

10401 of a phase II trial of axicabtagene ciloleucel.</p>

10402<p id="_1546" tabindex="-1">

10403Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1399">

10404text</a>

10405 about a phase II trial of 98 patients with relapsed or refractory follicular lymphoma after two or more lines of prior therapy who received anti-CD19 CAR T-cell therapy with tisagenlecleucel (cited Fowler et al. as reference 33 and level of evidence C3).</p>

10406<p id="_1547" tabindex="-1">

10407Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1479">

10408Bispecific T-cell engagers</a>

10409 as a new subsection.</p>

10410<p id="_1548" tabindex="-1">

10411<strong>

10412<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_244">

10413Treatment of Aggressive Stage I and Aggressive, Contiguous Stage II NHL</a>

10414</strong>

10415</p>

10416<p id="_1549" tabindex="-1">

10417Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1222">

10418text</a>

10419 about a retrospective analysis of 341 patients with stage I disease who received R-CHOP (or a similar regimen) with or without radiation therapy (cited Bobillo et al. as reference 7 and level of evidence C3).</p>

10420<p id="_1550" tabindex="-1">

10421Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1060">

10422text</a>

10423 to state that although a retrospective study suggested that patients with stage I extranodal disease and a positive positron emission tomography scan at the end of therapy may benefit from radiation therapy, this hypothesis must be confirmed in a prospective randomized trial.</p>

10424<p id="_1551" tabindex="-1">

10425<strong>

10426<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_258">

10427Treatment of Aggressive, Noncontiguous Stage II/III/IV NHL</a>

10428</strong>

10429</p>

10430<p id="_1552" tabindex="-1">

10431Added Nowakowski et al. as <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1407">

10432reference 10</a>

10433.</p>

10434<p id="_1553" tabindex="-1">

10435<strong>

10436<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1228">

10437Treatment of Aggressive, Recurrent NHL</a>

10438</strong>

10439</p>

10440<p id="_1554" tabindex="-1">

10441Revised the <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1415">

10442list</a>

10443 of treatment options for aggressive, recurrent NHL to include bispecific T-cell engagers and palliative radiation therapy.</p>

10444<p id="_1555" tabindex="-1">

10445Revised <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1421">

10446text</a>

10447 about the results of a prospective randomized trial of CAR T-cell therapy to state that clinically meaningful and statistically significant differences in quality of life were obtained in the CAR T-cell arm at day 100 and day 150, compared with the standard of care (cited Elsawy et al. as reference 8 and level of evidence A2).</p>

10448<p id="_1556" tabindex="-1">

10449Revised <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1422">

10450text</a>

10451 about the results of another prospective randomized trial of CAR T-cell therapy to state that grade 3 cytokine release syndrome occurred in 1% of patients, and grade 3 neurotoxicity occurred in 4% of patients.</p>

10452<p id="_1557" tabindex="-1">

10453Added Calabretta et al. as <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1429">

10454reference 41</a>

10455.</p>

10456<p id="_1558" tabindex="-1">

10457Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_1514">

10458Bispecific T-cell engagers</a>

10459 as a new subsection.</p>

10460<p id="_1559" tabindex="-1">

10461<strong>

10462<a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_289">

10463Treatment of Diffuse, Small Noncleaved-Cell/Burkitt Lymphoma</a>

10464</strong>

10465</p>

10466<p id="_1560" tabindex="-1">

10467Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_481">

10468text</a>

10469 to describe high-grade B-cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified (cited Evens et al as reference 2 and Olszewski et al. as reference 3).</p>

10470<p id="_1561" tabindex="-1">

10471Added <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_377">

10472text</a>

10473 about adverse prognostic factors for diffuse, small noncleaved-cell/Burkitt lymphoma and about the results of a retrospective review of 641 adult patients with Burkitt lymphoma.</p>

10474<p id="_disclaimerHP_3" tabindex="-1">

10475This summary is written and maintained by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/adult-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/adult-treatment">

10476PDQ Adult Treatment Editorial Board</a>

10477, which is

10478editorially independent of NCI. The summary reflects an independent review of

10479the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or NIH. More

10480information about summary policies and the role of the PDQ Editorial Boards in

10481maintaining the PDQ summaries can be found on the <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq#_AboutThis_1">

10482About This PDQ Summary</a>

10483 and <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq">

10484PDQ&#174; Cancer Information for Health Professionals</a>

10485 pages.

10486</p>

10487</div>

10488

10489 </section>

10490

10491

10492

10493 <section id="_AboutThis_1">

10494

10495 <h2>

10496About This PDQ Summary</h2>

10497

10498 <div id="_section_AboutThis_1" class="pdq-sections">

10499<section id="_AboutThis_2">

10500<h3 id="_AboutThis_2_toc">

10501Purpose of This Summary</h3>

10502<p id="_AboutThis_3" tabindex="-1">

10503This PDQ cancer information summary for health professionals provides comprehensive, peer-reviewed, evidence-based information about the treatment of adult non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is intended as a resource to inform and assist clinicians in the care of their patients. It does not provide formal guidelines or recommendations for making health care decisions.</p>

10504</section>

10505<section id="_AboutThis_4">

10506<h3 id="_AboutThis_4_toc">

10507Reviewers and Updates</h3>

10508<p id="_AboutThis_5" tabindex="-1">

10509This summary is reviewed regularly and updated as necessary by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/adult-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/adult-treatment">

10510PDQ Adult Treatment Editorial Board</a>

10511, which is editorially independent of the National Cancer Institute (NCI). The summary reflects an independent review of the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or the National Institutes of Health (NIH).</p>

10512<p id="_AboutThis_22" tabindex="-1">

10513 Board members review recently published articles each month to determine whether an article should:</p>

10514<div class="pdq-content-list">

10515<ul id="_AboutThis_6">

10516<li>

10517be discussed at a meeting,</li>

10518<li>

10519be cited with text, or</li>

10520<li>

10521replace or update an existing article that is already cited.</li>

10522</ul>

10523</div>

10524<p id="_AboutThis_7" tabindex="-1">

10525Changes to the summaries are made through a consensus process in which Board members evaluate the strength of the evidence in the published articles and determine how the article should be included in the summary.</p>

10526<p id="" tabindex="-1">

10527The lead reviewers for Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment are:</p>

10528<div class="pdq-content-list">

10529<ul id="">

10530<li>

10531Eric J. Seifter, MD (Johns Hopkins University)</li>

10532<li>

10533Cole H. Sterling, MD (Johns Hopkins University)</li>

10534</ul>

10535</div>

10536<p id="_AboutThis_9" tabindex="-1">

10537Any comments or questions about the summary content should be submitted to Cancer.gov through the NCI website's <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

10538Email Us</a>

10539. Do not contact the individual Board Members with questions or comments about the summaries. Board members will not respond to individual inquiries.</p>

10540</section>

10541<section id="_AboutThis_10">

10542<h3 id="_AboutThis_10_toc">

10543Levels of Evidence</h3>

10544<p id="_AboutThis_11" tabindex="-1">

10545Some of the reference citations in this summary are accompanied by a level-of-evidence designation. These designations are intended to help readers assess the strength of the evidence supporting the use of specific interventions or approaches. The PDQ Adult Treatment Editorial Board uses a <a href="/publications/pdq/levels-evidence/treatment">

10546formal evidence ranking system</a>

10547 in developing its level-of-evidence designations.</p>

10548</section>

10549<section id="_AboutThis_12">

10550<h3 id="_AboutThis_12_toc">

10551Permission to Use This Summary</h3>

10552<p id="_AboutThis_13" tabindex="-1">

10553PDQ is a registered trademark. Although the content of PDQ documents can be used freely as text, it cannot be identified as an NCI PDQ cancer information summary unless it is presented in its entirety and is regularly updated. However, an author would be permitted to write a sentence such as &#8220;NCI&#8217;s PDQ cancer information summary about breast cancer prevention states the risks succinctly: [include excerpt from the summary].&#8221;</p>

10554<p id="_AboutThis_14" tabindex="-1">

10555The preferred citation for this PDQ summary is:</p>

10556<p id="_AboutThis_15" tabindex="-1">

10557PDQ&#174; Adult Treatment Editorial Board. PDQ Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment. Bethesda, MD: National Cancer Institute. Updated &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. Available at: <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq">

10558https://www.cancer.gov/types/lymphoma/hp/adult-nhl-treatment-pdq</a>

10559. Accessed &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. [PMID: 26389492]</p>

10560<p id="_AboutThis_16" tabindex="-1">

10561Images in this summary are used with permission of the author(s), artist, and/or publisher for use within the PDQ summaries only. Permission to use images outside the context of PDQ information must be obtained from the owner(s) and cannot be granted by the National Cancer Institute. Information about using the illustrations in this summary, along with many other cancer-related images, is available in <a href="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/" title="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/">

10562Visuals Online</a>

10563, a collection of over 2,000 scientific images.

10564

10565</p>

10566</section>

10567<section id="_AboutThis_17">

10568<h3 id="_AboutThis_17_toc">

10569Disclaimer</h3>

10570<p id="_AboutThis_18" tabindex="-1">

10571Based on the strength of the available evidence, treatment options may be described as either &#8220;standard&#8221; or &#8220;under clinical evaluation.&#8221; These classifications should not be used as a basis for insurance reimbursement determinations. More information on insurance coverage is available on Cancer.gov on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care">

10572Managing Cancer Care</a>

10573 page.</p>

10574</section>

10575<section id="_AboutThis_20">

10576<h3 id="_AboutThis_20_toc">

10577Contact Us</h3>

10578<p id="_AboutThis_21" tabindex="-1">

10579More information about contacting us or receiving help with the Cancer.gov website can be found on our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact">

10580Contact Us for Help</a>

10581 page. Questions can also be submitted to Cancer.gov through the website&#8217;s <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

10582Email Us</a>

10583.</p>

10584</section>

10585</div>

10587 </section>

11219 <path
